[Note:] The born do not give birth yet are spontaneously born—thus though born, they do not know how they are born. Not knowing how they are born, birth cannot be severed; not knowing how they die, death cannot be warded off. Yet to desire to perpetuate their life and delimit their end is to be deluded by reckoning.

[Note:] "画" means *to cease*.

[Commentary:] Things that have birth must have an end, just as when harmonious qi sprouts, plants and trees cannot but grow. Yet to desire that they live forever is to be deluded by the supreme reckoning. Lu Wenchang says: The Zhang edition has "尽" (*cease*) for "画," with the note: "尽 means *to cease*." Yu Yue says: "画" means *to stop*. In the *Analects*, *Yongye* chapter, "今女画" (*now you stop*), Kong’s note says: "画 means *to stop*." "画其终" (*delimit its end*) means to stop it from ending. Above it states: "The born are those whose principle must end"—thus birth fundamentally cannot be made eternal, and ending fundamentally cannot be stopped. Yet to desire to "perpetuate their life and delimit their end"—this is why it is called delusion. Zhang’s note says: "画 means *to cease*," but it likely originally read "画止也" (*to stop and cease*), then became corrupted due to graphic similarity. The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Benwei* chapter states: "The Dao ceases that to rectify the self," but today it is mistakenly written as "止彼在己" (*stops that to be in the self*), which can serve as mutual proof. Yin Jingshun’s *Shiwen* says: "画 is also written as 尽," but this is a character error. In *Qunshu Shibu*, Lu Wenchang says: "The Zhang edition has 尽, with the note: 尽 means *to cease*," but this is incorrect.

Bo Jun notes: Yu’s interpretation is correct. The Zang edition, Northern Song edition, and Lu Chongxuan edition have "尽," but we now follow the Shidetang edition and emend it.

The *Shiwen* notes: "画 is read as *huai*, *strategy*."

One version reads *jin*, but this does not enhance the meaning.

"Spirit and essence are Heaven’s *you*;"
The *Shiwen* writes *fen* as *jiu*, noting: "*Jiu* is read as *you*; the same below." Originally written in seal script, it resembled the character *jiu*. According to the *Hanshu*, Yang Wangsun said: "Spirit and essence are Heaven’s *you*; bones and frame are Earth’s *you*." Wangsun frequently read this text, and the present edition of the Directorate of Education writes *fen*. Ren Dachun said: "Modern editions sometimes write *fen*, which is the Directorate of Education edition referred to in the *Shiwen*." Examining the *Huainanzi*’s *Jingshen Xun*: "Thus spirit and essence are Heaven’s *you*, while bones and frame are Earth’s *you*." Again, in "Huozi held to Heaven and Earth," Gao You’s commentary states: "Spirit and essence are Heaven’s *you*; form and frame are Earth’s *you*," all following this passage in the *Liezi*. Thus, the versions seen by Han scholars all wrote *you*, not *fen*. Jingshun’s *Shiwen* states that *jiu* should be *you*, which can still be verified in ancient editions. Sun Yirang said: The *Shiwen*’s claim that "*jiu* should be *you*" is correct. However, the seal script of *you* does not closely resemble *jiu*. I suspect that the alternate edition consulted by Yin wrote *you* as *you* (又), whose seal form (□) resembles that of *jiu* (□). *You* (又) and *you* (有) were interchangeable in antiquity, so Yin directly identified it as *you*.

"Bones and frame are Earth’s *fen*."
That which belongs to Heaven is clear and disperses; that which belongs to Earth is turbid and congeals. When spirit and essence depart from form, each returns to its true origin.
[Note] That which is Heaven’s *fen* returns to Heaven; that which is Earth’s *fen* returns to Earth, each reverting to its root. Thus it is called *gui*.
*Gui* means *to return*, to return to its true dwelling.
[Note] The true dwelling is the realm of the Great Void.
[Exegesis] When spirit and numinosity depart from form, it is called death. Returning to the true dwelling is reverting to the Great Clarity. Taking the Great Clarity as the true dwelling clarifies that this form and frame are but empty illusion.

Wang Chongmin said: Below the second *gui*, the original text included the word *zhe* (者), which is now omitted in modern editions. The *Han Shi Waizhuan* states: "The dead become *gui*. *Gui* means *to return*." The *Lunheng*’s *Lunsi* chapter says: "When a person dies, their spirit ascends to Heaven, and their bones return to Earth, hence they are called *gui*. *Gui* means *to return*." The *Fengsu Tong* states: "Death is *si* (澌); *gui* means *to return*. Spirit and essence dissipate, while flesh and bones return to the earth." In all these cases, *gui* is followed by *zhe*, which confirms this. The *Yilin* quotes the correct text as: "*Gui zhe* means *to return*."

The Yellow Emperor said: "When spirit and essence enter its gate, and bones and frame return to their root, what remains of me?"
[Note] What life lacks form, what form lacks *qi*, what *qi* lacks numinosity? Thus, mind, wisdom, form, and frame are but one body of yin and yang, a partial accumulation of a single *qi*. When they depart from form and return to their root, they revert to their true dwelling, and "I" cease to be anything at all.
[Exegesis] Ordinary people take form as "I," and from "I" arise emotions. Those with many emotions are deeply mired in attachment, while those with few desires have thinner cravings. Only the perfected person is without "I," fully comprehending their spirit. Ordinary people, unaware, cling ever more stubbornly.

When the spirit returns to the true, and the form returns to the earth, where then does the former "I" reside?

[Bo Jun’s note] *Gen* ("root") and *cun* ("abide") rhyme, both belonging to the ancient *wen* rhyme group.

Another interpretation: *Feng zhi* ("stubborn attachment") should be *feng zhi* ("nurtured growth"), as seen in *Zuozhuan* (Duke Zhao, Year 2).

From birth to death, the great transformation encompasses four stages:
[Note] Within these transitions, there is no moment of pause—these four are but a broad outline.

[Exegesis] The infant, in whom right and wrong have yet to arise in the heart, possesses deep virtue and single-minded focus. When desires and thoughts flourish, they invite many assaults. In old age, *qi* softens, drawing nearer to the Dao. At life’s final limit, one comes to rest.

[Lu Wenchong’s note] The annotation "no moment of pause" in the *Zang* edition reads the same below.

[Bo Jun’s note] The original text does not separate paragraphs; this division follows the meaning.

The *Shiwen* reads *ben jiao* ("fundamental outline") as *da jiao* ("broad outline"), noting: *Jiao* is pronounced *jue*.

The four stages are: infancy, youth and prime, old age, and death.

In infancy, *qi* is focused and the will undivided—harmony at its peak. Nothing harms it, and no virtue surpasses it.
[Note] *Laozi* says, "One whose virtue is deeply stored is like a newborn child."

In youth and prime, blood and *qi* surge and overflow, while desires and thoughts flourish. External things assail it, and virtue thus declines.

At the stage of youth and prime, one dwells in the realm of striving and contention—where external things do not align.
[Note] *Shiwen* reads *gu* ("thus") as *yin* ("correct"), noting: *Yin* means "upright." Another version reads *gu*.

In old age, desires and thoughts soften; the body prepares for rest, and nothing takes precedence.
[Note] *Xiu* means "to cease." Without a heart of competition, external things do not contend with it.
[Note] *Shiwen* notes: *Zheng* is pronounced *zheng*.

Though not as complete as infancy, it surpasses youth and prime.
[Bo Jun’s note] *Jian* means "rest" or "peace," as seen in the *Guoyu*’s *Jin Yu* annotation and the *Chu Ci*’s *Zhao Hun* annotation. It describes how, in old age, one attains tranquility compared to the surging *qi*, flourishing desires, and restless thoughts of youth and prime. Some say it should be read as *jian* in the *Lunyu*’s *Zi Han* chapter ("when the illness abates"), meaning "separation."
[Note] *Shiwen* notes: *Jian* is pronounced *jian*, meaning "to divide."

At death, one comes to rest, returning to the ultimate limit.
[Exegesis] Nearness to nature aligns one with the Dao, while delusion by emotion severs authenticity. Thus, one whose virtue is deeply stored is like a newborn child. Even weariness without action remains secondary—far superior to the reckless striving of the world.

Confucius wandered on Mount Tai—*Shiwen* notes *Tai* is written as *Da* (大), pronounced *Tai* (泰). He encountered Rong Qiqi walking in the wilds of Cheng—*Bo Jun* notes: The *Huainanzi*’s *Zhushu Xun* states, "Rong Qiqi played a single tune, and Confucius rejoiced for three days, moved by its harmony," likely referring to this same Rong Qiqi. *Shiwen* notes: *Cheng* is pronounced *Cheng* (成), the name of a fief in Lu. *Bo Jun* notes: *Cheng* is also written as *Cheng* (成), originally a state name; King Wu of Zhou enfeoffed his younger brother Shu Wu there. By the Spring and Autumn period, it belonged to Lu as a fief of the Meng clan. It lies ninety *li* northeast of present-day Ningyang County in the Tai’an region of Shandong.

Clad in a deerskin robe and girded with a hempen rope—Shen Tao remarks: A *deerskin robe* refers to a coarse fur garment, not one made of deer; a *deer cart* denotes a simple cart, not one drawn by deer. The character for "coarse" (粗) contains three "deer" (鹿), hence *lu* carries the sense of coarseness. The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Guisheng Pian* speaks of Yan He wearing a *deer-cloth robe*, meaning a garment of rough cloth. *Bo Jun* notes: The *Hanfeizi*’s *Wudu Pian* states, "In winter, a deerskin robe; in summer, ramie clothing—even the attire of a gatekeeper’s servant does not fall below this" (the original text reads *ni* (麑) for *deer*, but this is corrected following the *Li Si Zhuan* and the *Taiping Yulan*’s citations in chapters 27, 80, and 694). The *Records of the Grand Historian*’s *Autobiographical Afterword* says, "In summer, ramie clothing; in winter, a deerskin robe." The *Huainanzi*’s *Jingshen Xun* states, "Embroidered silks and fox-fur robes are what people desire, yet Yao concealed his form in plain cloth and wore a deerskin robe against the cold"—thus, a deerskin robe was winter’s humble garb. *Shiwen* notes: *Suo* (索) is pronounced *sùo* (先各切).

He strummed his zither and sang.

Confucius asked, "Master, what is the reason for your joy?"

*Wang Chongmin* notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (468) cites "以" as "为," while the *Yiwen Leiju* (44) renders it "先生为乐何也," with "以" likewise as "为." *Shiwen* reads "以乐" as "为乐," stating: *Le* is pronounced *luò* (洛), and the same applies below.

He replied, "My joys are many. Heaven generates the myriad things, yet only humans are noble—this is my first joy. That I have attained human form is one joy.

**[Note]**: Extending this reasoning, it becomes clear that the *qi* and spirit of humans differ not from those of other beings; only their destinies diverge, hence their forms vary. Thus, Rong Qiqi deeply probed the hidden causes of fortune and misfortune, penetrating the workings of the unseen and manifest. Therefore, he rejoiced in surpassing the forms of others and in attaining the esteemed male form—how could this be mere reckless speech?

*Bo Jun* notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (468) reads "吾既得为人," aligning with the syntax of the following phrases, "吾既得为男" and "吾既己行年九十." The *Shuo Yuan*’s *Za Yan* chapter has "吾既己得为人," while the *Kongzi Jiayu* (6) reads "吾既得为人." It is likely that the *Kongzi Jiayu* preserves the correct version.

As for the distinction between male and female, *Shiwen* notes: *Bie* (别) is pronounced *bǐe liè* (彼列切). Since men are honored and women humbled, the male form is esteemed. That I have attained the male form is my second joy.

**[Note]**: Before birth, whether one becomes male or female is not predetermined, hence the additional joy of attaining a male body.

*Shiwen* notes: *Fen* (分) is pronounced *fú wèn* (扶问切); *fù* (复) is pronounced *fú yòu* (扶又切).

There are those who do not live to see the sun and moon, who never leave swaddling clothes. *Shiwen* reads "襁褓" as "襁保," stating: *Qiǎng* (襁) is pronounced *jū liǎng* (居两切); some versions write it as *qiǎng* (襁). *Bǎo* (褓): The *Bowuzhi* states it is woven from threads, eight *cun* wide and one *chi* two *cun* long, used to secure infants on the back.

That I have already lived ninety years is my third joy.

*Wang Chongmin* notes: The *Yiwen Leiju* (44) reads "吾年九十有五矣," suggesting that the present *Liezi* text omits "有五" after "九十." The *Shuo Yuan*’s *Za Yan* chapter and the *Taiping Yulan* (509), citing the *Shengxian Gaoshi Zhuan*, both read "九十有五." The *Gaoshi Zhuan* likely relied on an older version of the *Liezi*, confirming that "有五" originally followed "九十."

*Bo Jun* notes: There are two *Gaoshi Zhuan*: one by Huangfu Mi, whose *Shiquan Lun* in the *Jin Shu*’s *Huangfu Mi Zhuan* states, "Rong Qiqi’s three joys moved Confucius," referring to this passage. The other, by Xi Kang, titled *Shengxian Gaoshi Zhuan*, also includes this figure, as cited in the *Taiping Yulan* (509). The *Yiwen Leiju* (36), citing Sun Chu’s *Rong Qiqi Zan*, draws from pre-Qin and Han texts, not the *Liezi*. Tao Qian’s *Drinking Wine* poem, "At ninety, he girds himself with rope," references this passage, showing that some versions read simply "九十."

Poverty is the constant lot of the scholar; death is the end of all humans.

*Bo Jun* notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (468) reads, "贫者人之常，死者命之终." The *Yiwen Leiju* (44) has, "贫者士之常，死者生之终."

Abiding in this constant and accepting life’s end—

*Lu Wenchang* notes: "得" in the *Shuo Yuan*’s *Za Yan* chapter is written as "待."

*Wang Chongmin* notes: "待" is correct. Rong Qiqi, content with Heaven’s decree and understanding fate, recognized that poverty is the scholar’s norm and death the end of all humans. Thus, he declared himself at ease with the constant, awaiting life’s end—what cause for sorrow? If written as "得," it would miss the point.

The *Taiping Yulan* (468) indeed reads "待." The *Yiwen Leiju* (44) has "居常以待终," with minor variations but the same meaning, and the "待" is unmistakably correct.

*Bo Jun* notes: Lu and Wang are correct. The following chapter’s Zhang Zhan commentary states, "Content with Heaven’s decree and understanding fate, he awaited life’s end with equanimity." The phrase "待终" clearly echoes this passage, showing that Zhang’s version still read "待."

—what cause for sorrow is there?"

*Bo Jun* notes: "当" should be read as "尚." The *Records of the Grand Historian*’s *Wei Gongzi Liezhuan* states, "If Qin destroys Daliang and razes the ancestral temples of our former kings, with what face could you stand in the world?" Here, "当" should likewise be read as "尚," providing mutual confirmation.

Confucius said, "Excellent! He is one who can console himself."

**[Note]**: Unable to entirely forget joy and sorrow, Confucius praised his ability to reason and find self-consolation.

**[Explanation]**: Just as a great smith casts metal, shaping it to the mold, so too does the spirit form its vessel, giving rise to all shapes. The length of life for men and women is predetermined by yin and yang. Why? The spirit enacts its work, and the form repays it in kind. Since the form cannot comprehend itself, the spirit, though formless, already knows. Qiqi only began to rejoice in his later years, for he came to the Dao late. His emotions remained bound to form, so Confucius merely praised his self-consolation, not his profound grasp of the ultimate Dao.

Lin Lei was nearly a hundred years old.

**[Note]**: No records of him exist in transmitted texts; he was likely an ancient recluse.

*Bo Jun* notes: "且" means "将." *Shiwen* notes: *Lèi* (类) is pronounced *lèi* (泪); versions writing it as *yǐng* (颍) are mistakenly conflating it with another character.

In late spring, he wore a fur robe.

**[Note]**: "底" means "当." The final "也" is added following the *Sijie* edition.

*Bo Jun* notes: The *Shuowen* states: *Qiú* (裘) is a fur garment, with a variant *qiú* (求). *Qiú* (求) depicts the shape of a fur robe, likely the original character. All fur garments are called *qiú*, without distinction of quality. Later writers sometimes used it to denote fine attire, as in the *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s "In early winter, the Son of Heaven first dons fur robes," the *Huainanzi*’s *Fanlun Xun*’s "The world considers fur robes rare and precious," and the *Gongyang Zhuan*’s *Huan 8* commentary, "Fur and linen are the finest garments for warding off cold and heat." These are examples of such usage.

Moreover, it can also serve as attire for the impoverished, as in the *Zhuangzi*’s *Tianxia* chapter: "Causing later Mohists to wear coarse fur and hemp garments and don straw sandals as their attire." Cheng Xuanying’s commentary explains: "Fur and hemp are rough clothing." The *Xinshu*’s *Zashi* chapter five states: "Formerly, Master Chuqiu, at seventy years of age, wore a fur robe tied with a rope and went to see Lord Mengchang." This passage’s "in late spring, he wore a fur robe" is another such example.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Dǐ* is pronounced *dǔ lǐ*; *bèi* is read as *bèi*.

Gleaning forgotten grain from the old fields—
**[Note]**: After the harvest, gathering the abandoned grain from the fields.
The *Shiwen* notes: *Suì* is pronounced *suì*; *qí* is read as *xié*; *jùn* is pronounced *jū yùn*.

Singing as they walked side by side.
**Bo Jun** notes: "Singing as they walked side by side" means singing while advancing.
The *Shiwen* notes: *Bìng* is pronounced *páng làng*; the same below. It means walking alongside the fields.

Confucius traveled to Wei and saw him in the countryside. Turning to his disciples, he said: "That old man may be someone worth speaking to. Try going to question him!"
The *Shiwen* notes: *Sǒu* is pronounced *xī kǒu*. One version reads "There is—try going to question him," with *xùn* pronounced *xìn*; another omits the word "there."

Zigong requested to go. Meeting him at the end of the ridge,
The *Shiwen* notes: *Lǒng* is pronounced *lì zhǒng*.

He faced him and sighed, saying: "Sir, have you no regrets, singing and gleaning grain as you go?"
Lin Lei did not pause in his steps nor cease his song.
The *Shiwen* notes: *Chuò* is pronounced *dīng liè*, meaning "to stop."

Zigong pressed him repeatedly,
The *Shiwen* notes: *Kòu* is pronounced *qiū hòu*.

Until he looked up and replied: "What should I regret?"
Zigong said: "In your youth, you did not strive in conduct;
The *Shiwen* notes: *Shào* is pronounced *shī zhào*; *xíng* is read as *xià mèng*, the same below.

In your prime, you did not compete with the times;
The *Shiwen* notes: *Zhǎng* is pronounced *dīng zhàng*, the same below.

Now in old age, you have no wife or children, and death approaches—what joy is there in gleaning grain and singing as you go?"
The *Shiwen* notes: *Lè* is pronounced *luò*.

Lin Lei laughed and said: "The reason I find joy is something everyone possesses, yet they turn it into sorrow.
**[Note]**: What I find joy in is shared by all, but they fail to remain equanimous in the face of events, so they never experience fleeting happiness.
**[Explanation]**: The benevolent know no sorrow; the wise know no fear. They are not bound by form. Life is allotted to me—why should the gentleman grieve over poverty and low status or rush after wealth and nobility? Those who do not understand this turn it into sorrow—why be surprised at me?

In youth, I did not strive in conduct; in my prime, I did not compete with the times—thus I have attained such longevity.
**[Note]**: Not striving in conduct means forsaking fame and reputation; not competing with the times means abandoning profit and desire. With neither in one’s heart, a lifespan of a hundred years is not sought but naturally attained.
**[Explanation]**: Striving in improper conduct and competing for time beyond fate—seeking what cannot be grasped—harms life and shortens years. My joy lies in understanding Heaven and knowing fate, thus attaining this longevity.
**Wang Lai** says: In Lu’s explanation, "seeking what cannot be grasped" (*qiú zhī bù bá*), *bá* should be *huò*.
The *Shiwen* notes: *Shòu* is pronounced *shòu*.

In old age, I have no wife or children, and death approaches—thus I find such joy.
**[Note]**: This is what is meant by understanding Heaven and knowing fate, hence no sorrow.
**[Explanation]**: Wife and children are enough to weary the mind and trouble the heart—how could they extend one’s lifespan? Living in constant expectation of death, with no sorrow or grief, is why I find such joy.

Zigong said: "Longevity is what people desire; death is what they detest.
**Bo Jun** notes: The *Hanshu*’s *Biography of Dong Zhongshu* states: "Desire is what people feel." It also says: "What people feel is called desire." The *Hou Hanshu*’s *Biography of Zhang Heng* commentary states: "Desire is what the nature feels." The ancients often paired desire and aversion in parallel, as in the *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Lun Wei* chapter: "People desire life and detest death." Thus, *qíng* here should be glossed as *desire*.
The *Shiwen* notes: *È* is pronounced *wū lù*.

Why do you find joy in death?"
Lin Lei said: "Death and life are but departure and return. Thus, one who dies here—how do we know they are not born there? **Liang Zhangju** says: The theory of transmigration likely originates here. Therefore, I know they are not unequal.
**Yu Yue** says: The word *ān* ("how") is missing after *wú* ("I"). Above, it says "death and life are but departure and return," so it should read "how do I know they are not equal," meaning death and life are one. Below, it says "how do I know that busily seeking life is not delusion?"—this directly follows. If it read "I know they are not equal," it would contradict the meaning entirely. Later scribes, seeing two instances of *ān zhī* ("how do I know") ending with *hū* ("?"), and this one ending with *yǐ* ("!"), thought it inconsistent and rashly deleted *ān*. They did not realize *yǐ* functions like *hū*—the difference is merely one of emphasis. Ancient texts often use *yǐ* in place of *hū*; for details, see Wang’s *Jingzhuan Shici*.
**Wu Kaisheng** argues that *gù* should be read as *gù* ("certainly"), meaning "I certainly know," which contradicts Yu’s interpretation. Yu’s view is preferable.

How do I know that busily seeking life is not delusion? How do I know that my death now is not better than my past life?"
**[Note]**: Following this principle, existence and nonexistence alternate endlessly.
**[Explanation]**: Knowing that form undergoes transformation while spirit knows no death or life—departure and return are like morning and evening. Why busily cling to this and fear that?
**Wang Shumin** says: After "seeking life," the word *zhī* ("it") should be added.

The *Wen Xuan* annotation to Bao Mingyuan’s *Poem on Taking Medicine at the City’s Eastern Bridge* indeed includes the word *zhi*. The *Shiwen* notes: *yu* is pronounced *yǔ*.

Zigong heard this and did not grasp its meaning. He returned and reported it to the Master. The *Shiwen* notes: *gao* ("reported") is read as *gǔwò*; the same applies below.

The Master said: "I knew he could be spoken with—sure enough. Yet what he attained was not yet complete."
**[Note]**: Hearing Lin Lei’s words so abruptly, Zigong believed he had reached the utmost. Yet the Master declared it still incomplete. "Complete" means nothing is left unexhausted, nor is anything exhausted—only then is principle wholly fulfilled. Now, when one opposes nonbeing to being, relinquishes that to grasp this, one cannot but sense the difference between inner and outer. Yet what remains incomplete is but a trifling part. As for the myriad transformations returning to the Mysterious One, where self and other are both forgotten, principle naturally levels itself, and in truth nothing is cast aside. When inner and outer merge in darkness and wander freely, becoming one with the multitude—how could there be completeness or incompleteness?

**[Explanation]**: To die here and live there is the inevitable principle. What Lin Lei called "how do I know" is merely ambiguous speech, hence the Master said it was not yet complete. In the note, "darkly within, freely without" (*ming nei you wai*), the Northern Song edition reads *you* ("freely") as *ni* ("contrary"); Wang’s edition follows this error. Here, it is corrected according to the *Daozang* and *Shidetang* editions. The *Shiwen* notes: *cu* ("abruptly") is read *cāngmò*; *zao* ("attained") is read *qīdào*; *qu* ("relinquishes") is read *qiūlǚ*; *chu* ("part") is read *chāngjù*.

Zigong, weary of study, said to Confucius: "I wish to rest for a while."
**[Note]**: Study is the means to recover one’s original nature, yet when one grows weary of it, the principle of spontaneity is impaired. The *Jinxiu Wanhua Gu* (Qianji 20) and *He Bi Shi Lei* (Qianji 43) read: "reported to Confucius, saying." The *Shiwen* notes: *yan* ("weary") is read *yùyàn*.

Confucius said: "In life, there is no rest."
**[Note]**: Exerting the mind and taxing the limbs—these are the affairs of the living. Zhuangzi said: "Life is corvée labor."

Zigong said: "Then does that mean I have no place to rest?"
Wang Shumin says: "Rest nowhere" (*xi wu suo*) likely originally read "nowhere to rest" (*wu suo xi*), following the above phrase "no rest in life." In the present edition, the word *xi* ("rest") is mistakenly transposed above "nowhere."

Bo Jun notes: Judging from the reply below, "rest nowhere" is not in error.

Confucius said: "There is, of course. Look to the grave mounds—
The *Shiwen* notes: *kuàng* is read *kuàng*; it means the burial pit. Xunzi has a chapter by this name.
—lofty as a high terrace,
Bo Jun notes: The *Xunzi* *Dalüe* chapter reads *gao ru* ("lofty as").
Liu Taigong says: *Yi* ("lofty") is the same as *gao* ("high").
Wang Niansun says: The *Kongzi Jiayu* *Kunshi* chapter also reads *yi ru*.
Wang Su says: *Yi* means "tall."
The *Shiwen* notes: *yi* is read *gāo*.
—orderly as a chief minister,
The *Shiwen* notes: It means "like the prime minister."
—mounded like a hill,
Lu Wenchang says: *Fen ru* means "like a great embankment."
The *Shiwen* notes: It means "like a grave mound."
—partitioned like a tripod."
Hao Yixing says: *Ge ru* likely resembles an inverted cauldron, narrow above and wide below—many such are seen today.
The *Shiwen* notes: *ge* is read *lì*; its shape is like a *ding*. It may also be read *gé*.

"Then you will know where rest lies."
**[Note]**: Seeing the grave’s earthen partitions and wings, one knows rest has its place. Zhuangzi said: "Death is repose."

Zigong said: "How great is death! The noble man rests there; the petty man lies low there."
**[Note]**: Knowing destiny and delighting in Heaven, awaiting the end with equanimity—this is how the noble man rests. Escaping sorrow and suffering, dying in darkness—this is how the petty man lies low.
Bo Jun notes: The *Xunzi* *Dalüe* chapter and *Kongzi Jiayu* *Kunshi* chapter both include this passage.
The *Shiwen* notes: *Fu yan* ("lies low") in Xunzi reads *xiu yan* ("reposes"). *Le* ("delight") is read *luò*; the same applies below. *Qu* ("escaping") is read *qiūlǚ*; *li* ("sorrow") is read *lìzhì*; *mei* ("darkness") is read *mèi*.
Wu Kaisheng says: *Xi* ("rests") and *fu* ("lies low") rhyme; reading *xiu* ("reposes") is incorrect.

Confucius said: "Ci! You have understood."

Man knows only the joys of life, not its sorrows;
knows only the weariness of old age,
not its ease.
He knows the dread of death,
yet not death as repose.

**[Note]**: *Zhuangzi* says: "The great clod burdens me with form, labors me with life, eases me with old age, and reposes me in death."
**[Exegesis]**: Life is the substance of activity and use; only in death can one truly rest. It is like the sun’s streaming light—all things move without cease. The noble man pursues fame; the petty man pursues profit; neither ever pauses.

Bo Jun notes: The passage cited in the note is from the *Zhuangzi* *Da Zongshi* chapter.
*Yanzi* says: "How excellent that the ancients had death!
**[Note]**: Life and death are the same in all ages, yet he praises only the death of the ancients—this shows that the ancients did not delight in life or dread death.
The virtuous find repose in it; the unvirtuous lie low in it."
**[Note]**: Those who cultivate themselves and act with caution, ever mindful of vigilance—these are the virtuous, whose concern is constant. Those who indulge in greed and excess, never satisfied—these are the unvirtuous, whose suffering is ceaseless. Only in death do they find rest and repose.

Bo Jun notes: This is from the *Yanzi Chunqiu* *Neijian* chapter.
Death is the culmination of virtue.
**[Note]**: *De* means "attainment"; *jiao* means "return." It speaks of each attaining its proper return. The ancients called the dead "those who have returned." If the dead are called "those who have returned," then the living are "those who are traveling." To travel without knowing one’s return is to lose one’s home. If one man loses his home, his generation will condemn him; if the world loses its home, none will condemn it.
**[Note]**: This is the mutual deception of the many and the few. *Yanzi* and the Mohists made their teachings their home, yet those who prized bodily life did not distinguish this—such words are merely attributed to them.

**[Exegesis]**: *Laozi* says: "Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called the restoration of mandate; restoration of mandate is called constancy; knowing constancy is called illumination. Not knowing constancy, one acts recklessly—calamity follows." The spirit’s possession of form is but a single term’s recompense. Deluded by the root and clinging to existence, one wearies the spirit and torments the heart—exhaustion reaches its limit. Only in death does one return to the true, like casting off shackles and laying down a burden. Those who cling to life and death, foolishly attached to existence, do not know to return to the root—yet the world does not condemn them as deluded, for such are many.

Bo Jun notes: *Zhuangzi* *Qi Wu Lun* says: "All their lives they toil without seeing success, wearily worn out and not knowing their return—how pitiful!" This is precisely the meaning here. Also, the present *Yanzi Chunqiu* *Neijian* chapter reads: *Yanzi* said, "Long ago, the Lord Above regarded man’s passing as good. The virtuous find repose in it; the unvirtuous lie low in it." *Liezi*’s quotation differs only in these three lines. The slight variation in the first line reflects how the ancients, when citing texts, did not adhere strictly to the original wording. Considering the placement of this note, it seems to treat all from "none will condemn it" onward as *Yanzi*’s words, hence the comment about attribution. Yet *Yanzi* did indeed say this—Chu Du simply had not seen the *Yanzi* text.

Is there a man who leaves his homeland, parts from his six relations, abandons his family’s livelihood, and wanders the four directions without returning—what manner of man is he? The world will surely call him a mad and dissolute man. And is there a man who clings to worldly worth,
**[Note]**: "Clinging to worldly worth" should read "prizing bodily life."
who prides himself on skill and ability, cultivates fame and reputation, and vaunts himself before the world, yet does not know himself—what manner of man is he?

The world will surely deem him a man of wisdom and strategy. These two types are both lost men. Though their conduct differs in small ways, neither escapes drowning and ruin.

Lu Wenchang: "Drowning" should read "weakness," as in the *Zhuangzi*; the same applies below.
Bo Jun’s note: The *Zhuangzi*’s "Equalizing Things" states, "How do I know that hating death is not weakness and ruin, forgetting one’s return?"—this is Lu’s source.

Yet the world approves one and rejects the other. Only the sage knows what to embrace and what to abandon. Those who treat life and death as waking and dreaming are to be embraced; those who drown and forget their return are to be abandoned.

To abandon the root and chase the branch, to labor the spirit and exhaust the mind—whether following emotions to seek fame or pursuing desires to chase profit—both are lost. What is thick, what is thin? What the multitude calls right, the whole world deems correct; what the common cling to, the whole world deems wrong. Only those who possess the Dao know what to leave and what to take.

Thus *Zhuangzi* says: Zang and Gu were both herding sheep, and both lost their sheep. One was absorbed in gambling, the other in reading. Though their good and evil differed, the loss of the sheep was the same. If the Dao is lost, then wandering the world and pursuing learning—how far apart are they?

Qin Enfu: In the *Zhuangzi*, when asked what Zang was doing, one said, "Gambling." When asked what Gu was doing, one said, "Reading." Lu’s note adds an extra "absorbed" after "gambling," which is likely superfluous.
Bo Jun’s note: Here, *yu* (与) means "to grant," as in the *Analects* ("I grant that you are not as good") and the *Zuozhuan* ("You grant it to him"). The *Liezi* often uses it to mean "to take," and the meanings are interchangeable. The next chapter states: "Stillness and emptiness obtain their proper place; taking and granting lose their place." Stillness and emptiness are synonymous, so taking and granting are also synonymous. Further, in the *Yang Zhu* chapter: "Fame is not what reality takes; reality is not what fame grants." The interchange of *qu* (取, "take") and *yu* (与, "grant") confirms this.

Someone asked Master Liezi: "Why do you value emptiness?"
Xu Weiyu: The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s "No Duality" states: "Master Liezi valued emptiness."
Liezi said: "Emptiness is not to be valued."
All valuing arises from preferring this over that, affirming oneself and negating things. Now, with the two forgotten and the ten thousand differences merged into one, this is called emptiness. Since emptiness is empty, where can the names of noble and base arise?

It is not its name. When affairs are manifestly real, they are not obtained through borrowed names. Nothing compares to stillness, nothing compares to emptiness. Stillness and emptiness obtain their proper place; taking and granting lose their place.

The principle of emptiness and stillness lies beyond the calculations of the mind and the confines of the body. Seek and obtain it, and it is your nature. When inwardly settled in oneself, one is naturally whole and true. Thus, what preserves things does so through emptiness and stillness, obtaining their place of rest; what ruins them does so through movement and seeking, losing their proper place.

Someone asked about valuing emptiness. The answer was: "There is nothing to value. My fondness for emptiness is not for its name. When an empty room gives rise to brightness, auspiciousness comes to rest. Only stillness, only emptiness, obtains its proper place. If one is greedy for taking and granting, the spirit loses its peace. Then names, profits, right and wrong converge in contention—how can one bear it? Thus, emptiness is not what *I* value."

When affairs are broken and ruined, then one dances with benevolence and righteousness—yet they cannot be restored.

One should act before things arise and govern before disorder begins. When things are already damaged and decayed, then to drum up benevolence and righteousness in hopes of returning to the utmost of nature and life—this cannot be achieved.

What I call emptiness is cultivation before disorder arises. If true nature is broken and ruined, the spirit muddled and confused, then to play with the words of benevolence and righteousness or stir the waves of human emotions—this cannot restore it.

Tao Hongqing: Zhang’s note interprets "dancing with benevolence and righteousness" as "drumming up benevolence and righteousness," which is incorrect. *Wu* (舞) should be read as in "dancing with words." In the "Confucius" chapter, "to act as if dancing—what will those who come think?" Zhang’s note interprets *wu* as "to play with," which is correct. It means that after affairs are broken and ruined, one applies benevolence and righteousness to patch them up, yet what is ruined cannot be made whole again. The *Daodejing*’s first chapter states, "When the great Dao declines, there is benevolence and righteousness." The *Zhuangzi*’s "Horse’s Hooves" states, "The sage hobbles for benevolence, limps for righteousness, and the world begins to doubt"—this is the same idea. The note does not grasp it.

The character *sang* (丧) is pronounced *xilang*. Zhu Xiung states: Liang Zhangju says: Among the various Masters’ texts, the *Yuzi* is the most ancient, yet there are two versions of it. The *Han shu*’s "Yiwen zhi" lists twenty-two *pian* of Daoist *Yuzi shuo* and nineteen *pian* of *xiaoshuo* *Yuzi shuo*. The *Liezi* cites *Yuzi* three times, all expounding the Yellow Emperor and Laozi’s teachings on purity and tranquility, which differ from the present text. It is likely that these are the Daoist twenty-two *pian*. Bo Jun notes: The current one-*juan* *Yuzi*, since Ye Mengde of the Song dynasty, has been widely suspected as spurious. The *Siku quanshu zongmu tiyao* suggests it was "a forgery by later enthusiasts, modeled after the passages cited by Jia Yi," which is plausible.

The *Shiwen* states: *Yu* is pronounced *yu*. Yu Xiong was the teacher of King Wen of Zhou, enfeoffed in Chu, and authored twenty-two *pian* of writings.

"Revolving without cease"—the *Shiwen* states: *yi* is pronounced *yi*.
"Heaven and earth shift imperceptibly—who perceives it?"

**[Annotation]** This aligns with the *Zhuangzi*’s "boat and valley" passage. Confucius said, "Day and night without pause, I thus pass away." All things embody transformation, and their forms shift with it. Transformation never halts for a moment—how can things remain unchanged? Thus, the form that lived before is not the form that lives now. In the space between a downward and upward glance, ten thousand changes have already occurred. Qi disperses, form decays—not suddenly, but by degrees. Yet the deluded cling to vessels of inevitable change, entrust themselves to ceaseless motion, and claim they can escape transformation. Is this not lamentable?

Bo Jun notes: The original text does not separate paragraphs; the division here follows the meaning.

The *Shiwen* states: *cao* is pronounced *qidao*.

"Thus, what is diminished there is filled here; what is completed here is depleted there."

**[Annotation]** As the saying goes: "When rivers run dry, valleys empty; when hills level, abysses fill." Loss and gain, fullness and emptiness follow the world and accompany death.

**[Annotation]** Here, *shi* (世) should also be read as *sheng* (生).

Bo Jun notes: The *Zhuangzi*’s "Da zongshi" states, "Nothing is not destroyed, nothing is not completed," which conveys the same idea.

The *Shiwen* states: *shi* is pronounced *sheng* below as well.

"Coming and going in succession, with no gap to omit—who perceives it?"

**[Annotation]** One who has just achieved completion already suffers loss; one who has just been born is already secretly dying.

The *Shiwen* states: *sheng* is read in the upper tone.

"Qi does not advance all at once"—Bo Jun notes: *Jin* (进) originally means "to ascend," as in the *Shuowen*. It also means "to advance," as in the *Mao shi*’s "Changwu" *jiang*, the *Shi guan li* *zhu*, and the *Gongyang*’s commentary on the thirteenth year of Duke Zhuang. By extension, it takes the meaning of "growth." Thus, in the *Zhou li*’s "Xiao sikou," "to regulate the state’s expenditures by advancing or retreating them," Zheng Xuan’s annotation explains: "Advancing and retreating mean increasing and decreasing." Here, *jin* contrasts with *kui* (亏), and below, "unaware of its completion" follows "does not advance all at once," while "unaware of its loss" follows "does not diminish all at once." Thus, *jin* is akin to *cheng* (成).

The *Shiwen* states: *jin* is pronounced *jinyi*.
"A form does not diminish all at once; one is unaware of its completion, unaware of its loss."

**[Annotation]** All occurs in obscurity, transforming imperceptibly—how could ears and eyes perceive it?

Lu Wenchang notes: In the *Zang* edition, the annotation includes the character *zhi* (之) after "ears and eyes."

Bo Jun notes: The original text lacks the character *yi* (亦) before "unaware of its loss"; it has been added here following the *Sijie* edition and the Qin engraving.

The *Shiwen* states: *zhan* is written as *zhu*, pronounced *zhu*; one version writes it as *zhan*.

"It is like a person from birth"—the *Shiwen* states: *shi* is pronounced *sheng*.

"To old age: appearance, complexion, wisdom, and demeanor change daily; skin, nails, and hair fall away with the world, not remaining as they were in infancy."

**[Annotation]** Form, color, hair, and skin are the coarser aspects of existence. Even these, renewed and replaced, escape recognition—how much more so the subtler aspects?

Bo Jun notes: In the annotation, *zhi cu* (之粗) should not be written as *jing* (精). Lu Baojing’s punctuation, treating "form, color, hair, and skin" as a complete phrase, is also incorrect.

"With no perceptible interval, one only knows afterward."

**[Exegesis]** The mind’s subtle operations, the stirring of yin and yang—thus the body transforms, heaven and earth shift imperceptibly, and loss, gain, fullness, and emptiness proceed. Who can awaken to this? Therefore, those who value the Dao know the root and do not grieve over loss.

In the state of Qi, there was a man who fretted that heaven and earth would collapse, leaving him nowhere to dwell, and thus neglected sleep and food. The *Chuxue ji* writes "there was a man" as "once there was a man."

The *Shiwen* states: *zhui* is written as *sui*.
The *Xiben* states: Tang of Yin enfeoffed the Xia descendants in Qi; the Zhou later enfeoffed them there as well. Today, it is Yongqiu County in Chenliu. During the Wude era, it was once established as Qi Prefecture.

Ren Dachun notes: The *Chuci*’s "Jiu ge" writes *shijiao zhui xi* (矢交坠兮) with *zhui* as *sui*. In the *Xunzi*’s "Ru xiao" chapter, "until their heads meet and the mountains *sui*," Yang Liang’s annotation reads: "*Sui* is read as *zhui*." The *Huainanzi*’s "Shuolin xun" states, "Things suspended and hanging may *sui* at times," with the annotation: "*Sui* means *zhui*." In the *Han shu*’s "Wang Mang zhuan," "not *sui* like a hair," and in the "Xu zhuan," "their lineage will not *sui*," *bu sui* means *bu zhui*. The *Lishi*’s "Xixia song" and the "Heng hai jiangjun Lü jun bei" write *yun sui* as *yun zhui*. The "Fan An bei" writes *shi sui* as *shi zhui*. The *Jingshun shiwen* still preserves the ancient character.

Bo Jun notes: Wude was the reign title of Emperor Gaozu of Tang. Huang Yaopu suspected the *Shiwen* was a Song forgery (see the postscript to the Northern Song edition of the *Liezi*), but this passage disproves that. Moreover, the state of Qi, enfeoffed at the beginning of the Zhou, corresponds to present-day Qi County in the Kaifeng region of Henan. The *Shiji* includes its *shijia*.

There was another who, troubled by the first man’s worries, went to enlighten him.

**[Annotation]** The first man’s worries were misguided, yet the second, though not misguided himself, worried over the first man’s misguided concerns rather than the actual cause of his distress. This analogy illustrates how accumulated delusions deepen—how could one enlighten the other?

The *Daozang* edition’s annotation includes the character *zai* 哉 after *ye* 也.

Bo Jun notes: The annotation "以不忧忧彼之所忧" should read "不忧彼之所忧."

He said: "Heaven is but accumulated *qi*, without place lacking *qi*. As you bend and stretch, inhale and exhale, you move and rest within it all day—why fear its collapse?"

**[Annotation]** The azure of heaven is not a solid substance. Thus, what we call "heaven" is not merely distant and boundless. All above the earth is heaven. Therefore, in every breath and movement, you never depart from it.

The *Hebi Shilei Qianji* cites this as: "Why fear its collapse?"

The man said: "If heaven is truly accumulated *qi*, should not the sun, moon, and stars fall?"

**[Annotation]** *Xiu* (lunar lodges), pronounced identically below.

The enlightener replied: "The sun, moon, and stars are but luminous entities within accumulated *qi*."

**[Annotation]** What is *qi* incapable of sustaining? Even the vastness of heaven and earth abides naturally within the realm of the Great Void—how much more so the mutual support of *qi* itself?

The *Yulin* (vol. 2) cites *chen* 辰 instead of *xiu* 宿.

Wang Chongmin notes: The character *zhi* 之 after "enlightener" is redundant, carried over from the earlier phrase "went to enlighten him." The *Yulin* (vol. 2) cites this as "the enlightener said," omitting *zhi*. The subsequent passage, "The enlightener said, 'Earth is but accumulated clods...'" also lacks *zhi*, confirming this.

The phrase "luminous entities within accumulated *qi*" in the *Yulin* (vols. 3 and 6) inverts "within" and "*qi*," which may reflect the original.

**[Annotation]** *Sheng* 勝, pronounced *sheng*.

"Even if they fell, they could cause no harm."

The *Yiwen Leiju* (vol. 1), *Chuxue Ji* (vol. 1), and *Shiwen Leiju Qianji* (vol. 2) cite this as "正复使坠."

Wu Kaisheng notes: *Zhishi* 只使 means "even if," though it is not language from the Three Dynasties.

**[Annotation]** *Zhong* 中, pronounced *dingzhong*.

The man said: "What of the earth’s ruin?"

The enlightener replied: "Earth is but accumulated clods."

**[Annotation]** *Kuai* 块, pronounced *koudui*.

"It fills the four voids, without place lacking clods."

**[Annotation]** *Sai* 塞, pronounced *suze*.

Bo Jun notes: The *Yanshi Jiaxun*’s "Guixin" chapter states, "Heaven is accumulated *qi*; earth is accumulated clods," seemingly drawing from this passage.

"As you tread and trample upon it, you move and rest upon the earth all day—why fear its ruin?"

**[Annotation]** The four characters *chu* 躇, *bu* 步, *ci* 跐, and *dao* 蹈 all describe the act of treading.

*Chu* 躇, pronounced *chu*; *ci* 跐, pronounced *ci*; *dao* 蹈, pronounced *tudao*.

The man, suddenly relieved, rejoiced greatly.

**[Annotation]** *She* 舍 should be *shi* 释; in this text, *shi* is written as *she*.

**[Annotation]** *She* 舍, pronounced *shi*, identically below.

The enlightener, too, was suddenly relieved and rejoiced greatly.

**[Annotation]** These two men—one fretted over inevitable destruction, the other rejoiced in inevitable preservation. Neither understood the true grounds for worry or joy, yet they consoled and enlightened each other, resolving their own doubts. This remains no less than profound delusion.

**[Exegesis]** Heaven is accumulated *qi*—where is *qi* absent? Earth is accumulated clods—where are clods absent? Clods conceal nothing; *qi* collapses nowhere. The sun and moon are luminous entities within *qi*—why fear their collapse?

**[Annotation]** In the *Daozang* and *Shidetang* editions, "必败" replaces "必破."

Upon hearing this, Changluzi laughed.

Bo Jun notes: The *Yulin* (vol. 2) omits *zhi* 之, which is correct and should be deleted. The subsequent passage, "When Master Liezi heard this, he laughed," also lacks *zhi*, confirming this.

**[Annotation]** The *Shiwen* cites *Changluzi* as *Changluzǐ*, noting: The *Records of the Grand Historian* mentions a Changluzi from Chu. The *Hanshu* states that Changluzi authored nine chapters, classified under the Daoist school.

Ren Dachun notes: The *Xunzi*’s "Fuguo" chapter reads "君卢屋妾," with Yang Liang’s annotation glossing *lúwū* as *lúwū* (hut). The *Zhuangzi*’s "Rangwang" chapter mentions "□水," with the *Shiwen* reading *lǘ* (闾), while Sima Biao’s edition has *Lu* (卢) water. The *Huainanzi*’s "Shuolin Xun" states, "The potter uses a cracked basin; the carpenter dwells in a narrow *lú* (庐)," where *lú* is *lú* (hut). The *Guoyu*’s "Jinyu" reads, "侏儒扶卢," with Wei Zhao’s annotation: "*Lu* is the shaft of a spear or halberd." The *Kaogong Ji* states, "Qin lacks *lú*," with the annotation: "The handle of a spear or halberd, a bundled bamboo shaft." Thus, *lu* and *lú* are interchangeable. The *Wu Yue Chunqiu* reads "吴子柯卢," while the *Shiji* writes *lú* (庐) instead of *lu* (卢). The *Zuozhuan* (Duke Huan, Year 13) *Shiwen* reads *lúróng* (庐戎) as written, with some editions using *lu* (卢), pronounced identically. The *Zuozhuan* (Duke Cheng, Year 13) *Shiwen* reads *Bólú* (伯庐), pronounced *lìwú*, with some editions using *lu* (卢). Thus, *lu* and *lú* are interchangeable, corroborating the *Shiwen*’s *lú* (卢). Furthermore, the *Shiji*’s "Shen Dao" chapter mentions "Chu had Shizi Changlu," with the *Suoyin* noting, "Changlu is unclear," evidently unaware of this passage in the *Liezi*.

He said: "Rainbows and mirages, clouds and mist, wind and rain, the four seasons—these are the formations of accumulated *qi* that constitute heaven. Mountains and peaks, rivers and seas, metals and stones, fire and wood—these are the formations of accumulated shapes that constitute earth. Knowing that heaven is accumulated *qi* and earth accumulated clods—how can one claim they do not decay?"

**[Annotation]** Before the primordial chaos divided, heaven and earth were one *qi*, and the myriad things were one form. Once separated into heaven and earth, dispersed into the myriad things, this reflects only the divergence of convergence and dispersion, the emptiness and fullness of form and *qi*. Heaven and earth are but a tiny thing within the void, the greatest entity within the bounded. That they are difficult to exhaust or fathom is surely so.

**[Annotation]** *Zui* 最, pronounced *ziwai*.

Difficult to fathom, difficult to comprehend—this is surely so.

**[Annotation]** *Zhong* 终 and *qiong* 穷 rhyme, both in the ancient *dong* 冬 rhyme group. *Ce* 测 and *shi* 识 rhyme, both in the ancient *zhi* 职/*de* 德 rhyme group.

Those who fret over their decay are indeed far off the mark; those who claim they do not decay are likewise mistaken. Heaven and earth cannot but decay, and thus must return to decay. When their time of decay arrives, how can one not grieve?

**[Annotation]** This is to know that what has a beginning must have an end, and what has form must decay; yet it fails to recognize the vicissitudes of fortune and the ascent and descent of yin and yang, the rise and fall of vessels and heaven and earth.

**[Exegesis]** Accumulated *qi* and accumulated clods form heaven and earth. What is accumulated and formed cannot but decay. Yet their vastness makes their end difficult to perceive. If one encounters their time of decay, one cannot but grieve.

**[Note]** The original text read *bi bai* 必败 ("must fail") for *bi huai* 必坏 ("must decay"); this has been emended following the *Zang* 藏 edition. Another exegesis reads the four characters *bu de bu you* 不得不忧 ("cannot but grieve") as *he de bu you* 何得不忧 ("how can one not grieve"). *Bu ke ze jian* 不可则见 should read *bu ke ce jian* 不可测见 ("cannot be perceived").

Master Liezi heard this and laughed, saying: "Those who speak of heaven and earth decaying are mistaken, and those who speak of them not decaying are likewise mistaken. Decay and non-decay—I cannot know which is so. Nevertheless, that is one possibility, and this is another.

**[Annotation]** "That" refers to those who claim non-decay; "this" refers to those who claim decay.

If they do not decay, then they endure together with humanity; if they decay, then they perish together with humanity. Why rejoice or grieve over such a matter? Thus, the living do not know death, and the dead do not know life; the coming do not know the going, and the going do not know the coming."

"Decay or non-decay—how could I harbor concern for such a matter?"

**[Annotation]** Not knowing life is like not knowing death. Thus, when things come to be, none know their dissolution; and when they dissolve, how can one know their coming to be? This is the manifest proof of going and coming, the clear evidence of success and failure. Yet I am equally present in both, with no distinction of feeling between them—where could the heart find room to dwell?

**[Exegesis]** Now, heaven and earth are the greatest of things, while bodily forms are the smallest. Yet the great are but one thing, and the small are but one thing. All things must decay—why debate the matter? Moreover, in life one does not know death, and in death one does not know life; coming and going are not self-aware, and success and failure cannot be fathomed. If one examines oneself closely, one cannot even know these things—why then expend the heart’s effort on heaven and earth, or grieve and debate over matters beyond the realm of things?

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *See* (見) is pronounced *xiàn*. *Chu* (处) is pronounced *chǔ*.

Shun asked Zheng, saying—**[Annotation]** Pi Xirui notes: *Zheng* (烝) should be *Cheng* (丞). **[Collation]** Bo Jun observes: Pi’s emendation is correct. The *Zhuangzi* "Knowledge Wanders North" chapter writes it as *Cheng* (丞), and the *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (519) also cites it as *Cheng*. The *Phonetic Gloss* writes *Zheng* (烝) as *Cheng* (丞), noting: "Cheng refers to an assistant or minister; one variant writes it as *Zheng*." Ren Dachun comments: The *Han Shu* "Table of the Kings’ Sons and Lords" records "Chengyang Lord Jing," with Yan Shigu noting: "*Cheng* is pronounced *zhēng*; the character may also be written as *Cheng* (丞)." In the *Biography of Zhai Fangjin*, "the Grand Protector’s assistant Chengyang Lord Zhen Han," Yan Shigu notes: "*Cheng* is pronounced *zhēng*." The *Hou Han Shu* "Treatise on Commanderies and States" writes it as *Zhengyang* Lord. Since *Cheng* (承) and *Cheng* (丞) both have the pronunciation *zhēng*, they are interchangeable as *Zheng* (烝). Jing Shun’s *Phonetic Gloss* preserves the ancient reading by writing *Cheng* (丞) as *Zheng* (烝).

"Can the Dao be possessed and held?"

**[Annotation]** Shun wished to clarify that all beings are ultimately the same as non-being, so he took the Dao as the starting point of his question.

Lu Wenchang notes: At the end of the annotation, the Zang edition includes the character *ye* (也).

The reply came: "Your body is not your own—how could you possess the Dao?"

**[Annotation]** Guo Xiang says: The body is not something you can possess; it simply exists of itself, a mere clod. If you do not even possess what you have, how much less can you possess what you do not have?

**[Exegesis]** "You" and "I" are merely designations for self and other in bodily form, not references to the spirit. Common usage takes one’s own body as "I" and others as "you." How then can one seek to possess the Dao? Thus it is said: "Your body is not your own—how could you possess the Dao?"

Shun said: "If my body is not my own, then who possesses it?"

**[Annotation]** Since one possesses this body, the question is posed again.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Chong* (重) is pronounced *zhòng*; the same below.

The reply came: "It is the form bestowed by heaven and earth."

**[Annotation]** It is a partial accumulation of the single qi.

Yu Yue notes: The *Strategies of the Warring States* ("Qi Strategies") states: "I wish to entrust it to Zihigh," with the commentary: "*Wei* (委) means to entrust." The *Zuozhuan* (Duke Cheng, second year) records: "The king sent it to be entrusted to the three officials." Du Yu’s commentary: "*Wei* (委) means to assign." Thus, "the form bestowed by heaven and earth" means the form assigned by heaven and earth. The three subsequent instances of *wei* (委) follow the same sense.

"Life is not your own—it is the harmony bestowed by heaven and earth."

**[Annotation]** The accumulation of harmony gives rise to life.

"Your nature and destiny are not your own—they are the compliance bestowed by heaven and earth."

**[Annotation]** The accumulation of compliance results in preservation and perishing.

Guo Xiang says: If the body were yours to possess, then beauty and ugliness, life and death would be determined by you. Yet when qi gathers to form life, you cannot prevent it; when qi scatters in death, you cannot halt it. This shows that it forms and completes itself through its own bestowal—it is not yours to possess.

"Your children and grandchildren are not your own—they are the moltings bestowed by heaven and earth."

**[Annotation]** Qi naturally accumulates and sheds like a cicada’s molting. If they were yours to possess, then the number of sons and daughters would also be determined by you.

**[Collation]** The *Liu Tie* (10) and *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (519) cite "children and grandchildren" as "descendants." It is likely that this should be followed. Zhang’s commentary on the passage below reads: "Where are descendants bestowed and molted?" suggesting that his edition also read "descendants."

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Tui* (蜕) is pronounced *shuì*.

Thus, in walking one does not know where one is going; in dwelling one does not know what one is holding; in eating one does not know the reason for it.

**[Annotation]** All arise spontaneously from within, not through conscious knowledge.

Yu Yue notes: The *Zhuangzi* "Knowledge Wanders North" chapter writes: "In eating, one does not know the taste."

Wang Shumin says: The *Exegesis of the Sage’s Meaning* by Emperor Huizong of Song and Fan Zhixu’s *Exegesis* both read "does not know the taste" for "does not know the reason," matching the *Zhuangzi*.

"The forceful yang of heaven and earth is qi—how then could it be possessed?"

The empty space here [indicates a lacuna in the text].

**[Annotation]** Heaven and earth are the greatest of the interwoven knots of return. Now, in walking, dwelling, eating, and resting, all are movements of the forceful yang qi—how could one recognize their underlying reason? "Forceful yang" means "unyielding solidity." If it is not the ultimate principle of unyielding solidity, and one returns instead to the extreme of emptiness and harmony, then there is no form, no life, no death, no end—so where could one’s nature and life be entrusted and follow? Where could descendants be entrusted and molted? Where could walking and dwelling find rest? On what could eating and drinking depend?

**[Exegesis]** Since one does not know that the numinous and luminous are the Dao, one borrows heaven and earth to explain it. Heaven governs numinous function; earth governs formed things. Those who engage with existence entrust their forms; those who embody harmony give rise to their natures; those who respond in function follow and comply; those who nurture emotions and rear offspring entrust and molt. Now, in your walking, stopping, eating, and resting, you know only the movements of forceful yang, yet do not know the true master of the numinous and luminous. How then could you possess the Dao?

Someone asked: "Yu Shun was a sage—how could he not know the Dao?"
The answer: "When one borrows guest and host to debate confusion, how could one remain in profound silence alone? Yet *Zhuangzi* says: 'Puliang Yi had the talent of a sage but not the Dao of a sage; I have the Dao of a sage but not the talent of a sage.' Thus, those who possess talent to aid the world and occupy the throne of the ruler do not necessarily know the Dao. Those who dwell beneath mountain forests with a reputation for solitary integrity do not necessarily govern others. Therefore, the Yellow Emperor, after thirty years on the throne, only then dreamed of the Land of Huaxu. Yao, after meeting the Four Masters, only then gazed in wonder at the northern bank of the Fen River. That Shun had not yet awakened—what is strange about that?"

**[Note]** In the line "If it is not unyielding solidity," four editions read "and is not unyielding solidity."

Wang Chongmin says: In the *Zhuangzi* "Knowledge Wanders North" chapter, there is a "之" after "heaven and earth," which cannot be omitted here. It is likely that the *Liezi* originally included this "之," but it is now missing from the current edition.

Guo Xiang’s commentary states: "Forceful yang is merely movement." Furthermore, in the "Parables" chapter, it says: "If they come, I come with them; if they go, I go with them; if they are forceful yang, I am forceful yang with them." Guo Xiang’s commentary explains: "Simply following the spontaneous movements of forceful yang in coming and going." Thus, "forceful yang" carries the meaning of movement, likely sharing the same iterative rhyme as *changyang* and *xiangyang*. This means that the life, nature, and descendants of the self are not possessed by the person but are all interwoven knots of heaven and earth. Moreover, one does not know that the rotation and movement of heaven and earth are also the work of a single qi. If one understands that the rotation of heaven and earth is the movement of qi, then how could anything between heaven and earth be possessed? The phrase "the forceful yang of heaven and earth" should be punctuated after "heaven and earth." Without the "之," the meaning would be unclear.

Zhang’s commentary says: "Forceful yang means unyielding solidity," which is incorrect.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Fu* (復) is pronounced *fú*.

The Guo family of Qi was immensely wealthy, while the Xiang family of Song was extremely poor.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Xiang* (向) is pronounced *xiàng*.

The Xiang family traveled from Song to Qi to ask for their method. The Guo family told them: "I am skilled in theft. When I first began stealing, after one year I had enough; after two years, I was sufficient; after three years, I greatly prospered."

**[Note]** *Rang* (穰) was originally written as *rang* (壤).

Hong Yi says: In the *Zhuangzi* "Gengsang Chu" chapter, it says: "After three years, the people of Weilei greatly prospered." The phonetic gloss notes: "Cui’s edition writes *rang* (穰)." In ancient times, the character *rang* (穰) was always written as *rang* (壤).

Wang Chongmin says: The *Shuowen* defines *rang* (穰) as "millet that has sprouted and grown." Under the character *yang* (秧), it says: "Rice seedlings are like *yangrang* (秧穰)." *Yangrang* are iterative rhyme characters, like *rangrang* (穰穰). Thus, *rang* has two meanings, and *yangrang* is the origin of the meaning of "great prosperity" here. Furthermore, according to the *Shuowen*, *rang* (壤) means "soft earth." Since *rang* (壤) is the ancient character, there is no evidence for it in antiquity, and it is likely that later people confused the two. The meaning of *rang* (穰) is closer to the intended sense. Xu Shen also used it to explain characters, so *rang* (穰) is the older form. The Cui edition of *Zhuangzi* and the alternate edition seen by Lu Deming both write *rang* (穰), as does the *Liezi* Jifu edition and the *Taiping Yulan* (485), which also write *rang* (穰).

Yang Bojun’s note: Wang’s argument is sound; here, we follow the Jifu edition in writing *rang* (穰).

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Rang* (穰) is written as *rang* (壤), glossed as *rǎng*, and also written as *rang* (穰).

"From then on, [my prosperity] extended to the towns and villages."

**[Note]** *Shi* (施) means "to bestow" (as in the *Guoyu* commentary to "Duke Qi loved to display his efforts and bestow favors").

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Shi* (施) is pronounced *yì*, meaning "to extend."

The Xiang family was overjoyed. They understood the words about theft but did not grasp the Dao of theft.

**[Note]** In the *Liu Tie* (91), the first "understood" (*yu*, 喻) is written as "heard" (*wen*, 聞), and "Dao" (道) is written as "meaning" (*yi*, 意).

They then climbed walls and tunneled through houses, taking everything their hands and eyes reached.

**[Note]** In the *Liu Tie* (91), "tunneled through houses" (*zao shi*, 凿室) is written as "pierced the eaves" (*chuan yu*, 穿宇), and "taking" (*tan ye*, 探也) is written as "taking away" (*tan qu*, 探取).

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Wang* (亡) is pronounced *wú*; the same below.

Before long, they were caught with stolen goods and punished.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Zang* (赃) is pronounced *zāng*.

They lost all the wealth they had previously accumulated.

Yu Yue says: "Accumulated" (*ju*, 居) means "stored," referring to the wealth they had previously stored. In the *Analects*, "Zang Wenzhong accumulated a *cai*" (*Lunyu* "Gongye Chang"), and Huang Kan’s commentary says: "*Ju* means 'to store.'" This is the same meaning.

Wu Kaisheng says: *Ju* (居) should be read as *zhu* (贮).

Wang Chongmin says: The *Taiping Yulan* (485) writes "former lord" (*xian jun*, 先君), which is better in meaning.

Yang Bojun’s note: In the "King Mu of Zhou" chapter, it says: "Offering half of his accumulated wealth to request their methods." Here, *ju* also means "to accumulate." Yu’s and Wu’s interpretations are the same and can both be used. The *Taiping Yulan* does not grasp the meaning and arbitrarily changes it to "lord" (*jun*, 君), which cannot be trusted.

The *Explanation of Text* states: "Former" (*xian*, 先) is pronounced *xiàn* (悉荐切).

When the Xiang clan was deceived by the Guo clan, Qian Yi says: "Deceived" (*miu*, 谬) means "to cheat." They went and resented them. The Guo clan said: "What would you do if you were a thief?" The Xiang clan described their situation. The Guo clan said: "Alas!" The *Explanation of Text* states: "Alas" (*xi*, 嘻) is pronounced *xī* (熙), a sound of grief and pain. "Have you lost the Dao of thievery to this extent? Now I shall tell you. I have heard that Heaven has its seasons, Earth has its advantages." The annotation states: referring to spring, autumn, winter, and summer, and all that the earth produces. Below "produces" (*chu*, 出) in the annotation, all versions lack the character "that which" (*suo*, 所); this follows the *Four Explanations* edition and adds it.

"I steal Heaven and Earth’s timely advantages," the *Explanation of Text* states: the sentence ends here. "The soaking moisture of clouds and rain," the *Explanation of Text* states: "soaking" (*pang*, 滂) is pronounced *pāng* (普郎切). "The products nurtured by mountains and marshes, to grow my grain, cultivate my crops," the *Six Excerpts* (9.1) quotes it as "grow my millet, cultivate my grains." "I build my walls," the *Explanation of Text* writes "cultivate" (*zhi*, 殖) as "plant" (*zhi*, 植) and states: "build" (*zhu*, 筑) is pronounced *zhú* (竹). "Walls" (*yuan*, 垣) is pronounced *yuán* (袁). "Plant" (*zhi*, 植) is pronounced *zhí* (时职切). Yang Bojun notes: The pronunciation of "plant" in the *Explanation of Text* appears below "walls," suggesting that the version Jing Shun saw read: "I build my walls, construct my dwellings, grow my grain, plant my crops." "I construct my dwellings. On land, I steal birds and beasts; in water, I steal fish and turtles," the *Explanation of Text* states: "turtle" (*bie*, 鳖) is pronounced *biē* (并列切). "There is nothing that is not stolen. Grain, crops, earth, trees, birds, beasts, fish, and turtles—all are born of Heaven. How can they be mine?" The annotation states: Heaven cannot even produce itself, so how can it produce things? People cannot even possess themselves, so how can they possess things? This clarifies that things produce and possess themselves.

"Yet when I steal from Heaven, I incur no misfortune." The annotation states: Heaven does not impose its bestowals; I act with impartiality—where could resentment arise? The *Commentary on the Yin Fu Jing* quotes it as: "I steal from Heaven and Earth yet incur no misfortune or blame." The *Explanation of Text* states: "bestow" (*shi*, 施) is pronounced *shì* (尸智切). "As for gold, jade, precious treasures, grain, silk, wealth, and goods," the Qin engraved edition writes "gold, jade, precious treasures" as "grain, earth, crops, treasures." "These are what people accumulate—how can they be what Heaven bestows?" The annotation states: Heaven cannot even bestow, so how can people accumulate? This also clarifies that things can bestow and accumulate themselves. Yang Bojun notes: The annotation "can bestow and accumulate themselves" should read "can bestow and possess themselves." "If you steal them and incur punishment, whom should you resent?" The annotation states: People possess their wealth; I violate their private interests—this is why blame arises.

The *Explanation* states: Heaven and Earth are not benevolent; they treat the myriad things as straw dogs. Since they have no feeling for nurturing life, how could they have a mind for giving and taking? The great devour the small, the wise enslave the foolish. They seize opportunities to pursue profit and use force to serve their private ends.

"Movement and use, taking and giving—all are theft. Yet with people’s wealth, it is not so: one guards and supplies oneself, and taking it incurs punishment—whom should one resent for this? Xiang Shi was greatly perplexed, believing that Guo Shi had deceived him." Yang Bojun notes: *Wang* (罔) should be read as in the *Analects*, *Yong Ye* chapter: "one cannot *wang* (deceive) them." The *Han Shu*, *Yang Xiong Zhuan* reads: "one cannot act deviously or *wang* (deceive)"; the annotation states: *Wang* means "to falsely accuse." The *Shi Wen* notes: *Wang* is pronounced *wen liang*.

He passed by Master Dongguo and asked him. "Passed by" (*guo*): The Northern Song edition reads "encountered" (*yu*); Wang’s edition follows this, but here we follow the *Zang* edition, *Si Jie* edition, and *Shi De Tang* edition in correcting it. The *Shi Wen* notes: *Guo* is pronounced *ge*, and is also written as the character *yu*.

Master Dongguo said: "Is not your very body likewise theft? You steal the harmony of yin and yang to complete your life, to sustain your form." Yu Yue notes: *Zai* (载) also means "to complete." The *Shang Shu*, *Gao Yao Mo* chapter reads: "Then he continued the song, saying..."; Ma Rong’s commentary states: *Zai* means "to complete"—this is its meaning here. "How much more so with external things—are they not theft?" The annotation states: Is it not that you possess theft?

The body is but one thing among Heaven and Earth; it cannot be privately possessed. If it is not theft, then there is no distinction between internal and external. The *Si Jie* edition reads: "cannot but be privately possessed" for the annotation "cannot be privately possessed."

Truly, Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things do not stand apart. To claim and possess them is delusion. The annotation states: Now, Heaven and Earth are the collective designation of the myriad things; the myriad things are the distinct names of Heaven and Earth. Though each privately possesses its own body, in principle they do not stand apart. To claim and possess them is the delusion of the mind.

Thus, when Heaven and Earth entrust us with form, it is not ours to own. To adorn and cherish appearance, to boast of wisdom and ability—this is already delusion. To go further and arbitrarily claim external things as one’s own, to display one’s name and lineage to set oneself apart, to rely on kin for security, to array fine robes to dazzle others, to wield titles and rank to sway the crowd, to amass wealth and property, to cultivate factions and power—all one’s life to delight in these without ever awakening to oneself.

Thus Laozi said, "That which is my great affliction is that I have a body." Zhuangzi said, "Of the hundred limbs and six viscera, with which am I most intimate?" Grasping this principle, the heart-mind becomes as empty as the Great Void, and the bodily form exists together with the myriad things.

Lu Wenchong notes: In the *Zang* edition of the annotation, *chi* (饬) is written as *shi* (饰); after "That which is my great affliction," there is the character *zhe* (者); and "Great Void" is written as "Grand Void." Bo Jun notes: "To claim and possess them" in the *Zang* edition is written as "to recognize and possess them"; *ren* (仞) is *ren* (认). In the *Zhou Mu Wang* chapter of this text, "dreaming of recognizing a deer as a man," the *Shi Wen* notes: "One edition writes *ren* (认) for *ren* (仞)," which serves as evidence. The *Shi Wen* writes "Grand" for "Great," and notes: *ren* is pronounced *ren*; *cheng* (称) is pronounced *zheng*; *fu* (复) is pronounced *fou*; *wu zhi wei* (吾之为) is pronounced *wu zhi wei* (于伪切); *zang* (藏) is pronounced *cang*.

The theft of the Guo clan was in accord with the public Dao, thus incurring no misfortune; the theft of the Ruo clan arose from private motives, thus incurring guilt.

**[Annotation]** "Public" is the opposite of "private"; without the private, the name "public" ceases to exist. Now to regard transgressing Heaven as "public" and transgressing man as "private" does not fully accord with principle.

**[Exegesis]** Heaven and Earth are without private motives; to take from them is without opposition, thus no misfortune arises. The human heart harbors private motives; to take with such intent is theft. To take what is privately held with a private heart—private motives entail opposition—how could guilt not follow? Thus, laws exist to restrain private motives; without opposition, there would be no prohibitions.

Bo Jun notes: In the exegesis, "to take with such intent" (*qu zhi you qing*) should read "to take with opposition" (*qu zhi you dui*). *Dui* means what is now called "the opposing party."

Those who act with public or private motives are likewise thieves.

**[Annotation]** The distinction lies only in what they transgress; they are not free from theft.

Those who are without public or private motives are likewise thieves.

**[Annotation]** The self cannot but exist, and wealth cannot but accumulate; to then seek to relinquish them is not to be one who is immediately without motive.

**[Exegesis]** The sage establishes laws and teachings to prevent harm to others and encroachment upon the multitude—these are not theft. Those who do not violate the law act in accord with the public Dao; those who violate the law act in accord with the private Dao. Even if one does not violate the public but appropriates for oneself, this is likewise theft—how much more so when one violates the law to enrich oneself?

The exegesis reads, "how much more so when violating the law to enrich oneself" (*kuang wei fa feng ji*); the Qin edition has "violating the law and teachings" (*wei fa jiao hua*). Here, we follow the Four Exegeses edition for correction.

Public and private, public and private—these are the virtues of Heaven and Earth.

**[Annotation]** Life is but one principle of Heaven and Earth; the body is but one thing of Heaven and Earth. What one now cherishes and begrudges is simply to cherish and begrudge the life and body born between Heaven and Earth. In affairs, there is no public or private; in principle, there is no cherishing or begrudging.

The *Shi Wen* notes: *lin* (吝) is pronounced *liang ren*.

Those who know the virtue of Heaven and Earth—who is a thief? Who is not a thief?

**[Annotation]** What is the virtue of Heaven and Earth? It is simply spontaneity, spontaneity alone. Where is there room to impose the names of public and private? Once the names of public and private are abolished, theft and non-theft differ not in principle.

**[Exegesis]** To know the public and the private yet be without private motives, to be of the same pattern as things yet not find them strange—this is the virtue of Heaven and Earth. If one knows the virtue of Heaven and Earth and takes without private motives, this is not to deceive Heaven. To take without differing from the multitude, to obtain without private motives, is not theft. If so, who is a thief? Who is not a thief? Only those who have fully realized the spirit and awakened to the Dao know this.

The annotation "厝其公私之名" (placing the names of public and private) appears in various editions as "历" (experience), but the present text follows the *Zang* edition in correcting it. The exegesis "若知天地之德" (if one knows the virtue of Heaven and Earth) appears in the *Qin* edition as "万" (ten thousand), but the present text follows the *Sijie* edition in correcting it.

Lu Wenchong notes: In the annotation "自然而已" (simply spontaneity alone), the *Zang* edition does not repeat these four characters.
The *Shiwen* states: 厝 is pronounced *cuo*.

*Liezi Jishi*, Volume Two: "The Yellow Emperor," Second Chapter

**[Annotation]** That which is endowed at birth is called *xing* (nature); to fully realize one’s nature is called *he* (harmony). Thus, when one responds to principle and abides in accordance, whatever one encounters is always unobstructed. When one follows the emotions and turns against the Dao, one meets with things and is immediately impeded.

**[Exegesis]** This clarifies the forgetting of form to nurture the spirit, following the profound and the silent to bring forth true wisdom. At the beginning of nurturing, one abandons the myriad existences and inwardly settles the mind. When wisdom is brought forth, one transforms living beings and outwardly engages with things. Thus, in its initial stage, one purifies the mind and disciplines the body, not becoming entangled in political affairs. By the final chapter, one assists Confucius and Mozi in aiding others. This is its great purport.

In the fifteenth year of his reign, the Yellow Emperor rejoiced that all under Heaven bore him [on their shoulders].

**[Annotation]** He rejoiced in accordance with the times.

Wang Shumin states: The *Lushi Houji* (Volume Five, Annotation) includes the character "之" (him) before "戴" (bear), and it should be followed. "喜天下之戴己" (rejoiced that all under Heaven bore him) matches the syntax of the following phrase, "忧天下之不治" (worried that all under Heaven was not well-governed). The *Yiwen Leiju* (Volume Eleven) also includes the character "之" before "戴."

He nourished his *zhengming* (proper destiny).

**[Annotation]** *Zheng* (proper) should be *xing* (nature).

Yu Yue states: *Zheng* (proper) should be *sheng* (life). The ancient characters *sheng* (life) and *xing* (nature) were interchangeable. In the *Zhouli* (*Rites of Zhou*), the *Da Situ* (Grand Minister of Education) states, "Distinguishing the *wu di* (five lands) by their *wu sheng* (five products)," where Du Zichun reads *sheng* as *xing*. This is an example. The original text of the *Liezi* reads "养生命" (nourishing life and destiny), for *sheng* (life) is *xing* (nature), and thus it was mistakenly written as *zheng* (proper). Zhang’s annotation, "正当为性" (*zheng* should be *xing*), though correct in identifying the character, overlooks the ancient usage. Hu Huaichen’s view is the same.
The *Shiwen* states: *Zheng* is pronounced *xing*.

He delighted his ears and eyes, gratified his nose and mouth, and his complexion became parched and sallow.

**[Annotation]** "焦" (*jiao*, parched) appears as "燋" (*jiao*) in the *Shide Tang* edition.
The *Shiwen* states: "焦" is written as "燋," pronounced *jiao*. *Jise* (complexion) also appears as *yanse* (countenance). *Gan* is pronounced *gu han*. □ is pronounced *mei*.

No character exists in other texts for this; the *Pi Cang* writes it as □, pronounced the same as *mei*, referring to wood damaged by rain that develops black speckles. *Gan* and □ are likewise. Qin Enfu states: □ does not appear in the *Shuowen*. □ is the vulgar form of *mei* (mildew) and should be written as *mei*. In the *Chuci*’s "Yufu," Wang Yi’s annotation reads: "sallow and mildewed, blackened."

His five emotions were dulled and confused in a stupor.

**[Annotation]** Exerting the mind and intellect is insufficient to nourish one’s nature and life—it only parches the body.
