These all attest to the ancient usage of *yān nǎi* (焉乃) as a compound. Wang Chongmin argues: Wang’s interpretation is incorrect. The original text read *xī* (西), a scribal error. The character *yān* (焉) should still conclude the preceding clause. Zhang’s annotation cites the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan*: "They ascended Yan Mountain in the west." According to Guo Pu’s commentary on the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan*: "Yanzi Mountain is where the sun sets." Yan Mountain lies west of the Jasper Pool, marking the sun’s setting. Zhang’s citation clarifies the meaning of "observing the west." The *Taiping Yulan* (vol. 3) quotes it as "observed the place where the sun sets in the west," with only minor variations but retaining the character *xī* (西). The Ji edition correctly writes *xī* (西). Bo Jun notes: Wang Chongmin’s argument is sound. *Nǎi* (乃) was a graphic corruption of *xī* (西), and the text is now emended following the Ji edition. The *Shiwen* states: *yǎn* (弇) is pronounced *yǎn* (奄).

Jiang Chaobo observes: The block-printed editions of the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* are fragmentary and incomplete; only Guo Pu’s commentary on the *Shan Hai Jing* preserves a more coherent version. His citation reads: "On the auspicious day of *jiǎzǐ*, they paid homage to the Queen Mother of the West, presenting a black jade tablet and white jade disk as gifts. They offered a hundred strands of brocade and a hundred *jin* of gold and jade. The Queen Mother of the West bowed twice in acceptance. On *yǐchǒu*, the Son of Heaven feasted with the Queen Mother of the West atop the Jasper Pool. The Queen Mother of the West sang a lay for the Son of Heaven:

*White clouds drift in the sky,*
*The mountains and hills rise on their own.*
*The Way stretches far and distant,*
*Separated by rivers and mountains.*
*May you not die, my lord,*
*And come again.*

The Son of Heaven replied:

*I return to the eastern lands,*
*To harmonize and govern the Central States.*
*When the myriad people are equitable and just,*
*I shall turn to see you once more.*
*Within three years,*
*I shall return to your wilds.*

The Queen Mother of the West then chanted for the Son of Heaven:

*Departing for those western lands,*
*You dwell where you belong.*
*Tigers and leopards gather in packs,*
*Birds and magpies nest beside you.*
*Your noble mandate does not waver,*
*For I am the Emperor’s daughter.*
*What manner of mortal are you,*
*Who would now leave me?*
*Playing the reed pipes and drums,*
*My heart soars within.*
*O child of this mortal world,*
*You are Heaven’s hope.*

Thereupon, the Son of Heaven drove his chariot up Yan Mountain, where he inscribed his tracks upon its stones and planted a locust tree, naming it the Mountain of the Queen Mother of the West." They traveled ten thousand *li* in a single day. The *Shiwen* writes *wàn xíng* (万行), noting: *xíng* (行) is read as *lǐ* (里).

The king sighed and said: "Alas! I alone am deficient in virtue yet harmonious in joy. Later generations will surely recount my transgressions!" *Xié* (谐) here means "to distinguish."

From "Thereupon he commanded his eight steeds to be harnessed" up to this point, the events are recorded in the *Tale of King Mu*. The *Shiwen* notes: *shù* (数) is read as *sèjù*, meaning "to reproach."

How near to a divine being was King Mu! *Here meaning: he was not divine.*

Wu Kaisheng remarks: *jǐ* (几) should be read as *qǐ* (岂, "how could"). The following line, "How could it be empty words?" serves as evidence. The *Shiwen* notes: *jǐ* is pronounced *qǐ*.

He exhausted the joys of his own lifetime—the *Shiwen* notes: *lè* (乐) is pronounced *luò*—yet after a hundred years, he still passed away. *Knowing the impermanence of worldly affairs, he gave free rein to his heart.* Bo Jun observes: The *Book of Jin*’s biography of Shu Xi cites the *Bamboo Annals*, stating, "From the Zhou’s receipt of the Mandate to King Mu’s reign, a hundred years had passed," leading later generations to mistakenly believe King Mu lived a hundred years. The world deemed him to have ascended.

*The character 假 here should be written as 遐, meaning the world believed he had "ascended afar," clarifying that he had in fact died.*

*[Exegesis]*
Selecting swift steeds and discerning worthy talents, he applied them as circumstances demanded. Unbound by the distinction between Chinese and foreign lands, he followed only where the Dao led. Without venturing far from the Palace of the Yellow Emperor, he exhausted all that heaven and earth possess, reaching the utmost of what divine knowledge can convey. He did not exalt virtue to flaunt his power but delighted in the Dao to commune with the divine. After a thousand years, he *transfigured* and ascended—yet the common folk believed he had merely "ascended afar."

Qin Enfu remarks: The character *□* in the exegesis does not appear in dictionaries. The *Jiyun* includes the character *□*, pronounced *qí*, an ancient form of *qì* (跂), though its meaning here is unclear. Sun Yirang notes: The exegesis’s *□化* should read *肢化* (*zhīhuà*), meaning "corpse-transformation" (a form of Daoist liberation). Qin’s citation of *□* as an ancient form of *qì* does not suit this context. The *Shiwen* notes: *jiǎ* (假) is pronounced *xiá*.

Lao Chengzi studied illusion under Master Yin Wen. Wang Chongmin observes: The *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (752) cites this as "Kao Chengzi," matching the *Shiwen* version. The *Shiwen* reads *lǎo* (老) as *kǎo* (考), noting: "Kao Chengzi" appears in one version, while another gives "Lao Chengzi," author of eighteen chapters. Ren Dachun adds: The *Xingshi Jijiu Pian* ("Quick Access to Surnames") records, "The Lao Cheng clan: the *Shi Ben* mentions Song minister Lao Cheng Fang. The *Liezi* states Lao Cheng studied illusion under Yin Wen. The *Treatise on Arts and Letters* lists *Lao Chengzi*." Thus, the version Hong Mai saw in the *Liezi* read "Lao Chengzi," matching the current text. After three years, he did not report his progress. Lao Chengzi requested to be corrected and sought leave to depart.

Yin Wen bowed and led him into the chamber. Dismissing his attendants, he spoke to him, saying:

"When the Old Master Lao Dan departed for the West, he turned to me and said: 'The qi of living beings and the forms of corporeal things are all illusion. What the Creator begins and what yin and yang transform are called life and death. Those who exhaust the numbers and comprehend the changes, following form to shift and alter, are called transformation and illusion.'

[Commentary] Those who master the numbers of the Two Modes and grasp the principles of yin and yang shape and move the myriad forms without perceiving the difficulty. The Creator’s craft is subtle, its work profound—inherently difficult to exhaust or bring to an end.

[Commentary] Does the Creator have intent? It is naturally and seemingly subtle.

When qi and substance press and thin, congealing into form, they follow transformation and depart, thus not immediately dissipating.

Tao Hongqing observes: Zhang’s commentary fails to grasp the meaning of *miao* (妙). The original character for *miao* should be *miao* (秒), also written as *miao* (妙). In the first chapter of the *Dao De Jing*, 'Constantly desireless, one observes its subtlety,' Wang Bi’s commentary states: '*Miao* is the utmost of the minute.' Its subtlety refers to its craft being so minute and wondrous as to be unknowable. This contrasts with the following phrase, 'Those who rely on form have craft that is manifest and work that is shallow.'

Bo Jun notes: The *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (725) cites this as 'thus difficult to exhaust or bring to an end,' with *gu* (固) as *gu* (故), which better suits the meaning.

[Commentary] *Fen* is pronounced *fèn* (房吻切).

Those who rely on form have craft that is manifest and work that is shallow, thus arising and vanishing in an instant.

[Commentary] Those who borrow things to enact change, or who follow form in its shifts, are but briefly born and briefly extinguished. Their work is evident, their deeds conspicuous, so all things are startled.

Only when one knows that illusion and transformation do not differ from life and death can one begin to study illusion.

[Commentary] The meaning of this has already been detailed in the commentary on the chapter title.

Lu Wenchang notes: In the Zang edition, the commentary includes the character *jian* (见) after *zhu* (注).

Wang Chongmin states: *Yu* (与) here means *yi* (以), as explained in *Shi Ci*.

This means one may then begin to study illusion. The *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (752) cites this as 'one may then begin to study illusion,' with different wording but the same meaning.

You and I are also illusion—why must you study?"

[Commentary] The body itself is illusion; to study illusion further is to have illusion study illusion.

[Exegesis] The transformations of form and qi are ever-renewing and unceasing—how do they differ from illusion? Thus, what the spirit and qi transform endures long and is difficult to know, while what techniques and arts produce is near and easily seen. Yet one does not realize that what is difficult to know is the greater illusion, and what is easily seen is the lesser illusion. If one knows that illusion and transformation do not differ from life and death, why study further?

[Commentary] *Fu* is pronounced *fù* (扶又切).

Lao Chengzi returned home and, applying Yin Wen’s words, meditated deeply for three months.

[Commentary] *Shen* (深) is written as *yin* (淫), pronounced *shēn* (深).

Ren Dachun states: In the *Nine Hymns* of the *Chu Ci*, 'floating without root' is glossed as 'one version reads *chen* (沉), meaning deep and profound.' In the *Stratagems of Yan* from the *Warring States*, 'his wisdom is deep and his plans profound,' the commentary states: '*Chen* means deep.' In the *Records of the Grand Historian*, *Treatise on Music*: 'The sound is excessive and reaches the Shang.' Wang Su comments: 'The sound is deeply excessive and avaricious for Shang.' This confirms that *yin* (淫) is glossed as *shen* (深). Moreover, in this text, *yin* (淫) and *shen* (深) are often interchangeable. In the *Yellow Emperor* chapter, 'He will dwell in a measure that is not *shen* (深),' the commentary states: '*Shen* should be *yin* (淫).' *Yin* is read as *shen*, and *shen* is also read as *yin*—their meanings are interchangeable.

Thereafter, he could freely control life and death, manipulating the four seasons.

Wu Kaisheng notes: *Fan jiao* (□校) means to manipulate or play with.

[Commentary] *Fan* is pronounced *fān* (翻). *Jiao* is pronounced *jiǎo* (绞). Gu Yewang reads it as *fan jiao* (翻交) of the four seasons.

In winter, he summoned thunder; in summer, he created ice. What flew ran, and what ran flew.

[Commentary] If deep contemplation for a time can yield such mastery, how much more so for one who attains it without effort? Life must follow principle, and form must follow life. There has never been life without principle, nor form without life. Life and form, form and principle—though differing in refinement and coarseness—alternate as guest and host. They flow and shift in ceaseless succession, never pausing even briefly. Thus, they are ever-changing and never fixed, now gathering, now dispersing. When governed with order, their work is subtle and their deeds concealed; when cultivation loses measure, their traces become manifest and their transformations evident. Now, if the commands of the four seasons are disrupted, the three luminaries fall into disorder. Thunder and ice reverse their seasons, vessels and objects melt and scorch, so that flying things smelt clouds and sand to form billowing ice. When this occurs as usual, none doubt it. Extending this principle, if one exhausts the subtle numbers of yin and yang and fathoms the nature of the myriad things, one can shape and mold all beings, equaling the work of Creation. As for those who partially grasp techniques and draw upon qi and substance, bending and rising to emerge and submerge, glancing to exchange flight and running for altered forms—these are but the lesser arts.

[Commentary] The phrase *bing hong* (冰澒) in all editions is mistakenly written as *shui qing* (水顷).

[Commentary] *Shuo* is pronounced *shuò* (铄). *Hong* is pronounced *hóng* (洪).

For the rest of his life, he never revealed his arts.

[Commentary] *Zhuo* (箸) is written as *zhuó* (着), pronounced *zhù* (陟虑切).

Thus, the world never transmitted them.

[Commentary] That the Hundred Clans use it without knowing—this is the Way of the Sage."

Revealing marvels to astonish an age—this is the affair of common men.

[Exegesis] One who fathoms the root of spirit and qi and discerns the source of life and death can then transform without limit; this is the necessary principle. It must be realized through personal awakening and embodied verification, and thus cannot be transmitted through words or texts.

Yu Yue notes: "Thus" in Lu Chongxuan’s edition reads "indeed." *Indeed* and *thus* are interchangeable—this is the ancient version. Zhang Zhan’s edition arbitrarily alters it to *thus*, which no longer preserves the antiquity of the original text.

Master Liezi said: "One skilled in transformation follows a Way that is subtle and ordinary, and their achievement is the same as others’.

[Commentary] They merely seek to benefit the world and pacify things, and so their achievement works in hiddenness, unknown to others.

[Phonetic Gloss] *Yǐ* is pronounced *yǐ*.

The virtue of the Five Emperors and the achievements of the Three Kings were not necessarily all due to the strength of wisdom or courage; some were accomplished through transformation. Who could fathom it?

[Commentary] The merit and virtue of emperors and kings are named by the world, not what makes them emperors and kings. Whether yielding the throne or wielding weapons, these are but borrowed paths—why should they not also borrow illusory transformation? Yet the traces that astonish the world are what the Sage employs in secrecy, never revealing them.

[Phonetic Gloss] *Wéi zhī wéi* is pronounced *wéi zhī wěi* (于伪切).

The manifestations of waking perception number eight—*Phonetic Gloss*: *jué* is pronounced *jiào*—while the signs of dreaming number six. *[Commentary]* *Zhēng* means verification; *hòu* means divination. The divination of the six dreams is explained in the *Rites of Zhou*. *Phonetic Gloss*: *xiàn* is pronounced *xián* (贤遍切).

What are the eight manifestations? The first is *gù* *[Commentary]* *Gù* means affairs. The second is *wéi* *[Commentary]* *Wéi* means action. *Táo Hóngqìng notes*: *Gù* refers to abandoning the old, while *wéi* refers to pursuing the new, forming pairs with the following *dé* and *sàng*, *āi* and *lè*, *shēng* and *sǐ*. *Zhang’s commentary* is unclear. The third is *dé* (gain), the fourth is *sàng* (loss) *[Phonetic Gloss]* *sàng* is pronounced *sàng* (息浪切). The fifth is *āi* (sorrow), the sixth is *lè* (joy) *[Phonetic Gloss]* *lè* is pronounced *luò*. The seventh is *shēng* (life), the eighth is *sǐ* (death). These eight manifestations are what form engages. *Yú Yuè notes*: It should read, "These eight are what form engages," to parallel the following "These six are what spirit intersects." *Wáng Chóngmín states*: Yu’s suggestion is correct. The *Jífǔ* edition reads, "These eight manifestations are what form engages." It appears an extra *zhēng* was mistakenly inserted, later moved beneath *zhě*, though the *Jífǔ* edition still preserves traces of this. *Wáng Shūmín notes*: The *Dàozàng* edition, citing *Fàn Zhìxū’s* commentary, reads, "These eight are what form engages," matching Yu’s suggestion. The *Bàibiān* (65) cites it as "These eight manifestations are what form engages," aligning with the *Jífǔ* edition. The *zhēng* is not a superfluous character; it likely originally read, "These eight manifestations are what form engages," to parallel the following "These six signs are what spirit intersects." In the current text, the *hòu* beneath *liù* has been omitted (as discussed later), rendering this passage garbled and unreadable. The *Emperor Huīzōng’s* commentary reads, "Thus it is said, 'These eight verifications are what form engages'" (using *zhèng* to gloss *zhēng*), indicating his edition was correct.

What are the six signs? The first is *zhèngmèng* (ordinary dreams) *[Commentary]* Dreaming in ordinary circumstances. The second is *èmèng* (startling dreams) *[Commentary]* The *Rites of Zhou* commentary states: *È* should be *è* (startling), meaning dreams arising from fright. *[Phonetic Gloss]* *È* is pronounced *è*. The third is *sīmèng* (thought dreams) *[Commentary]* Dreams arising from contemplation. The fourth is *wùmèng* (waking dreams) *[Commentary]* Dreams occurring while awake and recounting them. *[Phonetic Gloss]* *Wù* is pronounced *wù*. The fifth is *xǐmèng* (joyful dreams) *[Commentary]* Dreams arising from happiness. The sixth is *jùmèng* (fearful dreams) *[Commentary]* Dreams arising from terror. These six are what spirit intersects. *[Commentary]* The main point of this chapter is to clarify that waking and dreaming are not distinct. *Wáng Shūmín notes*: The *Emperor Huīzōng’s* commentary reads, "Thus it is said, 'These six signs are what spirit intersects.'" His edition includes *hòu* beneath *liù*, paralleling the earlier "These eight manifestations are what form engages." This should be restored. The *Cǎotáng Shījiān Bǔyí* (4) cites the text with *mèng* beneath *liù*, further proving the current edition omits characters. *Bó Jùn observes*: According to *Lú’s* commentary below—"Yet waking has eight manifestations, dreaming six signs"—and "knowing the constant transformations of the eight manifestations and six signs," this supports *Wáng Shūmín’s* argument.

Those who do not recognize the origins of sensory changes are perplexed by events when they arise, while those who recognize their origins understand them as they occur. Understanding their origins, one remains unalarmed. *[Commentary]* All transformations and actions arise from causes. Those who do not investigate their roots when events have yet to occur are inevitably confused. Truly recognizing their origins, even amid myriad strange occurrences, the mind remains unshaken. *[Exegesis]* By emptying the mind, quieting thoughts, reflecting inward, and preserving spirit, one can penetrate all sensory barriers and transform all living beings. Yet people only see the traces of such transformations, not the root of their efficacy. Why? Because the Dao operates in secrecy and is difficult to perceive, its achievements indistinguishable from human affairs. Thus, the Five Emperors and Three Kings are known only for their strength and wisdom, not for their accomplishments through transformation. Yet the eight manifestations of waking and six signs of dreaming encompass all human experiences. *Gù*, *wéi*, *dé*, *sàng*, *āi*, *lè*, *shēng*, and *sǐ* are what form engages; *zhèng*, *è*, *sī*, *wù*, *xǐ*, and *jù* are what spirit intersects. What form engages is deemed waking; what spirit intersects is deemed dreaming. Though waking and dreaming differ in expression, in transformation they are never distinct. Knowing the constant transformations of the eight manifestations and six signs is to recognize their origins. Understanding that preserving spirit without disturbance gives rise to transformation, what manifestations or signs could ever cause alarm? *[Phonetic Gloss]* *Dá* is pronounced *dá* (丁达切). *Jué* is pronounced *jué*.

The waxing and waning, ebb and flow of a single being all resonate with Heaven and Earth and respond to all things. *[Commentary]* Humans share qi with yin and yang and parallel Heaven and Earth in form; fortune and misfortune alternate, inevitably interconnected. Thus, when yin qi is strong, one dreams of wading through great waters in terror *[Commentary]* Losing harmony, one is overwhelmed and fearful. *[Phonetic Gloss]* *Rú* is pronounced *rú*. When yang qi is strong, one dreams of traversing great fires and being scorched—*the character is erroneous*. The *Lǐjì: Jiāotèshēng* *[Commentary]* Fire’s nature is fierce and violent; encountering it leads to scorching. *[Phonetic Gloss]* *Gài* is pronounced *yuè* (如悦切). *Jìngshùn’s* commentary in the *Phonetic Gloss* correctly uses *gài*, also pronounced *yuè*. This is not *Gù’s* original text but a later interpolation, which should be corrected accordingly—it is evident the error had not yet occurred in the Tang dynasty.

The *Yùpiān* includes this character. However, the *Xīgǔ Yì Cóngshū* fragment of the *Yùpiān* lacks the "fire" section, leaving no means to verify it. The *Phonetic Gloss* states: *fán* is pronounced *fán*. *Gài* is pronounced *yuè* (如悦切).

When both yin and yang qi are strong, one dreams of life and death.
*[Commentary]* Yin and yang function through harmony. When they contend, they harm one another, hence dreams of life or death.
*[Phonetic Gloss]* *Kàng* may also be written as *kàng* (亢).

When overly sated, one dreams of giving; when ravenous, one dreams of taking.
*[Commentary]* Surfeit leads to the desire to bestow; want leads to the desire to seize. This, too, mirrors waking reality.
*[Note]* The phrase "desire to seize" appears as "wading to seize" (*shè qǔ*) in the Northern Song edition and Wang’s edition; the present text follows the *Daozang* edition’s emendation.

Thus, those afflicted by floating emptiness dream of soaring; those burdened by sinking solidity dream of drowning.
When sleeping atop one’s sash, one dreams of serpents.
*[Phonetic Gloss]* *Jiè* is pronounced *jì* (慈夜切).
When a bird grasps one’s hair in flight, one dreams of flying.
*[Commentary]* This arises from resonance with external things.
*[Note]* The *Zàng* edition includes an "而" after "类" and a "也" at the end of the commentary.

Approaching yin, one dreams of fire; nearing illness, one dreams of food.
Those who drink wine grieve; those who sing and dance weep.
*[Commentary]* These illustrate the nature of dreams: some arise from resonance with events, others from extremes inverting into their opposites—aligning with the *Zhōulǐ*’s six dreams and six principles, for such patterns are never groundless.
*[Exegesis]* When spirit and qi cling to phenomena, transformations follow; when yin and yang interact, dreams shift. Some responses arise from past extremes, some traces appear through resemblance, some manifest causes as realities, while others invert logic yet fail to express true feeling. For those who concentrate their minds to grasp the real and darkly align with the Dao, clarity transcends change—neither sorrow nor joy can enter.
Táo Hóngqìng observes: Both "those who drink wine grieve" and "those who sing and dance weep" should begin with the word "dream."
Bó Jùn notes: Táo is correct. The *Zhuāngzǐ: Qíwù Lùn* states, "One who dreams of drinking wine wakes to weep; one who dreams of weeping wakes to hunt," differing slightly in phrasing but sharing the inclusion of "dream."
*[Further Note]* In the exegesis, the character "未" in "or invert logic yet fail to express true feeling" is superfluous.
*[Phonetic Gloss]* *Zào* is pronounced *qī* (七到切).

Master Lièzǐ said: "Spiritual encounter gives rise to dreams; physical contact gives rise to events."
*[Commentary]* As *Zhuāngzǐ* states: "In sleep, spirits commune; in waking, forms unfold."
Bó Jùn notes: The *Tàipíng Yùlǎn* (397) quotes this as "Thus, spiritual encounter gives rise to dreams," omitting "Master Lièzǐ said" and replacing it with "Thus." The commentary’s citation of *Zhuāngzǐ* appears in the *Qíwù Lùn*; the present text reads "魂交" instead of "神交."

Thus, daytime thoughts yield nighttime dreams—encounters of spirit and form.
*[Commentary]* "Thoughts" here refer to waking concerns, not the common notion of daydreaming leading to subsequent dreams.
Therefore, those whose spirits are concentrated find thoughts and dreams dissolve.
*[Commentary]* Without waking cares, there are no dreams at night.

In truth, waking does not speak; in truth, dreams do not convey—these are the comings and goings of transformed things.
*[Commentary]* Dreaming of being a bird and soaring to the heavens, dreaming of being a fish and diving into the depths—these are the transformations of feeling.
*[Note]* The character "戾" originally appeared as "厉," which also conveys meaning. However, the *Shījīng* (*Xiǎoyǎ: Sìyuè*) reads: "Neither quail nor kite, soaring to the heavens; neither sturgeon nor salmon, diving into the depths"—here, the text uses "戾," which should be considered correct. The present text follows the *Zàng* edition’s emendation.

The true persons of antiquity forgot themselves in waking and slept without dreams.

"How could this be empty words?"

*[Commentary]* The true person forgets in all actions, even to the point of sleeplessness—how could there be dreams? This is also a parable to clarify the principle.

*[Exegesis]* When the six senses are all engaged, people regard it as real; when consciousness acts alone, people regard it as illusory—both are called illusion. When one dreams and takes the dream as real, both are called truth. Yet they do not realize that waking is the movement of spirit, and dreaming is the activity of spirit. To believe one and not the other is to fail to comprehend. If one forgets the self, there are no dreams—how could there be another principle?

Qin Enfu remarked: The exegesis appears to have omissions and errors.
Wang Lai said: Above "people regard it as illusory," four characters—"people regard it as illusory"—should be added. The four characters "梦行" and "为梦" are superfluous.
Bo Jun noted: The *Zhuangzi* ("Ke Yi" chapter) states: "The sage’s life is the movement of Heaven; their death is the transformation of things. [...] Their sleep is dreamless; their waking is carefree." (Text omitted.) The "Da Zong Shi" chapter is largely the same. The *Huainanzi* ("Chu Zhen Xun") says: "The sage relies on the mind, leans on nature, and depends on spirit to complete the cycle—thus their sleep is dreamless, and their waking is carefree." All express this idea.
*[Pronunciation Note]* 几 is pronounced *qǐ*.

In the southwestern corner of the farthest west lies a state. *[Pronunciation Note]* 隅 is written as 嵎 in the *Exegesis*. It notes: 嵎 and 隅 are interchangeable. Ren Dachun observes: The *Exegesis* of the *Erya*’s "Shui" chapter states: "隅 is also written as 嵎隅, both pronounced *yúxū*." The *Shuowen* says: "嵎 is the Fengyu Mountain, located in the state of Wangmang between Wu and Chu. It is composed of 山 and 禺 phonetic." Xu Kai notes: The *Guoyu* reads: "The Lord of Fangfeng guarded the Fengyu Mountain." The present *Luyu* states: "The lord of the Wangmang clan guarded the Fengyu Mountain." Wei Zhao comments: "Feng is Mount Feng; Yu is Mount Yu." Thus, 嵎 and 隅 are interchangeable. Furthermore, the *Suoyin* to the *Records of the Grand Historian*’s "Xia Benji" states: "The modern *Shangshu* and *Di Ming Yan* both write 禺铁." 禺 is the same as 嵎, so 嵎, 隅, and 禺 are all interchangeable.

Its borders are unknown, and it is called the State of Ancient Wilderness. *[Pronunciation Note]* 莽 is pronounced *mǎng*. The qi of yin and yang do not intermingle, so cold and heat are indistinguishable. *[Variant]* 辨 is written as 辩 below. *[Pronunciation Note]* 亡 is pronounced *wú* below. The light of the sun and moon does not reach it, so day and night are indistinguishable. Its people neither eat nor wear clothing but sleep excessively. They awaken once every fifty days, believing what they do in dreams to be real and what they perceive while awake to be illusory.

The Central State, as the four seas call it—*[Annotation]* that is, the lands within the four seas. Tao Hongqing says: 齐 means "central." 谓 is used interchangeably with 为. Bo Jun notes: The preceding text reads "called the State of Ancient Wilderness," and the following text reads "a state called the State of Flourishing Settlements," so 谓 here should share the same meaning as 名 and 曰 and should not be read as 为. Tao’s interpretation may be imprecise.

It spans north and south of the Yellow River—*[Pronunciation Note]* 跨 is pronounced *kuà*—and east and west of Mount Tai, extending over ten thousand *li*. Its yin and yang are measured precisely, so one cold and one heat alternate. Yu Yue says: The characters 审度 are transposed in transmission; the original reads "阴阳之度审." The following sentence reads: "其昏明之分察, 故一昼一夜." 度 pairs with 分, and 审 pairs with 察, making this clear. The division of darkness and light is distinct, so one day and one night alternate. *[Pronunciation Note]* 分 is pronounced *fèn*. Its people possess both wisdom and folly. The myriad things flourish, and skills and arts abound. There are rulers and subjects in hierarchy, and rituals and laws in mutual restraint. Their undertakings are beyond reckoning. They alternate between waking and sleeping, believing what they do while awake to be real and what they see in dreams to be illusory.

In the northeastern corner of the farthest east lies a state called the State of Flourishing Settlements. *[Pronunciation Note]* 阜 is pronounced *fù*. Its land is perpetually warm—*[Pronunciation Note]* 燠 is pronounced *yù*—and bathed in the lingering light of the sun and moon. Its soil does not yield fine crops. Its people eat grass roots and tree fruits, ignorant of cooked food. Their nature is fierce and violent, with the strong oppressing the weak—*[Pronunciation Note]* 藉 is pronounced *líng*. Bo Jun notes: 藉 should not be given the pronunciation *líng*. The *Exegesis* likely assumes 藉 corresponds to the 陵 in 陵轹 (as in the *Book of Later Han*’s *Zhu Fu Zhuan* commentary: "陵轹 means to bully or despise"), hence the *líng* pronunciation. Yet 藉 itself carries the meaning of oppression (as in the *Records of the Grand Historian*’s *Tian Ji Zhuan*: "Now that I am alive, people all 藉 my brother," where the commentary glosses 藉 as "to tread upon, to trample"). There is no need to alter its reading. This passage may have been supplemented by Xiang Xuan. They value dominance and do not esteem righteousness.

The people there run swiftly and seldom rest, ever wakeful and never sleeping.

*[Annotation]* Such differences in local customs—like the inversion of waking and dreaming, the divergence of activity and rest—are but adaptations to their respective regions, not grounds for mutual reproach.

*[Exegesis]* Thus, though these two lands differ, the convergence of their spirits remains unchanged. Hence we know that the harmony of spiritual principle transcends distinctions of dreaming and waking, clothing and food. If one cannot forget desires, the emotions become bound to custom.

Tao Hongqing notes: "In the southwest lies a land called the Ancient Wilderness," and so forth; "in the northeast lies a land called the Land of Mound-Dwellers," and so forth. By modern geography, the characters for "south" and "north" should be transposed.

During the Zhou dynasty, the House of Yin amassed vast wealth. *[Pronunciation Note]* 治 is pronounced *chí*.

Their subordinates, driven to labor, toiled from dawn till dusk without respite. The Qin edition reads 趣 as 趋. *[Pronunciation Note]* 趣 is pronounced *qū*, and so below. Ren Dachun observes: The *Records of the Grand Historian*’s *Zhang Yi Zhuan* states, "He was about to harness his carriage and *qū* on his way," with the *Justice* glossing *qū* as *qù*. The *Sima Qian Zhuan* reads, "*Qū*-shě take different paths," where *qū-shě* means *qū-shě*. The *Book of Han*’s *Jia Yi Zhuan* states, "*Qū* into the hall to perform *Xià*." Here, *qū* is *qū*. Thus, Jing Shun’s *Pronunciation Note* reads *qū* as *qū*. Bo Jun notes: The character 趨 (qū) in common usage (see *Guangyun* under 十虞, and *Longkan Shoujian*) shares the same form as the 趨 (chí) in *Shuowen*’s "趨趙" but differs in sound and meaning.

An elderly laborer’s strength was utterly spent, *[Bo Jun’s Note]* The *Guanzi*’s *Qingzhong Ji* states: "Those dwelling in villages are called *xiàchén*; those in towns, *xiàtōng*—these are *yìfū*." *Yìfū* is a term for the lowly, hence its use as an insult. The *Zuo Zhuan* of Duke Wen’s first year records: "Jiang Qian grew angry and said, 'Bah! *Yìfū*! It is fitting that the king wished to kill you and install Zhi!'" Yet he was made to toil even harder. By day, he groaned and moaned as he worked. *[Pronunciation Note]* 呻呼 is pronounced *shēn yín*, and so below. *[Bo Jun’s Note]* 呼 should not be given the pronunciation *yín*; the text may be corrupt or missing characters. Otherwise, it is likely that Jing Shun glossed 呼 as 吟, hence the annotation, unaware of its phonetic inaccuracy. By night, he sank into exhausted slumber. His spirit scattered and waned, and night after night, he dreamed he was a ruler. *[Qin Enfu’s Note]* 昔 and 夕 are phonetically close. *[Bo Jun’s Note]* The *Book of Songs* states, "Enjoying wine *jīn-xī*," where *jīn-xī* means *jīn-xī* (this evening). The *Guliang Zhuan* reads, "From sunset to starlight is called *xī*," where *xī* is 夕. The *Guanzi* states, "*Dàn-xī* at work," where *dàn-xī* is *dàn-xī* (day and night). These all attest to the interchangeability of 昔 and 夕. *[Pronunciation Note]* 昔昔 means nightly. Enthroned above his people, he governed the affairs of the state. He roamed and feasted in palaces, indulging every desire, his joy unmatched. *[Pronunciation Note]* 燕 is pronounced *yàn*; 觀 is read *guàn*. *[Pronunciation Note]* 樂 is pronounced *lè*. Upon waking, he returned to servitude. *[Pronunciation Note]* 覺 is pronounced *jiào*, and so below. When others consoled and urged him to rest, the laborer said: "A human life spans a hundred years, with day and night each taking half. *[Annotation]* 分 means half. By day, I am a slave, suffering greatly; by night, I am a lord, my joy unmatched. What cause have I for resentment?"

The House of Yin, consumed by worldly affairs and fixated on family wealth, exhausted both mind and body. By night, he too sank into exhausted sleep, and night after night, dreamed he was a servant—running errands, performing every labor, enduring every task. He suffered countless scoldings and beatings, every torment. In his sleep, he muttered, groaned, and moaned. *[Annotation]* 啽 is pronounced *wú nán*; 呓 is pronounced *yì*. *[Pronunciation Note]* 啽 is pronounced *wú nán*; 呓 is pronounced *yì*. 啽呓 and 呻吟 both refer to sleep-talk. He did not wake until dawn. The House of Yin, afflicted by this, sought counsel from his friend.

His friend replied, "Your rank suffices to bring you honor, and your wealth exceeds what you need—you surpass most men by far. To dream at night of being a servant is but the natural alternation of hardship and ease, a common occurrence. *[Annotation]* For prosperity and decline follow one another in turn, and when joy reaches its peak, sorrow arises. Thus, what one finds beautiful in waking life may turn foul in dreams. *[Pronunciation Note]* 恶 is pronounced *wū lù*. If you seek to enjoy both waking and dreaming states alike, how could that be possible?"

Upon hearing his friend’s words, the House of Yin eased the laborer’s tasks and reduced his own burdensome thoughts. *[Pronunciation Note]* 思 is pronounced *sì*. His illness gradually improved. *[Annotation]* This passage also illustrates that waking and dreaming are not distinct—pleasure and suffering each find their place. Thus, the laborer toils by day and finds rest by night, while the House of Yin enjoys honor by day and humiliation by night. If the principle does not encompass both, it is not sufficient to bridge the divide. *[Exegesis]* He who wearies the body but rests the spirit will feel fatigue in waking life yet peace in dreams; he who wearies the spirit but labors the body will find joy in waking life yet suffering in dreams. The spirit is the master of life, yet men do not know to nurture the spirit to calm the body. The body is the vessel of the spirit, yet men do not know to sustain the body to ease the spirit. Thus, when both body and spirit are exhausted, they exceed their proper measure. If labor and rest are balanced, illness will gradually improve.

*[Textual Note]* In the annotation, "则役夫" originally appeared as "明役夫" in Wang’s edition; the present version follows other editions. "适一方" is also found as "通一切". *[Pronunciation Note]* 少间 means "illness improves" and is pronounced *shǎo jiàn*. The character 跨 is written as "" in the *Shiwen*, pronounced *kuā*.

There was a man from Zheng who gathered firewood in the wild. He chanced upon a startled deer and pursued it, striking it down. *[Annotation]* 御 means "to meet" or "to intercept." *[Pronunciation Note]* 御 is pronounced *yà*, meaning "to intercept." He killed it. *[Pronunciation Note]* 毙 is pronounced *bì*. Fearing others would see, he hastily concealed it in a dry moat. *[Pronunciation Note]* 隍 is pronounced *huáng*, referring to a moat without water. He covered it with firewood. *[Annotation]* Huang Sheng said: *Jiao* (蕉) and *qiao* (樵) were interchangeable in ancient script. *Qiao* means "firewood," so the phrase means "covered it with firewood." In the *Zhuangzi*’s "Ren Jian Shi," it says, "The dead are measured by the state as if they were firewood in the marsh," where the character is the same as here, referring to piled bones like firewood. Nowadays, *jiao* is used for the banana plant, while Sima Xiangru’s *Zi Xu Fu* writes it as *ba qie* (巴且). *[Pronunciation Note]* 蕉 is interchangeable with 樵. Overcome with joy... *[Pronunciation Note]* 胜 is pronounced *shēng*.

Shortly after, he forgot where he had concealed it and thus took it for a dream. As he traveled along the road, he recounted the tale in song. A passerby overheard him, followed his words, and retrieved the deer. Upon returning home, he told his wife, “A woodcutter once dreamed of obtaining a deer but forgot where it was—now that I have it, his was truly a dream!”

*[Textual Note]* The character *zhe* (者) originally appeared after *meng* (梦). Yu Yue said: The original text read *bi zhi zhen meng yi* (彼直真梦矣), and *zhe* (者) was a superfluous addition. The Lu Chongxuan edition omits it. *[Editor’s Note]* Yu Yue’s observation is correct. Following the Qin engraving of the Lu Chongxuan edition and the *Sijie* edition, the character *zhe* (者) is deleted.

His wife replied, “Are you the one who dreamed of the woodcutter obtaining the deer? How could there be a woodcutter? Now that the deer is truly in your possession, is your dream the real one?”

The man said, “I have the deer—why trouble myself over whether his was a dream or mine?”

The woodcutter returned home, unwilling to accept the loss of the deer. *[Editor’s Note]* *Yan* (厌) is interchangeable with *qie* (愜). The *Shuowen* defines it as “contentment.” The *Book of Songs*’ “Xiao Rong” reads: *Yan yan liang ren* (厌厌良人), with the *Commentary* explaining *yan yan* as “tranquil.” Thus, *bu yan shi lu* (不厌失鹿) means “unwilling to resign himself to losing the deer.” *[Pronunciation Note]* *Yan* is pronounced *qiè*, or alternatively *yàn*.

That night, he truly dreamed of where he had hidden it and of the one who had taken it. At dawn, he followed his dream’s guidance and found the place. He then brought the matter to court to dispute ownership, and the case was referred to the *shishi*. *[Pronunciation Note]* *Shishi* refers to the official in charge of the five prohibitions.

The *shishi* said, “At first, you truly obtained the deer but falsely called it a dream; now, you truly dreamed of obtaining it but falsely call it real. He truly took your deer, and you dispute it with him.” Tao Hongqing said: The phrase *er yu ruo zheng lu* (而与若争鹿) should read *er ruo yu zheng lu* (而若与争鹿). Here, *zheng lu* (争鹿) refers to the one who lost the deer; below, *ju you ci lu* (据有此鹿) refers to the one who took it. Thus, I propose dividing it in two.

The wife also claimed that the deer belonged to the one who dreamed of it. *[Textual Note]* The *Jifu* and *Shidetang* editions write *ren* (认) instead of *ren* (仞). *[Pronunciation Note]* *Ren* is also written as *ren*.

“No one truly obtained the deer. Now that one party possesses it, I propose dividing it in two.” The matter was reported to Lord Zheng, who exclaimed, “Hmph!”

The *Shiwen* notes: *Xi* (嘻) is pronounced *xi*. The judicial officer asked, “Will you once more divide a man’s deer based on a dream?” The *Shiwen* notes: *Fu* (复) is pronounced *fuyou*.

He consulted the state minister. The *Shiwen* notes: *Xiang* (相) is pronounced *xiliang*. The minister replied, “Whether one dreamed or not, your servant cannot discern. To distinguish waking from dreaming, only the Yellow Emperor and Confucius could do so.”

[Annotation] How do sages discern waking from dreaming? Simply by knowing they are not different.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Xie* (邪) is pronounced *sizhe*. *Zhi* (直) may also be written as *zhen* (真).

“Now that the Yellow Emperor and Confucius are gone,”—the *Shiwen* notes: *Wang* (亡) is pronounced *wu*—“who can discern it? Yu Zhengxie said: The *Shiji Zhengyi* quotes the *Diwang Shiji*, which states: ‘The Yellow Emperor dreamed of a great wind that blew away all the dust and grime of the world. He also dreamed of a man wielding a thousand-jun crossbow herding ten thousand sheep. Upon waking, the Emperor sighed and said: The wind is the herald of commands, the one who governs; the dust is removed, and earth remains—would there not be one surnamed Feng and named Hou? The thousand-jun crossbow is the instrument of extraordinary strength; herding ten thousand sheep is the work of one who can guide the people toward goodness—would there not be one surnamed Li and named Mu? Thereupon, he sought them according to these omens: he found Feng Hou at the edge of the sea and appointed him minister; he found Li Mu in the great marsh and made him general. The Yellow Emperor then compiled the *Omen Dream Classic* in eleven scrolls.’ His method of interpreting dreams followed the natural course of events and achieved success—truly, it was like *Xiangwang* obtaining the pearl. The *Lingshu* contains the *Yin Xie Fa Meng* chapter. The *Omen Dream Classic* is listed in the *Yiwen Zhi*. It is said: *The Yellow Emperor’s Long Willow Dream Interpretation*. Confucius’s dream between the pillars is recorded in the *Tan Gong*. To speak of discerning dreams by invoking the Yellow Emperor and Confucius—this is the meaning. Moreover, the judicial officer’s words may be trusted.”

[Annotation] *Xun* (恂) means “trust,” pronounced *xun*. If one is deluded by joy and anger, one still cannot distinguish the reality of waking and dreaming—how much less when there is no waking or dreaming at all?

[Exegesis] As for those who take it as a dream, it is merely deluded perception. When the spirit’s perception is unclear, it becomes a false dream. The one who overheard and took the deer was also unclear—this, too, was a dream. The one who obtained the deer then dreamed of seeking the deer and brought the case before the judicial officer. All were unclear. Their deluded sentiments were the same, hence the division in two. Only the sage could fully comprehend this delusion! But in an age without sages, matters lack certainty, so the judicial officer, unable to resolve what was unresolved, only added further delusion.

Wu Kaisheng said: *Xun* (恂) should be *xun* (徇). Bo Jun’s note: The *Shuowen* states: *Xun* (恂) means “sincere of heart.” The *Zuozhuan* for the eleventh year of Duke Wen reads: “The people of the state did not *xun*,” and Du’s commentary says: *Xun* (徇) means “to comply.” The *Shiwen* notes: *Xun* is pronounced *xun*, meaning “trust.”

In his middle years, Hua Zi of Yangli in Song suffered from forgetfulness. The *Shiwen* notes: *Hua* (华) is pronounced *huahua*. *Wang* (忘) is pronounced *wang*, meaning he could not remember things. What he took in the morning, he forgot by evening; what he gave in the evening, he forgot by morning.

While on the road, he forgot his journey; while in his chamber, he forgot his seat. He knew not the present, nor could he distinguish past from future.

Wang Chongmin said: The two lines *"Now he knew not the past, later he knew not the present"* are erroneous. The *Taiping Yulan* (738) cites them as *"He knew not past from future, nor present from ancient times,"* which is closer to the mark.

His entire household suffered from this affliction. The *Shiwen* notes: *Hé* (阖) is pronounced *hulà*. *Dú* (毒) means "suffering."

They consulted scribes and divined, but the omens were not revealed. Wu Kaisheng said: *Fú zhān* (弗占) means "were not verified." Bo Jun’s note: The *Xunzi*’s "Rhapsodies" reads: *"I beg to divine it with the Five Powers,"* and Yang Liang’s commentary states: *"Zhān* means 'to verify.'"

They entreated shamans and prayed, but the affliction was not averted. They summoned physicians and treated him, but the condition did not abate.

In Lu, a Confucian scholar offered himself as one able to cure Hua Zi. His wife and children offered half of their stored wealth in exchange for his remedy. Tao Hongqing said: *Jū* (居) means "stored," referring to their long-accumulated possessions. The *Tianrui* chapter’s *"exhausting their ancestral stored wealth"* carries the same meaning.

The Confucian scholar said: "This is certainly not a matter for divination by milfoil and tortoise-shell. [Note] For when the subtle workings arise there, the yarrow and oracle bones respond here, so fortune and misfortune may be inferred from the hexagrams, and hidden truths may be sought through images and numbers. But now, the heart of the forgetful man is as still as cold ashes, as vast and empty as an abandoned house. The sage would find no place to apply his discernment—how could this be a matter for divination by hexagrams?" The *Shiwen* notes: *Shī* (蓍) is pronounced *shī*. *Nì* (匿) is pronounced *nìlì*. *Pò* (泊) is pronounced *pò*. *Jiàn* (鉴) is pronounced *jiàn*.

Nor is it a matter for prayers and supplications. [Note] For sincerity and compliance may invoke blessings, and upright integrity may dispel deceit and falsehood—this is the natural order. Thus, those who feel shame before the spirits or incur resentment in human affairs inevitably bring ruin upon themselves. But when one’s emotions are not singularly deluded and one’s conduct is not wildly perverse, this is not a matter for prayers and supplications." The *Shiwen* records *"zì jí"* (自极) as *"zì zhěng"* (自拯), noting: *Zhěng* (拯) is pronounced with the rising tone, originally written as *jí* (极). *Xíng* (行) is pronounced *xiàmèng*. *Pì* (僻) is pronounced *pì*. Bo Jun’s note: *Jí* (极) means "afflicted and distressed," a common expression in Wei-Jin texts. Those unfamiliar with this meaning altered it to *zhěng* (拯), rendering the passage incoherent. This entry in the *Shiwen* appears to have been added by Xiang Xuan of the Jingyuan era, not part of Yin’s original text.

Nor is it a matter for medicine and stone needles."

When chronic ailments lodge in the organs and acute illnesses disperse through the limbs and flesh, one must rely on pulse diagnosis to discern excess and deficiency, and administer medicines and stone needles to attack the affliction. Yet if the heart is not disordered by craving, nor the body harmed by cold or heat, then the physician’s art ought to be set aside.

The annotation notes: *Jiù’ē* (疚痾) is also written as *jíbìng* (疾病), *téng’ē* (疼痾), or *jí’ē* (疾痾). The Northern Song edition reads *gōng màizhěn* (攻脉诊) for *jiǎ màizhěn* (假脉诊), and *shíyù* (食欲) for *shìyù* (嗜欲), but neither variant improves the meaning. The *Shiwen* records: *Jiù* is pronounced *jiù*; *ē* as *ē*; *zàng* as *cáng*; *zhěn* as *zhěn*.

I shall attempt to transform his heart and alter his thoughts—perhaps then he may recover!

The annotation notes: The utterly forgetful have no thoughts at all—what is there to transform? This passage itself admits it is easier to instill thought than to remove it, or easier to instill worry than to dispel it; the phrasing merely shifts direction. The variant *luàn* (乱) for *cí* (辞) is likely an error. The *Shiwen* records: *Chōu* is pronounced *chōu*.

Thereupon, I exposed him to the cold, and he sought clothing; I starved him, and he sought food; I confined him in darkness, and he sought light.

The annotation notes: First, I deprived him of what assailed him to test his response.

A Confucian scholar joyfully told his son: “The illness can be cured! Yet my method is secret—the *Shiwen* punctuates: *Rán wú zhī fāng mì* (然吾之方密) as a complete phrase—and I do not transmit it to others. Try sending away your attendants and remain alone with me in the chamber for seven days.” He complied. The *Shiwen* records: *Cóng* is pronounced *zòng*.

Lu Bujun notes: *Cóng* (从) should be read in its standard sense, meaning "to comply with." The *Shiwen* is in error. No one knew what methods he employed—[Annotation:] The Confucian scholar’s many techniques were not confined to a single path of verification. Yet the illness of many years vanished in a single morning. [Annotation:] The preceding passage states that where shamans and physicians had exhausted their arts in vain, the Confucian scholar alone could cure what ailed him. First, it cites Huazi’s forgetting as akin to spontaneity, demonstrating the ultimate state of non-contrivance, which cannot be restored through mere techniques. The Confucian scholar’s achievement surpassed that of shamans and physicians, proving that when principle is not obscure, one may employ diverse methods to guide the afflicted. It further sought to awaken the forgetful one to the realization that his former oblivion nearly approached the supreme principle. [Exegesis:] Laozi said: "In the pursuit of learning, one daily accumulates; in the pursuit of the Dao, one daily diminishes. Diminish and again diminish, until one reaches non-action." Huazi studied the Dao and forgot his own existence, while the Confucian scholar studied the manifest to augment his knowledge. One who augments knowledge must distinguish right and wrong before his eyes; one who forgets existence remains unmoved by gain or loss in the celestial storehouse. How could divination or medicine ever cure such a condition? Thus, the Confucian scholar used manifold methods to entice his mind, and right and wrong confounded his thoughts. Huazi thereby lost the Dao and afterward virtue; having lost virtue, right and wrong raced through his breast, and so the art of "sitting in forgetfulness" was lost. [Annotation:] Below *yǒu guò* (有过), the Zang edition includes the particle *hū* (乎). Wang Lai states: In the exegesis, the second *zhī* (之) in *sǔn zhī yòu sǔn zhī* (损之又损之) is superfluous. Lu Bujun notes: According to Fan Yingyuan’s *Collected Commentaries on the Daodejing*, Peng Zun’s *Collected Commentaries on the Daodejing*, and the ancient editions, both *zhī* characters are present, matching the citation in *Chongxuan*. Thus, the second *zhī* is not superfluous, and Wang’s claim is mistaken. The *Shiwen* records: *Sī* is pronounced *sì*.

Hazi, now awakened, flew into a great rage, cast out his wife, punished his son, and seized a halberd to chase away the Confucian scholar. Lu Bujun notes: The *Zuozhuan* for the twenty-third year of Duke Xi records: "Jiang said, ‘Go! Clinging to comfort will surely ruin your reputation.’ The prince refused. Jiang plotted with Zifan, got him drunk, and sent him away. When he awoke, he took up a halberd to pursue Zifan." The ancients regarded the halberd as a personal weapon, hence its frequent mention in ancient texts as *cāo gē* (操戈). The *Shiwen* records: *Cāo* is pronounced *qī dāo*. The people of Song seized him and demanded an explanation.

Hazi said, "Before, I was in oblivion—so vast and boundless that I did not perceive the existence or nonexistence of heaven and earth. Now, suddenly awakened to the past, the myriad threads of life and death, gain and loss, sorrow and joy, love and hate have arisen in tumult. The *Shiwen* notes: *shù* is pronounced *sè zhǔ*. *Lè* is pronounced *luò*. *Hào* is pronounced *hū bào*. *È* is pronounced *wū lù*. I fear that the future’s entanglements of life and death, gain and loss, sorrow and joy, love and hate will disturb my heart in this way. Could I ever again attain even a moment’s forgetfulness?" {Note} Even one whose illness resembles the ultimate principle can be thus afflicted—how much more so one who embodies its extremity? {Explanation} Hazi, desiring to return to the true but finding no way, thus raged at his wife and son and drove away the Confucian scholar. The *Shiwen* notes: *fù* is pronounced *fú yòu*.

Zigong heard of this and found it strange, so he reported it to Confucius. Confucius said, "This is not something within your grasp!" Then, turning to Yan Hui, he instructed him to record it. {Note} This principle should indeed be within Zeng’s reach, but by suppressing it, he sought to bestow subtle appreciation upon a greater worthy. {Explanation} Zigong was a scholar of eloquent learning, one who advanced through diligent study, hence the words, "This is not something within your grasp." Yan Hui, who loved learning and was second only to the sages, never deviated from benevolence, so he was commanded to record it—to illuminate the Dao through a great worthy. The character *jì* in the *Zang* edition is written as *jì* ("record"), both being interchangeable. The *Shiwen* writes *miào dàng* as *miào shǎng*, noting: *dàng* is pronounced *dīng làng*, with one version reading *shǎng*.

Among the people of Qin, there was a man of the Feng clan who had a son. The *Shiwen* notes: *Féng* is pronounced *páng*. In his youth, he was perceptive. Lu Bujun notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (49) writes *huì* ("perceptive") as *huì* ("wise"). The *Book of Later Han*, in the biography of Kong Rong, states: "Will he not soon be wise?" The commentary notes that *huì* is interchangeable with *huì* ("wise"). The *Shiwen* notes: *shào* is pronounced *shī zhào*. But upon reaching adulthood, he developed an illness of delusion and confusion. {Note} Perceptiveness is not delusion, yet the flaw of relying on it must lead to delusion. The *Shiwen* notes: *wǎng* is pronounced *wén liǎng*.

He mistook singing for weeping, saw white as black, smelled fragrance as rotten, {Note} The *Monthly Ordinances* states: "Its odor is rotten." Qian Daxin said: The ancients paired fragrance with rottenness, taking their opposition, just as flavors have sweet and bitter. The *Monthly Ordinances* states: "Spring’s odor is rank, summer’s is scorched, the center’s is fragrant, autumn’s is fishy, and winter’s is rotten." He tasted sweetness as bitterness. The *Shide Tang* edition writes *cháng* ("often") as *cháng* ("taste"). Yu Yue said: *Cháng* and *cháng* were interchangeable in antiquity. The *Liji*, in the "Shaoyi" chapter, states: "Horses are not *cháng* fed," and the *Shiwen* notes: "*Cháng* is written as *cháng* in one version." The *Erya*, in the "Shigu" section, states: "*Cháng* means sacrifice," and the *Shiwen* notes: "The character *cháng* is also written as *cháng*," both serving as evidence. The original text of the *Liezi* borrowed *cháng* for *cháng*. The *Daozang* edition replaced it with the original character, but this deviates from the ancient text’s usage. His actions were not what he deemed correct: wherever his intentions turned—heaven and earth, the four directions, water and fire, cold and heat—nothing was not inverted.

{Explanation} Those who pride themselves on petty wisdom are deemed perceptive by others; those who embody the Dao and preserve harmony are deemed foolish. One who equalizes sound and color, forgets water and fire, is beyond the discernment of common people, hence they regard the Dao as delusion and confusion.

Yangshi told his father, "The gentlemen of Lu possess many arts and skills. Might they be able to cure him? Why not seek their help?" His father went to Lu, passing through Chen. The *Shiwen* notes: *guò* is pronounced *gē*. There, he encountered Lao Dan and recounted his son’s condition. Lao Dan said, "How do you know your son is deluded? Now, all the people in the world are confused about right and wrong, blinded by profit and harm. Those sharing the same affliction are many, so none awaken. Moreover, the delusion of one person is not enough to overturn a household; the delusion of one household is not enough to overturn a village; the delusion of one village is not enough to overturn a state; the delusion of one state is not enough to overturn the world. If the entire world is deluded, who could overturn it? Wang Chongmin said: The character *qīng* ("overturn") does not correspond with the preceding text, likely an error for *zhèng* ("correct"). Lao Dan’s words to the Feng clan meant that his son’s delusion was not an illness—today, all the world’s people are confused about right and wrong, blinded by profit and harm, which is the true illness. Only because those sharing the illness are many do they fail to recognize it as such. If the entire world were as deluded as your son, who would seek to correct it? This follows the preceding *qīng* ("overturn") in error. The subsequent text—"Who could correct sorrow and joy, sound and color, odor and taste, right and wrong?"—directly continues this idea. If written as *qīng* ("overturn"), it would not convey the meaning. The *Taiping Yulan* (490) correctly writes it as *zhèng* ("correct"), providing evidence.

Had all the people in the world been of the same mind as your son—The *Shiwen* writes *xiàng* as *xiāng*, noting: *xiāng* is pronounced *xiàng*—you would be the one truly deluded. Who could correct sorrow and joy, sound and color, odor and taste, right and wrong? The *Shiwen* notes: *lè* is pronounced *luò*. Moreover, my words here are not necessarily free from delusion, let alone the gentlemen of Lu, those couriers of delusion. {Note} The gentlemen of Lu extolled benevolence and righteousness, clarifying right and wrong, hence they are called couriers of delusion. The *Shide Tang* edition omits the character *cǐ* ("this") before *yán* ("words"), while the *Taiping Yulan* (490) includes it. Wang Zhong said: *yóu* ("courier") and *yóu* ("fault") are interchangeable. Wang Chongmin said: The *Taiping Yulan* (490) writes *yóu* as *yóu*, likely altered by the compiler. Lu Bujun notes: *Yóu* and *yóu* were interchangeable in ancient script, as seen in Gu Yanwu’s *Rizhi Lu*, volume 27, under the *Erya* commentary entry.

The *Shiwen* notes: *yóu* is pronounced *yóu*. How could they resolve others’ delusions? The *Shiwen* notes: *yān* is pronounced *yúqián*. "Cherishing your provisions is not as good as hastening home."

{Note} *Róng* means to discard. This chapter clarifies that the principles of right and wrong cannot be entirely settled, for they are all formed by the majority overwhelming the few to create contention.

{Exegesis} *Róng* means to discard. The world is full of vulgar scholars, while those who awaken to the Dao are few. The deluded many mock the solitary wise, reversing truth to call them deluded. Thus Laozi said: "When inferior scholars hear the Dao, they laugh heartily at it. If they did not laugh, it would not be the Dao." Now, to expect the contentious scholars of Zhao to rectify right and wrong is to stray ever further from the Dao. The Confucians of Lu, so deeply lost in the Way of forgetting form and preserving spirit, are themselves the most deluded—how could they enlighten others’ delusions? You would do better to abandon your roadside provisions and return swiftly.

Qin Enfu said: The character *zhào* ("Zhao") in the exegesis is likely a miswriting of *qū* ("to hasten"). Mou Ting said: Xunzi’s *Discourse on Military Affairs* states, "Carry three days’ provisions," with the annotation: "*Yíng* means to bear a load." Zhuangzi’s *Opening the Trunk* says, "*Yíngténg* and hasten," with the *Shiwen* gloss: "*Yíng* means to wrap." The *Fangyan* states: "*Yíng* means to carry on the shoulder." Thus *yíngténg* means to bind and carry. Liezi’s *róng* is a loan for *yíng*. Yu Yue said: Zhang Zhan and Lu Chongxuan both gloss *róng* as "to discard," but their basis is unknown—this is likely incorrect. *Róng* stands in contrast to *shí* ("substance"); *róng* is like *huá* ("flower"). The *Erya*’s *Explanation of Plants* states: "Trees are called *huá*, grasses are called *róng*. Those that bear fruit without flowering are called *xiù*; those that flower without bearing fruit are called *yīng*." Such is its meaning. In ancient diction, all that lacks substance is called *huá* ("flowery"). The *Book of Later Han*, in the commentary to the *Biography of Ma Rong*, states: "*Huáyù* means empty reputation." If *huá* can mean "empty," then *róng* may also mean "empty." "*Róng* your provisions" means they are wasted, without practical use. The *Book of Han*, in the *Biography of Yang Xiong*, states: "The Four Elders gathered *róng* on South Mountain." Yan Shigu commented: "*Róng* means reputation." Since *róng* contrasts with *shí* ("substance"), it may also mean "name." In the context of plants, *róng* and *shí* are paired; in human affairs, *míng* ("name") and *shí* ("substance") or *xū* ("empty") and *shí* ("substance") are paired. Its meaning is thus coherent. Wu Kaisheng said: *Róng* should be the same as *yíng*; *qì* ("discard") should be *qì* (variant form). Lu Bujun noted: Yu Yue’s explanation is overly circuitous; Mou Ting’s is closer to the mark.

The *Shiwen* notes: *chuán* is pronounced *shìyuán*. *Zhēng* is pronounced *zhèng*.

A native of Yan was born in Yan but grew up in Chu. As he aged, he returned to his homeland. Passing through the state of Jin, his traveling companions deceived him. Pointing to a city wall, they said, "This is the city of Yan." The man’s expression darkened with emotion. Pointing to a local altar, they said, "This is your village’s altar." A note in *Leiyu* (ch. 34) reads: "若" is written as "君" here and below. Wang Chongmin observes: *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 558) includes a gloss after "若": "若 means 'you.'" The man sighed deeply. Pointing to a house, they said, "This is your ancestors’ dwelling." He wept silently. Pointing to a mound, they said, "This is your ancestors’ grave." The man could not restrain his sobs.

His companions burst into laughter, saying, "I have just been tricking you. This is the state of Jin." Yu Yue comments: "昔" should be "皆," a scribal error. Wang Chongmin notes: *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 558) writes "昔" as "等." Lu Bujun observes: "昔" is acceptable as is; no emendation is needed. The man was overcome with shame.

When he arrived in Yan, he truly saw the city and altars of the state of Yan, truly saw his ancestors’ house and grave—yet his sorrowful heart grew faint.

This chapter illustrates that emotions have their limits; once grief and joy have passed, what once moved one no longer stirs joy or sorrow.

Man’s nature is fundamentally alike, but habits diverge—each follows what his emotions and customs find familiar. One born in Yan never leaves his roots; one raised in Chu grows accustomed to his surroundings. Returning to one’s origin yet failing to recognize it, the shallow-minded are easily deceived. If one is led by semblances and lured, the credulous will be misled. When they realize the truth is not as they believed, they forget their emotions and feel only shame. Even when they see the real, they still regard it as false—neither right nor wrong is clear to them, for they are confused by others’ influence.

How much more so with today’s gentlemen, who all falsely cling to the city and altars of Jin—how could they know the supreme Dao of nurturing the spirit and returning to the root?

*Geng* ("grew") is written as *bian* ("then") in the Shide Hall edition. Wang Lai notes: In the commentary, the four characters *shi ren de zhi* ("the shallow-minded are easily deceived") should precede *suo gui yu ben* ("returning to one’s origin"), and *yan* ("then") should follow *shi* ("recognize").

The *Shiwen* notes: *Wei* ("faint") means "slight"; the variant *che* is an error.

---

**Chapter Four: Zhongni**

The wise one knows without knowing, for when wisdom is forgotten, nothing is known; when wisdom is employed, nothing is accomplished. One who embodies the spirit and acts alone, who forgets emotions and follows principle, abides in stillness and illumines the mysterious.

This chapter speaks of those who realize the Dao of non-action and may thus act without limitation. The world sees only the traces of the sage but not the root he has realized. Learners merely grasp the beginning of transcending emotions but not their all-pervading function—both miss the mean.

The *Shiwen* writes *wang qing* ("forgets emotions") as *qu qing* ("abandons emotions"), noting: *Qu* is read as *qiulu*, with one variant reading *wang*.

Confucius was at leisure when Zigong entered to attend him. Seeing his master’s worried expression, Zigong dared not ask. He went out and told Yan Hui, who took up his zither and sang. Confucius heard him and indeed summoned Hui in, asking, "Why do you alone find joy?"

The *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 468 and 469) includes the character *gan* ("dare") before *du* ("alone").

Hui replied, "Why does the Master alone feel sorrow?"

Hui did not speak of his desire to ask, but played the zither and sang to provoke his master’s words.

The note *xuan* ("proclaim") is written as *zhi* ("purpose") in the Zang edition.

Confucius said, "First, speak your own thoughts."

Hui said, "I once heard from you, Master: ‘Find joy in Heaven and know fate, and thus have no sorrow.’ This is why I rejoice."

Heaven is the portion of nature; fate is the reckoning of rise and fall.

The *Shiwen* notes: *fen* is pronounced *fu wen* cut, the same below.

Confucius, his expression suddenly grave, paused for a moment. The *Shiwen* notes: *qiao* is pronounced *qi xiao* cut; *qiaoran* means a change of countenance for a brief time.

He said, "Did I truly say such a thing?"

The note explains: To clarify that these words were not fully realized, he thus displayed a doubtful and questioning expression. The Daozang edition of the note reads "doubtful questioning" as "doubtful inquiry." The *Shiwen* records *shi* ("lost") as *jia*, noting: *jia* is pronounced *xia*, with one version reading *shi*. Ren Dachun states: *jia* is pronounced *xia*, thus it corresponds with *xia* ("narrow"). Judging by the context, it likely means your understanding is narrow and not yet expansive. The *Guanzi*’s "Bayan" chapter states: "When the superior is narrow, the inferior is constrained." The note explains: "When the superior is already narrow, the inferior is encompassed by it." The *Shiwen* for the *Zhouli*’s "Sishi" reads: "broad and narrow" as "broad and constricted." The *Guangya* also states: "*Jia*, *xia*, *ci*, *qiu*, *po*, *cu*—all mean near." Since *jia* shares the same gloss as *po* ("urgent") and *cu* ("pressed"), *jia* thus means "narrow." The *Hou Hanshu*’s "Juli" chapter states: "It is narrow from east to west and long from north to south." Li Xian’s note reads: "*Jia* is pronounced *xia*," thus *yi jia* ("understanding narrow") means *yi xia* ("understanding constricted"). The *Shiwen* preserves the ancient character. This was merely my past teaching. Let me now correct it with my present words.

Here is the translation:

---

The note states: "Words of the past arose in response to circumstances; what is now made clear exhausts their ultimate meaning. You merely know that delighting in Heaven and knowing fate brings no sorrow, yet you do not know the great sorrow in delighting in Heaven and knowing fate."

The note explains: "To know nothing, to delight in nothing, to sorrow in nothing—this is called greatness."

Wang Chongmin observes: The *Taiping Yulan* (468) includes a *zhi* (之) before *you* (有).

Now I tell you the truth: cultivate the self, accept poverty and success, recognize that going and coming are not of the self, and banish disorder from the mind’s reckonings. (The original text reads *zhi* (止, "to stop"), but the present version follows the *Zangben*, *Shidetang*, and *Qin* editions, emending it to *wang* (亡, "to banish"). The *Shiwen* notes: *wang* is pronounced *wang* (忘, "to forget"), and one edition reads *zhi* (止).) This is what you call delighting in Heaven and knowing fate without sorrow.

The note explains: "This merely distinguishes the boundaries of inner and outer, discerns the realms of honor and disgrace—no more. How could it be a matter of being without preference or aversion?"

The exposition states: "To delight in Heaven and know fate without sorrow is the way of timely success, not the means to respond, act, and save the world."

Confucius said: "I once held these words, but now they differ from the past. Formerly, I cultivated the *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents*, rectified rites and music—" (The *Shiwen* notes: *nang* (曩) is pronounced *nang* (乃朗切). *Yue* (乐) is pronounced *yue* (岳), and the same applies below.) "—intending to govern the world and leave a legacy for future generations."

The note explains: "The *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, rites, and music are instruments for governing the age. The sage employs them to remedy the ills of the time; if their use strays from the Dao, they are of no benefit to order."

The *Shiwen* notes: *yi* (遗) is pronounced *yi* (唯季切).

"It was not merely to cultivate the self and govern the state of Lu. The note explains: "The sage’s wisdom encompasses all things, and his Dao saves the world. To secure the self and save a single state is no way to be a sage."

Yet the rulers and ministers of Lu daily lost their proper order, benevolence and righteousness further declined, and human nature grew ever more shallow. If this Dao could not prevail in a single state or in its own time, what of the world and future generations?

The note explains: "The arts of governing the age truly require benevolence and righteousness. Once the age is ordered, the arts used to order it should be set aside. If, when all affairs are concluded, one clings to them without letting go, those who are moved by them will be few, while those who profit from them will be many. The beginning of decline and shallowness truly lies here. To observe the world through a single state, or future generations through the present—how different are the harms they bring? Only one who is perfectly adaptable and unobstructed can follow change as it suits, without clinging to one side."

Zhongfu said: "What of the world and future generations?" *Ru* (如, "what of") here means *ruhe* (如何, "how"). The omission of *he* (何) is particularly rare.

Bo Jun notes: Yu Shengwu’s *New Evidence on the Book of Changes* holds that *yi* (矣) here is the same as *yi* (以) in the *Book of Songs* (*Zhaonan*, "Gathering White Milfoil"): "Where shall we gather white milfoil?"

The *Shiwen* notes: *zhi* (治) is pronounced *zhi* (直吏切), and the same applies to *zhi luan* (治乱, "order and disorder"). *She* (舍) is pronounced *she* (舍). *He* (阂) is pronounced *ai* (碍).

"I first realized that the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, rites, and music could not save order and disorder, yet I did not know the way to reform them. This is the sorrow of those who delight in Heaven and know fate."

The note explains: "Only by discarding the misuse of rites and music, not the use of rites and music themselves—for rites and music cannot be discarded—does one not know the way to reform them. Citing this as a sorrow lays the groundwork for the meaning below, hence these words come first."

The exposition states: "It is not that the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, rites, and music are insufficient as methods for governing the world; rather, the theories of the age cannot be saved by the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, rites, and music. Yet to discard these methods would leave nothing as the foundation of rites. This is the profound sorrow of those with the Dao."

Bo Jun notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (468) includes a *ye* (也) after "This is the sorrow of those who delight in Heaven and know fate."

The *Shiwen* notes: *wei* (为) is pronounced *wei* (于伪切).

"Nevertheless, I have attained it. What is called delight and knowledge is not what the ancients meant by delight and knowledge."

The note explains: "Zhuangzi said: 'To delight in poverty and success, things and the self—this is not the sage.' Thus, the ancients did not take the absence of delight as delight, nor the absence of knowledge as knowledge. To follow what one delights in is to naturally have no delight in principle; to follow what one knows is to naturally have no knowledge in principle." The characters *suo wei* (所谓, "what is called") are inverted as *wei suo* (谓所) in all editions; the present version follows the *Jifu* edition in correcting them.

Bo Jun further notes: The *Zhuangzi* (*Da Zongshi* chapter) states: "Thus, when the sage employs troops, he may lose a state but not the people’s hearts; his beneficence extends to ten thousand generations, yet he does not do so out of love for people. Therefore, to delight in things and the self is not the sage." The note’s citation of "delighting in poverty and success" includes a *qiong* (穷, "poverty"), which is likely an interpolation.

"To have no delight and no knowledge—this is true delight and true knowledge."

The note explains: "To be without any delight or any knowledge is to be able to delight in the world’s delights and know the world’s knowledge while remaining without intention."

Thus, there is nothing in which one does not delight, nothing one does not know, nothing one does not sorrow for, and nothing one does not do.

The note explains: "Abiding in the fundamental and embodying completeness, one can act without acting and yet do all things."

"What is there to discard in the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, rites, and music? Why reform them?"

The note explains: "If one wishes to cast aside the *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents* and change the methods of governance, how is this the way to remedy ills? To employ them without clinging, to act without reliance—things will be preserved of themselves."

The exposition states: "To know what Heaven’s fate renders unavoidable and to accept one’s lot without sorrow—this is the constant heart of the noble person. But those of old who opened things and accomplished affairs, who aided people and benefited customs, were not so. They did not rest in their delight or entrust themselves to their knowledge. They preceded Heaven without opposing it, and followed Heaven while honoring its timing—this is true delight and true knowledge. Being thus, there is nothing they do not delight in, nothing they do not know, and thus they can do all things."

"Could one ever rely on such strategies? Thus, the *Songs* and *Book of Documents*, rites and music, are indeed the foundation for assisting transformation—why would one seek to change them?

The *Shiwen* notes: *Juan* is read as *yuan*. Yan Hui faced north, bowed with hands clasped, and said, 'I too have attained it.' The annotation states: This is what is meant by 'not opposing yet seeming foolish.'

Bo Jun notes: 'Bowed with hands clasped' is grammatically unsound. *Bai* should be written as □. □ is also written as □, and in the *Baihan Jian* as □. The characters for □ and *bai* are similar in form and thus mistaken. The *Shuowen* states: '□ means to raise the hands; a variant is □. Yang Xiong says *gong* is formed from two hands.' This is the modern character *gong*. The *Fei Gou* chapter of the *Xunzi* reads: 'The noble person examines the Way of the later kings and discusses it before the hundred kings of old, as if bowing in respect and deliberating.' Wang Niansun emends this, stating: '*Bai* is a corruption of *zhi*.' This serves as evidence.

He went out and told Zigong. Zigong was bewildered and lost, for he had not yet fully aligned with the ultimate words, and thus fell into confusion. Returning home, he indulged in thought for seven days without sleep or food, until his bones stood stark. The annotation states: He exerted himself in contemplation of the Dao, forgetting sleep and sustenance.

Yan Hui went again to enlighten him, whereupon Zigong returned to Master Qiu’s gate, playing the zither and reciting the texts, never ceasing for the rest of his life. The annotation states: Having awakened to the ultimate principle, he forgot all else.

The exposition states: Yan Hui, second only to the sage in the Dao, attained it without opposing what he heard. Zigong relied on the *Songs* and *Documents* for his wisdom, and thus, when words were spoken, he lost sight of their source. After Yan Hui enlightened him again, he awakened to the benefits of learning and the Dao of daily diminution.

The annotation's 'forgot' was written as 'perished' in the Northern Song edition; Wang’s edition followed this, but the present text follows the *Zang* edition and *Shi De Tang* edition in emending it.

A minister of Chen paid a visit to Lu. The *Shiwen* notes: *Pin* is read as *pì zhèng*. He had a private audience with the house of Shusun. The *Shi De Tang* edition omits the character 'house' before 'said.' Shusun said, 'There is a sage in our state.' The minister asked, 'Is it not Kong Qiu?' 'It is,' he replied. 'How do you know he is a sage?' The annotation states: Profound is this question! The Dao of the sage transcends the bounds of common understanding, beyond the reach of all things; one sees only the traces of its convergence and calls him a sage. How could one truly know what makes him a sage?

Shusun said, 'I have often heard of him from Yan Hui.' The annotation states: Profound is this answer! Unless one embodies both aspects and manifests both forms, how could one speak of even a semblance or glimpse of what comes before and after? Even with Yan Hui’s capacity, he could not adequately describe it—how much less could those beneath him?

The *Shiwen* notes: *Fo* is read as *fāng wèi*; *liang* is read as *liàng*; *cheng* is read as *chǐ zhèng* below, the same.

He said, 'Kong Qiu can set aside the mind and employ the form.' The annotation states: These are Yan Hui’s words. The sage neither sets aside nor employs anything. The terms 'setting aside' and 'employing' arise only in response to circumstances. Thus, in attending to the myriad affairs, engaging with worldly matters—these are all matters of form and trace. As for the profound and absolute, the still and silent—these remain serene and unmoving.

The exposition states: The sage responds to things as they arise, aiding the times and serving their use, guiding the multitude of beings by manifesting traces, yet does not display the true to transform the common.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Bo* is read as *pò* below, the same.

The minister of Chen said, 'There is also a sage in our state—did you not know?' 'Who is this sage?' he asked. 'Among the disciples of Lao Dan, there is one named Kang Cangzi.' The annotation states: *Kang* is read as *gū láng*, also as *gēng*. The *Shiwen* notes: *Kang Cang* is read as *Gēng Sāng*; his name was Chu, and the *Records of the Historian* writes it as *Kang Cangzi*. Jia Kui’s *Xing Shi Ying Lan* states: In Wu Commandery, there is a family named Gengsang, regarded as a scholarly clan. Duan Yucai says: Jia Kui’s *Xing Shi Ying Lan* must be the *Xing Shi Ying Xian Pu* mentioned in the *Suishu Jing Ji Zhi*.

The annotation states: Even Lao Dan did not speak of attaining the Dao himself—how could Kang Cang have attained it? This is merely a borrowed name to illustrate that the ultimate principle is never severed from the principles of things.

'He has attained Lao Dan’s Dao and can see with his ears and hear with his eyes.'
