The annotation states: The physical form is the dwelling of the mind and intelligence; the ears and eyes are the doors and windows of seeing and hearing. If the spirit is thoroughly permeating, then seeing and hearing do not depend on doors and windows, and illumination is not obstructed by walls.

Jiang Chaobo says: The *Miscellaneous Chapters* of the *Zhuangzi* reads: 'Among the followers of Lao Dan, there was one named Gengsang Chu, who had partially attained Lao Dan’s Dao and dwelt in the northern mountains of Weidie.'

The Lord of Lu heard this and was greatly astonished. The annotation states: He was not surprised by Confucius’s employment of form but by the interchangeability of ears and eyes. Since his traces were the same as those of other things, nothing startled him.

He sent a high minister with rich gifts to invite him. Wang Chongmin says: The *Yi Lin* quotes it as 'sent with the礼 of a high minister'; the *Quan Dao* chapter of the *Kang Cangzi* reads: 'Sent Shusun to return the visit and invite Kang Cangzi, treating him with the礼 of a high minister.' This aligns with the meaning of the *Yi Lin* quotation.

Bo Jun notes: The present two-volume *Kang Cangzi* was forged by Wang Shiyuan, a recluse of Xiangyang during the late Kaiyuan era of the Tang, as seen in the preface to the *Meng Haoran Ji* and the *Da Tang Xin Yu*.

Kang Cangzi accepted the invitation and arrived."

The annotation notes: One who is utterly without intent perceives no distinction between east and west as external to the self. The Duke of Lu humbly entreated him for instruction.

Kang Cangzi replied: "Those who transmit such accounts speak falsely. *Shiwen Leiju Houji*, chapter nineteen, includes the character *ye* after *wang*. *Shiwen* glosses *chuan* as pronounced *zhuān*. I can see and hear without employing ears and eyes, but I cannot alter the function of ears and eyes."

The annotation explains: To alter the function of ears and eyes is not to render them entirely without use. If they were entirely without use, the instruments themselves would be discarded.

The exegesis states: Ears and eyes are the instruments of seeing and hearing; only spirit can employ them. If spirit is absent, even the ears and eyes of a dead man cannot see or hear. Kang Cangzi understood what man is capable of, and thus did not rely on ears and eyes as the masters of seeing and hearing. How could he command ears to see and eyes to hear? This is merely the ignorance of transmitters fabricating explanations.

The Duke of Lu said: "This is most extraordinary. What is the nature of your Way? I remain eager to hear it."

The exegesis notes: The Duke of Lu still did not grasp this meaning, instead taking it as an augmentation of wonder, and thus persistently inquired about the Way.

Kang Cangzi said: "My body harmonizes with mind—this is the non-opposition of form and wisdom. Mind harmonizes with qi—this is to further distance the use of form and wisdom, entrusting oneself to the tranquil qi. Qi harmonizes with spirit—this is to be still and unmoving, entirely forgetting wisdom. When wisdom is entirely forgotten, the principle of spirit operates alone, and there is no response it does not penetrate. Spirit harmonizes with nothingness."

The annotation explains: To be one with nothingness is to be spirit; to be one with spirit is to be nothingness. Do these two possess form? Only one who possesses wisdom cannot but draw near to nothingness to achieve communion; one who forgets the mind becomes one with nothingness.

The exegesis states: The body, having substance, becomes an obstruction; the mind, having attachments, becomes fixation. That the body harmonizes with mind does not lie in physical obstruction but in the fixation of boundaries. Thus, qi in relation to mind, though moving, is without fixation; therefore, that mind harmonizes with qi does not lie in fixation but in dynamic function. That qi harmonizes with spirit does not lie in movement but in clear perception. That spirit harmonizes with nothingness transcends the marvelous beyond form, thus it does not lie in clear perception but in profound union with the real.

Bo Jun notes: The *Zhuangzi*, "Ren Jian Shi" chapter, states: "Unify your will; do not listen with the ears, but listen with the mind; do not listen with the mind, but listen with qi. The ears are limited to hearing (this sentence follows Yu Yue’s emendation), the mind is limited to correspondence. Qi is that which is empty and awaits things. Only the Dao gathers in emptiness. Emptiness is the alignment of the mind." This likely shares the same meaning. Regarding *jieran zhi you* and *weiran zhi yin*, Sun Yirang says: This passage pairs *you* with *yin*; *you* should likely be *xing*. Lu Chongxuan’s commentary reads, "Thus there is form, there is sound, no far, no near," suggesting Lu’s text originally had *xing*. (*Kang Cangzi Quandao* also follows this passage with *you*.) *Shiwen* glosses *wei* as pronounced *guǐ*.

Though distant in the eight wilds or near at the edge of one’s eyelashes—*Shiwen* glosses *jie* as pronounced *jiē*—whatever comes to engage me, I necessarily know it. The annotation explains: Only the vast openness of nothingness does not engage the sage’s thoughts. Where it touches the realm of differentiation, the illumination of spirit shines without distinction of far or near. *Shiwen* glosses *huo* as pronounced *huò*, and *fen* as pronounced *fèn*.

Yet I do not know whether it is my seven apertures and four limbs that perceive it, or my heart, belly, and six viscera that know it—*Shiwen* glosses *zang* as pronounced *cáng*. The five viscera are heart, lungs, liver, spleen, and kidneys. The six viscera include two kidneys: the left is the kidney, the right is the Gate of Life. The Gate of Life is where spirit resides. In men, it stores essence; in women, it connects to the womb. As it communicates with the kidneys, it is said there are six viscera. It is simply self-knowing.

The annotation explains: Where one’s destination is entirely forgotten, how could there be awareness of such attainment?

The exegesis states: Thus, whether form or sound, far or near, whatever comes to engage me, I know it all. Without employing the four limbs or seven apertures, it is like a bright mirror hung high, clearly illuminating itself. How could it rely on ears and eyes?

The Duke of Lu was greatly pleased.

One day, the Duke told this to Confucius, who smiled but did not answer.

**Annotation:** Kang Cang’s words have exhausted the matter—what more could Confucius say? Yet in not answering, he answers, and so he expresses it with a smile.

**Exegesis:** To express it with a smile is to grasp the purport of forgetting words.

The Chief Minister of Song—*Fayan Zhulin* (Vol. 20) reads "Wu’s Chief Minister Pi," while *Guang Hongming Ji* (Vol. 1, *Gui Zheng Lun*), *Dui Fu Yi Fei Fo Seng Shi* (Vol. 11), *Fanyi Mingyi Ji*, *Shiwen Leiju* (Front Collection, Vol. 35), and *He Bi Shi Lei* (Front Collection, Vol. 48) all read "Chief Minister Pi," though none are reliable. Lu Wenyu notes: The *Zang* edition reads "Grand" instead of "Great," and the same below. Yang Bojun observes: *Han Feizi*’s *Shuo Lin* (Part 1) states, "Ziyu met Confucius at the Chief Minister of Song’s residence." *Shuo Lin* (Part 2) says, "The Grand Minister of Song was noble and decisive." *Nei Chu Shuo* (Part 1) mentions, "Dai Huan was the Grand Minister of Song," and again, "The Chief Minister of Song sent his young steward to the market." Gu Guangqi remarks: "These all refer to the same person—Song’s Chief Minister, surnamed Dai and named Huan, a high minister of Song." The *Analects* (*Zihan* chapter) records: "The Grand Minister asked Zigong, ‘Is your Master a sage? How is it that he is so versatile?’ Zigong replied, ‘Surely Heaven has endowed him to be a sage, and moreover, he is versatile.’ When the Master heard of this, he said, ‘The Grand Minister knows me! I was poor in my youth, so I acquired many humble skills. Does a noble man need so many? No, he does not.’" This passage draws from that *Analects* exchange, casting the Grand Minister as the Chief Minister of Song and framing their dialogue. The *Shiwen* reads "Chief Minister of Song," noting: *Da* is pronounced *tai*. Song was also called Shang, as its capital was Shangqiu, hence the two names. "Grand Minister" is an official title. Yang Bojun notes: Song was the successor of Shang, hence it was also called Shang. The *Zuozhuan* (Duke Xi, Year 22) states: "The Chu people attacked Song to rescue Zheng. The Duke of Song prepared for battle, but the Grand Marshal firmly advised, ‘Heaven has long abandoned Shang—if you seek to revive it, you cannot be forgiven!’" The *Zuozhuan* (Duke Ai, Year 9) also records: "The historian Gui said, ‘This is called *Chen Yang*—it is auspicious for raising troops, favorable for attacking the Jiang, but inauspicious for Shang. Attacking Qi is permissible, but opposing Song is ill-omened.’" This confirms the point. Though the state name Shang originally derived from a place name (as discussed in Wang Guowei’s *Guantang Jilin*), the *Shiwen*’s explanation is less precise.

The Chief Minister of Song asked, "Is Qiu a sage?"
Confucius replied, "If Qiu dares claim sagacity, how could he be a sage?"

**Annotation:** What the world calls sages is merely based on their traces—how could they know what makes one a sage or not? Thus, Qiu is merely learned and widely informed.

**Annotation:** He appears learned and widely informed, but in truth, he has nothing to learn and nothing to know. The *Shiwen* reads "appears" as *shijian*, noting: *Jian* is pronounced *pian*.

The Chief Minister of Song asked, "Were the Three Kings sages?"
Confucius replied, "The Three Kings were adept at employing wisdom and courage—whether they were sages, Qiu does not know."
The character *fu* ("not") in all editions reads *bu* ("no"), but this follows the *Daozang* white-text edition and Lin Xiyi’s edition.

He asked, "Were the Five Emperors sages?"
Confucius replied, "The Five Emperors were adept at employing benevolence and righteousness—whether they were sages, Qiu does not know."

He asked, "Were the Three Sovereigns sages?"
Confucius replied, "The Three Sovereigns were adept at following the times—whether they were sages, Qiu does not know."

**Annotation:** Confucius’s erudition, Tang and Wu’s martial prowess, Yao and Shun’s yielding, Fuxi and Shen Nong’s simplicity—these are all coarse traces of sages responding to their eras, not what makes them sages. What makes them sages is fundamentally beyond the reach of words and traces.

**Exegesis:** To clarify that the great Dao is not a trace: what later generations expound are merely its traces. Thus, the Master, addressing what people commonly perceive, sought to illuminate the true sage.

The note "Confucius" in the *Shide Tang* edition reads "Qiu." Wang Chongmin observes: The phrase "adept at following the times" is semantically incoherent. Likely, the original read "The Three Sovereigns were adept at following the times," with the character *ren* ("employing") interpolated due to the preceding phrases "The Three Kings were adept at employing wisdom and courage" and "The Five Emperors were adept at employing benevolence and righteousness." Wisdom and courage, benevolence and righteousness, can be "employed," but following the times does not require "employment." Both *Leiju* (Vol. 30) and *Taiping Yulan* (Vol. 401) omit the character *ren*. The *Shiwen* notes: *Pu* ("simplicity") is pronounced *pianjiao*.

The Chief Minister of Song was greatly astonished.

**Annotation:** The world calls them sages, yet Confucius denies their sagacity—hence the Chief Minister’s astonishment.

He asked, "Then who is a sage?"
Yang Bojun notes: The character *zhe* ("one who") likely belongs after *sheng* ("sage"), originally reading "who is a sage?"

Confucius’s expression shifted, and after a pause, he said, "There are sages among the people of the West."

**Annotation:** Is sagacity tied to a fixed place? I speak of it in such distant terms.

"There are sages who govern without disorder."

**Annotation:** They do not govern by governing, so they cannot be disordered.
Yu Yue observes: The original text read "govern without self-disorder." *Luan* ("disorder") means "order"—it signifies governing without governing. This aligns with the following phrases: "speak without self-trust," "transform without self-action." Later readers, not grasping *luan*’s meaning, altered it to "without disorder," which is incorrect. Zhang’s annotation—"They do not govern by governing, so they cannot be disordered"—reflects the error in his base text.

The Lu edition is the same.

**Explication of Pronunciation:** *Zhi* ("govern") is pronounced *zhílì*. The *zhi* below is the same.

"They speak without self-trust."

**Annotation:** Those who speak are not trustworthy.

"They transform without self-action."

**Annotation:** Those who act cannot transform. This is the ultimate perfection of non-action. "Vast and boundless—people cannot name it."

**Annotation:** He Yan’s *Discourse on the Nameless* states: "To be praised by the people is to have a name; to lack praise is to be nameless. As for the sage, his name is nameless, his praise is unpraiseworthy. To call the nameless the Dao, and the unpraiseworthy great—then the nameless may be spoken of as having a name, and the unpraiseworthy as having praise. Yet how could they be the same in function as those that can be praised or named? This is like comparing them to nothingness, yet they possess all things. Within the realm of possession, they align with nothingness and differ from those that possess. Like attracts like, no matter how distant; unlike repels, no matter how near. It is like yin within yang, or yang within yin—each seeks its own kind. Summer is yang, yet its evenings and nights, far removed, share yin with winter; winter is yin, yet its mornings and days, far removed, share yang with summer. All differ from what is near yet align with what is distant. Only by examining these differences and similarities can the discourse on the nameless be understood. What brings one to this? The Dao is nothingness, possessing nothing. Since the beginning of heaven and earth, all things have possessed something; yet it is still called the Dao because it can once more employ nothingness. Thus, though dwelling in the realm of names, it effaces the form of the nameless; though residing in the distant body of yang, it forgets its own distant kindred in yin."

Xiahou Xuan said: "Heaven and earth operate by nature; the sage employs nature. Nature is the Dao. The Dao is originally nameless, hence Laozi said, 'Forced to name it.' Confucius called Yao 'vast and boundless, beyond naming.' Below, he speaks of 'towering success,' which is a forced name, borrowing what the world knows to describe it. How could something with a name then be called 'beyond naming'? Only because it is nameless can it be named with all the names under heaven—yet is that truly its name? This is sufficient to illustrate, yet none comprehend it, like gazing at Mount Tai’s towering majesty and claiming the primal qi lacks vastness."

**Note on the Shide Tang Edition:** "Sufficient" (*zú*) is written as "this" (*shì*); "vastness" (*máng*) as "boundless" (*máng*).

**Explication of Pronunciation:** *Qiǎng* ("forced") is pronounced *qíliǎng*; *wéi* ("to name") as *yúwěi*; *biàn* ("all") is the same as *piàn*. *Jué* ("towering") is pronounced *jiānwù*; *máng* as *máng*.

"Qi [the Grand Steward] suspected him of being a sage. Did he not know whether he was truly a sage or truly not a sage?"

**Annotation:** The principle of sagacity is profoundly obscure, hence one can only suspect it.

Liang Zhangju said: "Praise of the Buddha likely begins here."

The Grand Steward Shang fell silent, pondering in his heart: "Confucius has deceived me!"

**Annotation:** This is beyond the grasp of ordinary understanding, so he deemed it deception.

**Explication:** Those who establish traces to exalt teachings, or clarify conduct to inspire transformation, are but worthy sages who save the world. As for one who embodies the great Dao—encompassing all like heaven and earth, transforming like the four seasons—without showing what can be governed yet cannot be disordered, without relying on words to be trusted, overflowing to benefit the myriad things, embracing all sentient beings with life, vast and unfathomable—this is the sage. To lodge him in a place and explain him with words is still insufficient; thus, one resorts to doubt and analogy to convey him. This is what the Grand Steward did not understand, taking it as the Master’s deceit.

**Explication of Pronunciation:** *Mò* ("silent") is pronounced *mò*.

Zixia asked Confucius: "What is Yan Hui’s character like?"
The Master said: "Hui’s benevolence surpasses my own."

**Pei Jun’s Note:** In the *Shuo Yuan*’s "Miscellaneous Sayings" and the *Kongzi Jiayu* (Book 6), "benevolence" (*rén*) is written as "trustworthiness" (*xìn*).

"What is Zigong’s character like?"
The Master said: "Ci’s eloquence surpasses my own."

**Pei Jun’s Note:** In the *Shuo Yuan*’s "Miscellaneous Sayings" and the *Kongzi Jiayu* (Book 6), "eloquence" (*biàn*) is written as "quickness" (*mǐn*).

"What is Zilu’s character like?"
The Master said: "You’s courage surpasses my own."

"What is Zizhang’s character like?"
The Master said: "Shi’s dignity surpasses my own."

**Annotation:** That is, solemn dignity.

Zixia rose from his mat and asked: "Then why do these four serve you?"
The Master said: "Sit! I will tell you."

The *Shiwen* notes: "語" is read as *yú jù* (鱼据切).

Hui could embody benevolence but could not be resolute.
**Annotation:** *Fǎn* (反) means "to change." One who clings to oneness without change, lacking the adaptable wisdom to respond to things, will inevitably encounter obstruction wherever they go.
**Explanation:** One may journey with him along the Way, but not entrust him with discretion.

Yu Yue said: The character *fǎn* (反) lacks meaning here; it is likely a corruption of *rèn* (刃). In vulgar script, *rèn* (刃) is written as 刃, hence the error of rendering it as *fǎn* (反). *Rèn* (刃) and *rěn* (忍) are interchangeable. The *Mao Commentary* on the *Ode* "Jiang Zhongzi" states: "the hardy and *rěn* (忍) tree," while the *Zheng Annotation* on the *Ode* "Yi" speaks of "the pliant and *rěn* (忍) tree." The *Shiwen* further notes: "*Rěn* (忍) was originally written as *rèn* (刃)." This serves as evidence. "Could embody benevolence but could not be *rèn* (刃)" thus means "could embody benevolence but could not be *rěn* (忍)." This aligns perfectly with the subsequent text: "Ci could be eloquent but could not be reticent; You could be courageous but could not be timid; Shi could be dignified but could not be accommodating." The *Huainanzi*'s "Among Men" chapter also records this matter, stating: "Qiu could be benevolent and yet *rěn* (忍), eloquent and yet reticent, courageous and yet timid." Here, the character is correctly written as *rěn* (忍), providing clear proof. Zhang’s annotation, "反 means 'to change,'" shows that the text he relied upon was already corrupted. The Lu edition concurs.

**Pei Jun’s Note:** Yu Yue’s argument is highly persuasive.

If so, then this "忍" (*rěn*) should be read in the same sense as in the *Zuozhuan*'s "Duke Wen, Year One": "Moreover, this man has the eyes of a wasp and the voice of a jackal—he is a *rěn* (cruel) man," where *rěn* means "cruel-hearted" as used today. "Ci could be eloquent but could not be reticent" [*nè*]: [Explanation] He possessed the ability to advance but had not yet ascended to the Dao. **Pei Jun’s Note:** The *Shuo Yuan*'s "Miscellaneous Sayings" and *Kongzi Jiayu*'s "Six Teachings" both write *nè* (讷) as *qū* (屈). The *Shiwen* notes: *nè* is pronounced *núhū* (奴忽). "You could be courageous but could not be timid": [Explanation] He knew only the masculine but could not abide by the feminine. "Shi could be dignified but could not be accommodating." [Annotation] To be eloquent yet unable to be reticent is to lack the substance of loyalty and trust; to be courageous yet unable to be timid is to harm the Dao of benevolence and forbearance; to be dignified yet unable to be accommodating is to violate the principle of harmonizing and concealing one’s brilliance—all of these are fixations on one aspect. [Explanation] To be self-guarded and austere yet unable to harmonize with others is to lose the virtue of harmony.

Xu Shidong says: In the *Analects*, "Master Zeng said, 'How imposing Zhang is!'"—this is what is meant by "dignified"; and "It is difficult to join him in practicing benevolence"—this is what is meant by "unable to be accommodating."

"Even if I could exchange my Way for the combined virtues of the Four Masters, I would not consent." [Annotation] Each of the Four Masters embodies the extreme of a single practice; even if they were combined, to seek to exchange my Dao for theirs is not something I would permit. **Pei Jun’s Note:** This *yì* (易) should be understood as "exchange," not "transformation." Zhang’s annotation, interpreting it as "transformation," is incorrect; Lu’s explanation as "exchange" is correct. The *Shiwen* notes: *xíng* (行) is pronounced *xiàmèng* (下孟).

"This is why they served me without divided loyalty." [Annotation] Gathering and uniting must be entrusted to the sage, and thus one cannot cease even if one wished to. [Explanation] Even if one possessed the combined virtues of benevolence, eloquence, dignity, and courage, I would still not exchange my Way for theirs—how much less so for those who cannot combine them? The Master could encompass what the Four Masters could not, and thus they served him without divided hearts. This discussion concerns the greatness of the Dao, which is further elaborated in the chapter on "Concealment and Manifestation."

The *Shiwen* notes: *èr* (贰) means "doubt"; *yāo* (要) is pronounced *yīyáo* (一遥).

After Master Liezi had studied under Master Hulu Zi Lin—[Annotation] a teacher who daily diminished [his attachments]—and befriended Bohun Maoren, the *Shiwen* notes: *mào* (瞀) is pronounced *mòhóu* (莫侯), he then resided in the southern outskirts. The *Shiwen* notes: One version writes "反居" (*fǎn jū*, "returned to reside") instead of "乃居" (*nǎi jū*, "then resided"). **Pei Jun’s Note:** The *Taiping Yulan* (406) correctly cites it as "反."

Those who followed him were so numerous that even daily reckoning could not keep pace. [Annotation] Visitors came in an unbroken stream; even if one tallied them day by day, one could not exhaust the count. Hu Huaichen says: "日" (*rì*, "day") is a corruption of "百" (*bǎi*, "hundred"). "Hundreds tallied yet not exhausted" means that those who followed Liezi were so numerous that none could match him. The *Huangdi* chapter states, "The gulls that came numbered in the hundreds yet did not cease" (*Lüshi Chunqiu* writes "数" [*shù*, "count"]), which shares the same structure and serves as evidence. Wang Shumin says: The *Chuxue Ji* (18) cites "游" (*yóu*, "travel") for "处" (*chǔ*, "reside") and "百" for "日"; the *Taiping Yulan* (404) also writes "百" for "日." It is likely that "百" is the correct character. The *Shiwen* notes: *shù* (数) is pronounced *sèzhǔ* (色主); *liào* (料) is pronounced *liáo* (聊).

Nevertheless, Master Liezi was also somewhat obscure. [Annotation] Liezi himself did not know their number. Yu Yue says: *wēi* (微) means "dim." The *Zhouyi*'s *Tuan* commentary on *Zhun* states, "Heaven creates in the midst of dimness." The *Zhengyi* cites Dong Yu: "*mèi* (昧) means subtle things." The *Xici* commentary states, "To know the subtle and know the manifest." The *Wen Xuan*'s commentary on the *Western Capital Rhapsody* cites an old annotation: "To know the subtle is to know the dim." Thus, *wēi* (微) and *mèi* (昧) share the same meaning. "Master Liezi was also somewhat *wēi*" is equivalent to saying "Master Liezi was also somewhat *mèi*." Hence, Zhang’s annotation states, "He himself did not know their number." Tao Hongqing says: *wēi* means "subtle." The *Xunzi*'s "Discourse on Warfare" states, "The feudal lords possess the ability to be subtle and refined in their regulations." Yang’s commentary: "*wēimiào* (微妙) means utmost precision." This passage says that Liezi’s arts were subtle, which is why, though his disciples were many, he could daily engage with them in debate and be heard far and wide. Later in this chapter: "Long Shu said to Wen Zhi, 'Your arts are subtle! I have an illness—can you cure it?'" The *Tang Wen* chapter states, "Master Xiang then clapped his chest, stamped his feet, and exclaimed, 'Your playing is subtle!'" Both refer to the subtlety of the arts, which confirms the meaning of this passage. Zhang’s annotation, "Liezi himself did not know their number," and Yu’s interpretation of *wēi* as *mèi* are both incorrect.

Day after day, they debated without ceasing, and nothing went unheard. [Annotation] Master and disciples engaged in teaching and practice, their voices carrying far and wide. [Explanation] Since his followers were so numerous that Liezi could not tally them, he daily discoursed on the traces of the sages, and nothing went unheard.

Yet for twenty years, he and Master Nanguo lived as neighbors, sharing a wall, without ever visiting or sending inquiries. [Annotation] Their Ways were profoundly aligned, and thus, even in old age, they did not exchange visits. When they encountered each other on the road, their eyes seemed not to see. [Annotation] When the Dao is present, sight is abandoned.

His disciples and followers suspected that Master Liezi and Master Nanguo were enemies. [Annotation] *dí* (敌) means "enemy." [Explanation] The crowd suspected enmity, seeing that they did not exchange visits. **Pei Jun’s Note:** Later in the text, "Among the disciples of Puze there was one named Bo Fengzi," the annotation states: "*yì* (役) means 'disciple.'" The *Zhuangzi*'s "Gengsang Chu" chapter states, "Laozi had a disciple named Gengsang Chu," and the *Shiwen* cites Sima: "*yì* (役) means 'student disciple.'" Hence, "disciples and followers" are mentioned together.

There came one from Chu who asked Master Liezi, "What enmity exists between you and Master Nanguo?"

Master Liezi replied, "Master Nanguo’s appearance is full yet his mind is empty; his ears do not hear, his eyes do not see, his mouth does not speak, his mind does not know, and his form is without change. **Tao Hongqing’s Note:** The character *tì* (惕) should be *□*. The *Shuowen* states: '*□* means intertwined.' It is the original character in the *Yijing*. 'Form without *□*' means his form does not alter. The following text states, 'Upon seeing Master Nanguo, he indeed appeared as if a disembodied spirit, impossible to engage. Turning to look at Master Liezi, his form and spirit were not in accord, impossible to join.' This confirms that his form does not alter. Later generations have seen *yì* (易) often but *□* rarely, thus mistakenly writing *tì* (惕).' **Annotation on the Text:** *Tì* is pronounced *tā lì*. What shall we do when we go?

**[Annotation]** *Chōng* (充) means "complete." When the mind is empty, the form is whole; thus, the ears are not confused by sounds, the eyes are not hindered by sights, the mouth does not choose its words, and the mind does not employ knowledge. Inner and outer merge as one, so the form does not tremble.

**[Explanation]** His appearance is whole and his mind is perfect, never engaging in the distinctions of ears, eyes, mouth, or mind. Thus, his mind has no use for knowledge, and his form has no cause for anxiety or change. **Note:** The character *wéi* (为) appears as *yān* (焉) in Wang’s edition; here, it is corrected according to other versions.

"Nevertheless, come with me and let us go together."

They reviewed forty disciples to accompany them.

**[Annotation]** Was this journey to distinguish the excellent from the inferior or to calculate the long from the short? The number was forty, so it is recorded directly as such.

**[Pronunciation Note]** *Yuè* (阅) is pronounced *yuè*.

They saw Nan Guozi, who indeed resembled a *qīpò*—utterly unapproachable.

**[Annotation]** *Qīpò* refers to a clay figurine. Another interpretation reads *qī* [missing character]. With spirit congealed and form dissolved, external things could not perceive him.

**[Note]** The character *□* originally appeared as *tóu* (头, "head"); it is corrected here according to the *Shidetang* edition.

Ren Dachun states: The original text reads, "Nan Guozi’s appearance resembled a *qīpò*," and Zhang Zhan’s annotation says, "*Qīpò* is a clay figurine." This likely refers to a figure made of clay adorned with a human face—what is called a *□tóu*. Jiang Chaobo argues: "*Qīpò* should be *qīchǒu* (□丑), a corruption of the character." The *Huainanzi*’s *Jingshen Xun* states, "Gazing upon the most exalted and favored is like observing a passing traveler; beholding Mao Qiang or Xi Shi is like seeing a *qīchǒu*," with Gao You’s annotation: "*Qīchǒu* means extreme ugliness." Zhang Zhan’s annotation is incorrect.

Wang Chongmin says: Ren’s interpretation is mistaken.

Though *qī□* shares a single graph, "*qīpò*" and "*□tóu*" are not the same thing. *Qīpò* is used to pray for rain, while *□tóu* is used to drive away plague. *□tóu* is so named for its hideous appearance, whereas *qīpò* is simply a clay figurine. Here, describing Nan Guozi as resembling a *qīpò* serves to illustrate the depth of his attainment of the Dao—what is meant by "a form like withered wood, a mind like dead ashes." Zhang’s annotation further cites an alternative interpretation: "*Qī□* refers to a spirit whose form is so concentrated that external things cannot perceive it." This aligns with the intended meaning.

Bo Jun notes: Wang’s interpretation is correct.
The *Shiwen* states: *Pò* is pronounced *piàn’gè*. Dictionaries write it as *qī□*, meaning "a human face of extreme ugliness." *□* is pronounced *piàn’gè*. *Sàng* is pronounced *xīlàng*. Qin Enfu says: The *Shiwen* writes it as *qī*, but this is a scribal error—it should be *□*. The *Shuowen Jiezi* states: "[*□*] means 'ugly.'" In the *Guangyun*, *□* is pronounced *pǐ’gè*. Its sound is close to *pò*, making them interchangeable loan characters.

Ren Dachun states: The *qī* in *qīpò* takes *□* as its original graph. The *Shuowen* says: "*□* means 'ugly,' from *yè* (page) with *qí* as phonetic. Today, in plague-expelling rituals, there is the *□tóu*." The *Yupian* and *Guangyun* concur. It is also written as *魌 (qī)*—the *Zhouli*’s *Fangxiangshi* commentary says: "It is like the *qītóu* of today." It is also written as *倛 (qī)*—the *Xunzi*’s *Feixiang* chapter says: "Confucius’ face resembled a *méngqī*." Yang Liang’s annotation: "It refers to the *fangxiang*." It is also written as *□*—the *Yupian* states: "*□* is the same as *□*." All share the same pronunciation as *qī*, hence this text also writes it as *qī*.

Gazing upon Master Liezi, his form and spirit seemed mismatched, such that he could not mingle with others.
**[Annotation]** This describes a spirit that commands the body.
A mind without thought shows no movement in the countenance; thus, they appear uncoordinated, and how could external things engage with them?
**[Exegesis]** When his disciple Yuejian went to visit him, Nan Guozi indeed resembled a *qīpò*—like the *qītóu* of today—such that his form and spirit were inaccessible.

Suddenly, Nan Guozi pointed to one of Liezi’s disciples in the back row and spoke to him.
**[Annotation]** He happened to be in the back row, without regard for rank or status. Responding to stimuli without intention toward things.
**[Shiwen]** *Háng* is pronounced *hùláng*.

The disciple was *kànkàn*-like, as if single-minded and domineering.
**[Annotation]** One who has attained the ultimate principle speaks no words. When words arise, distinctions between self and other emerge. The sage engages with the world through humble deference, aligning with things. Thus, to an observer, he may seem to seek truth and strive for superiority.
**[Exegesis]** The disciple in the back row had not yet forgotten concerns of right and wrong. His *kànkàn* manner was merely the air of one seeking to prevail.

Yu Yue states: The *Shiwen* notes, "In one version, *zài* (在) is written as *cún* (存)." This should be followed. The *Zhuangzi*’s *Tianxia* chapter says: "Shi Cunxiong had no method." This also contains the phrase *cúnxióng*, providing evidence.
**[Shiwen]** *Kàn* is pronounced *kǒuhàn*. *Zàixióng* in one version is written as *cúnxióng*.

Liezi’s disciples were astonished.

**[Annotation]** Observing his corpse-like stillness, they saw him as no different from wood or earth; witnessing his engagement with things, they perceived him as if clinging to right and wrong—hence their astonishment.
**[Shiwen]** *Hài* (駴) is written as *hài* (骇), noting: "駴 and 骇 are the same."
Returning to their lodgings, all bore expressions of doubt.

**[Annotation]** He sought to elicit Master Liezi’s words.
**[Exegesis]** They suspected he had not yet relinquished the mind of victory and defeat.

Master Liezi said: "The one who attains the meaning speaks no words; the one who advances in knowledge also speaks no words.
**[Annotation]** Having exhausted the principle and embodied its ultimate, both words and meaning are forgotten.
**[Shiwen]** *Jìn* is pronounced *jìn*.

To employ no-words as words is still to speak; to employ no-knowledge as knowledge is still to know.
**[Annotation]** Just as one seeks to abolish words through no-words and dispel knowledge through no-knowledge, those who revere rare speech and follow secondary teachings remain inevitably bound to words and knowledge.

No-words yet not-words, no-knowledge yet not-knowledge—these are still words, still knowledge.
**[Annotation]** By comparison, even those who strive to preserve the natural and abide in the realm of no-words and no-knowledge are but attempting to dispel what cannot be dispelled, to know what cannot be known.
One who attempts to dispel what cannot be dispelled has not yet departed from dispelling; one who claims to know what cannot be known—when has he ever forgotten knowledge? This is assuredly not the natural forgetting of words and knowledge.
**[Annotation]** "Has not yet departed from dispelling": The *Wang* edition writes *bù* (不) for *wèi* (未); here corrected according to the Northern Song edition and the *Zang* edition.
Yu Yue states: *Yǔ* (与) means *wéi* (为). Above it says, "To employ no-words as words is still to speak; to employ no-knowledge as knowledge is still to know"; thus here it says, "No-words as not-words, no-knowledge as not-knowledge—still words, still knowledge." This builds upon the preceding passage to advance a further meaning. The earlier passage uses *wéi* (为), while this uses *yǔ* (与), differing in wording but not in sense—such variations are common in ancient texts. The *Guanzi*’s *Jie* chapter states: "Even from my concubine’s body, I do not *wéi* (为) others to hold or meet." Yin Zhichang’s commentary says, "*Wéi* is like *yǔ*," hence *yǔ* is also like *wéi*. For further discussion, see Wang’s *Jingzhuan Shici*.
**[Shiwen]** *Lí* is pronounced *lìzhì*.

Yet there is nothing not spoken, nothing not known; yet there is nothing spoken, nothing known.
**[Annotation]** Now, no-words are the source of words; no-knowledge is the master of knowledge. The mind of the perfected person is vast and empty, responding to things with words yet not his own words; knowing through things yet not his own knowledge. Thus, though he speaks all day, he bears no reputation for profound silence; though he employs knowledge all day, he bears no name of toiling thought. Therefore, he attains nothing not spoken, nothing not known.
**[Shiwen]** *Chēng* is pronounced *chǐzhèng*.

Such is the case, and nothing more. Why this groundless astonishment?"

**[Annotation]** Those who fail to comprehend where the most wondrous converges grow coarser still; those who attain the loftiest heights find themselves descending instead. Then, marveling at the strange countenance of responsive stillness or the unusual bearing of movement and rest—how could this not be groundless astonishment?

**[Exegesis]** Supreme knowledge and intent both forget words. If there were distinctions of superiority or inferiority, one would need words to guide them. Yet what difference is there between wordless words and knowing without knowledge? Nevertheless, where the Dao is concerned, one ought to discern this: there has never been speech, yet never an absence of speech; never knowledge, yet never an absence of knowledge. The principle is precisely thus—why this baseless wonder?

Master Liezi studied—
**[Annotation]** The preceding chapter states, "Liezi studied the Dao of riding the wind."
**[Bo Jun’s Note]** There is likely a missing "之" before "学."

—three years later, his mind dared not entertain judgments of right and wrong, his mouth dared not speak of profit and harm. Only then did Old Shang deign to glance at him askance.
**[Shiwen]** *Miǎn* is pronounced as "squinting sideways."

Five years later, his mind once more pondered right and wrong, his mouth once more spoke of profit and harm. Only then did Old Shang begin to relax his features and smile.

Seven years later, he followed his mind’s every thought—
**[Shiwen]** *Cóng* is pronounced *zòng.*

—yet no right or wrong remained; he followed his mouth’s every word, yet no profit or harm remained.

Master Liezi was first drawn by his teacher to sit beside him on the same mat.
**[Annotation]** His sidelong glance, his smile, and their shared seat seemed to convey subtle shifts of praise or censure, elevation or demotion.

Yet the heart of the sage responds to circumstances and is moved, measuring itself by the weight of external things—how could it be fixed to one direction alone?
**[Wang Chongmin’s Note]** The character "吾" is likely superfluous. This passage also appears in the *Huangdi* chapter. There, it is Liezi’s words to Yin Sheng, so the "吾" is appropriate. Here, however, the narrative is in the author’s voice, and the inclusion of "吾" renders it incoherent.

Nine years later, his mind roamed freely in thought,
**[Shiwen]** *Heng* is pronounced with a falling tone.
his mouth spoke without restraint—yet he no longer knew whether these were his own judgments of right and wrong, profit and harm, or another’s. Inner and outer had merged.
**[Shiwen]** *Jin* is pronounced *jin.*

Only then did his eyes become like ears, his ears like nose, his nose like mouth—all alike, with no distinction.
**[Lu Wenchang’s Note]** The second "mouth" is redundant. The earlier scroll includes an "也" after "无不同," which should be followed.
**[Wang Shumin’s Note]** Lu’s observation is correct. The *Huangdi* chapter does not repeat the "口" character.

His mind congealed, his form dissolved; flesh and bone fused as one. He no longer sensed where his body leaned, where his feet trod, what his mind pondered, or where his words resided. Thus it was—nothing of principle remained hidden.
**[Annotation]** This passage appears in the *Huangdi* chapter, where it is explained in detail. Its repetition here serves a purpose: first, it clarifies the ultimate attainment of inherent nature, enabling one to ride transformation without end; later, it elucidates the principle of following the heart, illuminating even the most obscure depths. The two chapters appear in tandem, each with its own intent—how could one fail to discern this?

**[Exegesis]** Laozi said, *"Great wisdom seems foolish; great eloquence seems inarticulate."* People only recognize the distinction between knowing and speaking, unaware that not knowing and not speaking are the same. Thus, the *Huangdi* chapter demonstrates the use of wordless speech to aid others, while this chapter revisits the topic of speech, showing that the use of words is no different from their absence.
**[Annotation]** The character "则" appears as "明" in the *Cang* edition; "攸趣" is "攸极" in the Northern Song edition, followed by the Wang edition. Here, the *Cang* and *Shidetang* editions are adopted for correction.
**[Shiwen]** *Chong* is pronounced *zhuyong.*

Early on, Liezi delighted in wandering.
**[Shiwen]** *Hao* is pronounced *hubaò* (falling tone), as below.

Master Huqiu asked, "You, Gou, delight in wandering—what is it you love about wandering?"
Liezi replied, "The joy of wandering lies in the ever-new play of things.
**[Annotation]** What one encounters is always fresh.
**[Shiwen]** *Le* is pronounced *luò.*

Others wander to observe what they see; I wander to observe what transforms.
**[Annotation]** "Others" refers to the common and petty, who only perceive the contrasts of glory and decay, taking them as fortune or misfortune, unaware that they move with the flux of change, which never pauses for even a moment.
**[Variant]** The *Shidetang* edition reads "观之所变."
**[Annotation]** "惟观" appears as "惟睹" in the *Cang* and *Shidetang* editions.
**[Yu Yue’s Note]** "之" is equivalent to "其." In the *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Yinchu* chapter), it states, *"之子是必大吉,"* where Gao You glosses "之" as "其." In the *Mencius* (*Gongsun Chou* chapter), it reads, *"皆悦而愿为之氓矣,"* and the *Zhouli* (*Zaishi* commentary) quotes it as *"皆悦而愿为其民矣,"* showing that "之" and "其" share the same meaning. Above, it says *"观其所见,"* and below, *"观之所变,"*—the wording differs, but the meaning is the same. Such examples abound in ancient texts. The variant reading "其" likely arises from a failure to grasp this classical usage.

The *Shiwen* notes: "悴 is pronounced as *jízuì*."

"Wandering, ah, wandering! Yet none can discern this wandering."

**[Annotation]** Though people wander with Liezi as one, the manner of their wandering differs—hence the exclamation, "Wandering, ah, wandering!" This clarifies the distinction between the two perspectives. None have yet distinguished between them, for those who understand are few.

**[Exegesis]** The transformations of things are ceaseless, ever-shifting without constancy. Others merely delight in what they perceive, while I observe their transformations—this is how I differ from them.

**[Variant]** "辨" appears as "辩" in the *Cang* edition.
The *Shiwen* notes: "鲜 is pronounced as *xīqiǎn*."

Master Huqiu said: "Does Youkou’s wandering truly align with others’, or does he claim it fundamentally differs? For all that is seen, one invariably perceives its changes."

**[Annotation]** If there is no momentary pause, then what is seen now is never what was seen before. Thus, whether observing what is seen or observing what changes, there is no basis for distinction. Those who indulge in the impermanence of external things fail to recognize their own impermanence.

**[Annotation]** Both the external and the self flow away with the transformations. Those who pursue outward wandering do not know to turn inward in observation.

**[Bo Jun’s Note]** "Outward wandering" and "inward observation" stand in contrast, implying that observation is also a form of wandering. The *Mencius* (*King Hui of Liang* chapter) states: *"What must I cultivate to compare with the observations of the former kings?"* Zhao Qi’s commentary reads: *"What cultivation would allow one to compare with the former kings’ wandering and observation?"*—using "wandering" to gloss "observation." The *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Jichun* chapter) says: *"Forbid women from observing,"* and Gao You’s annotation explains: *"Observation means wandering."* These are all evidence of this usage.
The *Shiwen* notes: "不知 appears as 不如 in one edition. 观 is pronounced as *guàn*. 谛 means *examination*."

Those who wander outwardly seek completeness in things; those who observe inwardly find sufficiency within themselves. To find sufficiency within oneself is the perfection of wandering; to seek completeness in things is its failure.

**[Annotation]** Though man possesses a seven-foot form, the principles of Heaven and Earth are fully contained within. Thus, the head is round and the feet square, mirroring the Two Modes; the nose protrudes and the mouth is recessed, resembling mountains and valleys. Flesh and skin connect like soil and earth, blood and vessels link like rivers and streams; warmth and steam resemble scorching fire, breath and qi differ not from wind and clouds. Inwardly observing these myriad forms, not a single thing is lacking—why must one gaze upward and downward, tread through court and countryside, before their perceptions are complete?

**[Exegesis]**
You deem yourself different from others, yet what others perceive differs not from what you perceive. Why so? You know things and their transformations, yet know not that you yourself remain unchanged. Merely wandering outward without inward observation—though moved by things, you lose yourself—this is the utmost extreme. Why then seek completeness in external wandering?

**[Annotation]** The *Lüling* and *Shidetang* editions read “tread through” for “tread and ascend.” Wang Lai notes: In the exegesis, the phrase “know things” is repeated; above “utmost” a “not” should be added. The *Explication of Script and Phonology* reads: *wā* (recessed) as *wūguā*; *zhēng* (steaming) as *zhèng*.

Thereupon Liezi never ventured forth for the rest of his life, deeming himself ignorant of wandering.

**[Annotation]**
Having heard the ultimate discourse, he abandoned his wanderings and observations. “Never ventured forth” does not mean secluding himself within doors and courtyards. The *Explication of Script and Phonology* reads: *nì* (conceal) as *nìlì*.

Huqiuzi said: “Is this not the perfection of wandering!”

**[Annotation]**
Earlier, he questioned Liezi’s discourse on wandering, yet had not discussed wandering to its perfection—hence this reiteration. The *Explication of Script and Phonology* reads: *nàn* (question) as *nǎidàn*; *chóng* (reiterate) as *zhùyòng*.

The perfect wandering knows not where it goes; the perfect observation knows not what it sees.

**[Annotation]**
Sufficient within himself, he knows not where he goes; turning his gaze inward, he knows not what he sees. All things wander, all things observe.

**[Annotation]**
Forgetting wandering, he thus encounters things and wanders; forgetting observation, he thus encounters things and observes. This is what I call wandering, this is what I call observation.

**[Annotation]**
What I affirm is, in truth, the affirmation of nothing. Wherever he goes, he remains unobstructed and without fixation—this is what I call wandering and observation. Thus it is said: “Is this not the perfection of wandering! The perfection of wandering!”

**[Exegesis]**
When the form goes nowhere and the eye fixes on nothing, then nothing is not seen and nothing is not wandered. Such wandering and observation—truly the perfection of wandering!

Long Shu said to Wen Zhi: The *Explication of Script and Phonology* reads: *Zhì* as *zhì*. Wen Zhi, a man of the Warring States period, once treated King Wei of Qi. Some say: a skilled physician of Song during the Spring and Autumn period, who cured King Wen of Qi by provoking his anger.

“Your art is subtle indeed. I suffer from an affliction—can you cure it?”

Wen Zhi replied: “As you command. Yet first, tell me the symptoms of your affliction.”

**[Exegesis]**
What Wen Zhi healed were but ailments of the viscera, bones, and flesh. What Long Shu spoke of was the heart that forgets form and transcends the vulgar—distinct from the common herd, he deemed it an affliction.

Long Shu said: “I do not take praise from my village as honor, nor censure from the state as disgrace; gain brings me no joy, loss no sorrow; I regard life as death.”

Seeing wealth as poverty;
seeing others as swine—
**[Annotation]** With equanimity in all directions, one regards the myriad things as devoid of preference or distinction, of nobility or baseness.
Seeing myself as another—
**[Annotation]** Forgetting self and other.

Dwelling in my household as in a wayside inn—
**[Annotation]** Not possessing one’s home.
Viewing my homeland as a land of barbarians—
**[Annotation]** The world as one.

All these manifold afflictions—
**[Textual Note]** The Northern Song edition reads “multitudes” (*shù*) instead of “afflictions” (*jí*); Wang’s edition follows it. Here, we adopt the reading from the *Zang* edition, the *Shide Tang* edition, and the Qin edition to emend.
**[Exegesis]** The *Exegesis and Phonology* notes: “All these manifold afflictions” was once rendered as “all these multitudes,” which is incorrect.

Neither rank nor reward can incentivize,
nor punishment nor threat coerce;
prosperity or decline, profit or harm cannot alter,
grief or joy cannot sway.

Thus, one cannot serve a lord,
associate with kin or friends,
govern wife and children,
or command servants and slaves.
**[Annotation]** What binds a person to external things is the heart’s attachment to beauty and aversion, the body’s sensitivity to benefit and harm. If one can unify the ten thousand differences into a single thread, how could one perceive any distinction between existence and non-existence? Therefore, even the Son of Heaven cannot make such a one his subject, the feudal lords cannot make him their friend, wives and children cannot claim his intimacy, and servants and slaves cannot grow familiar with him.

Tao Hongqing says: *gù* should be read as “thus.”
Yang Bojun notes: In the annotation, “the Son of Heaven cannot make such a one his subject,” the word *suǒ* (“that which”) appears to be superfluous. The *Four Exegeses* edition reads: “the feudal lords cannot make him their friend, wives and children cannot claim his intimacy, servants and slaves cannot grow familiar with him,” and the *suǒ* in each case seems to have been added later.

What affliction is this?
With what method could it be cured?

[Solution]

Zhuangzi says: “Praise does not spur him on, slander does not dishearten him; he has settled the distinction between inner and outer, discerned the boundary between honor and disgrace.” One who fastens upon the spirit and forgets the form—poverty and wealth, life and death, human and beast, self and other—are all but passing travelers; what difference is there? Now, if one employs the mind in this manner, then the Dao of ruler and minister, of friends, will be abandoned; the heart of love and hate, joy and anger, will be severed. By what method could this be cured?

Wenzi then instructed Long Shu to stand with his back to the light. *Shiwen* notes: *bèi* (“back”) is pronounced *pèi*. Wenzi himself stepped behind and faced the light to observe him. *Shiwen* reads: “Wenzi stepped behind and faced the light to observe him,” adding that versions inserting “from” or “self” below “Wenzi” are incorrect. After a while, he said: “Ah! I see your heart now: a space of a square inch, utterly empty. You are nearly a sage! Your heart has six apertures flowing freely, with one still unopened.” The annotation states: According to the old saying, the sage’s heart has seven apertures. Wang Chongmin notes: *Yulin* (sections 376, 401, and 724) all quote “flowing freely” as “freely flowing.” Now, those who take sagely wisdom as an affliction may do so for this reason! This is not something my shallow art can cure.

Here the *Exegesis* states: Standing with one’s back to the light is to revert to the concerns of the common and vulgar; facing the light to observe is to look up and measure the heart that reaches toward the supreme Dao. The emptiness of the square inch arises from clinging to the written word; the one aperture that remains unopened means that perfection is not yet complete. Now, if all seven apertures were freely flowing, would one still take the Dao of sagely wisdom as an affliction? This affliction is not something Wenzi’s shallow art can cure.

Qin Enfu remarks: The *Exegesis*’s “clinging to the written word” may be a corruption of the two characters *shì jìn* (“power exhausted”). Bo Jun notes: The *Exegesis*’s “look up and measure” should likely read “look up and fathom.”

That which arises without cause and yet is ever-generative is the Dao.
*Annotation*: To forget all cares and let things pass, whether in success or failure, is to be without fatal ground—this is the Dao of the sage.
*Exegesis*: The supreme Dao abides constantly, not dependent on external things. It arises from life and so lives on, and thus, though it may come to an end, it does not perish—this is constancy.
*Annotation*: Laozi says, “That which dies yet does not perish is longevity.” To grasp the principle of life’s continuity without losing the primal meeting of supreme good fortune—even when it comes to death—is the way by which the Dao of life abides constantly. This is the portion allotted to the worthy, not that which can be attained by forgetting all cares and obscurely attaining spontaneity in its fullness.
*Exegesis*: True constancy follows principle, moving with the transformations of life and death while never perishing—this is the constancy of the Dao.

*Shiwen* notes: *fèn* (“portion”) is read as *fú wèn* (“to inquire”).

That which arises from life and yet perishes is misfortune.
*Annotation*: To employ cunning in pursuit of self-preservation, to value the self and demean things, to turn from harm and seek profit, to be inwardly bound while outwardly driven—even if one comes to death, it is due to misfortune.
*Exegesis*: To covet life and lose the Dao is misfortune.

Some versions read “pursue self-preservation” as “bind the self.”

That which arises without cause and yet is ever-dying is also the Dao.
*Annotation*: To follow the principle of certain death and proceed to a place of certain death—this correspondence of fact and principle is also the natural Dao.
*Exegesis*: The common understanding of ritual and teaching is that one must part and come to death.

That which arises from death and so dies—though it may not yet have reached its end, it perishes of itself—is also constancy.
*Annotation*: To be constant in death, though one may not yet have reached the end, is to have already exhausted the principle of life—this too is the constancy of principle.
*Exegesis*: To cherish the body of life and death, to practice the teachings of life and death, and not to preserve the Dao—this the common take to be constancy.

In all versions, the character *yě* (“also”) is missing below “is also constancy”; here it is supplied following the Jifu edition.

That which arises from death and yet lives is good fortune.
*Annotation*: To violate principle and defy the natural order, to be due for death yet not yet reach it—this is mistaken life.
*Exegesis*: To dwell in the work of change and decline while moderating one’s desires is also to know the good fortune of life.

*Shiwen* reads: “That which arises from death and yet lives is misfortune,” noting that most versions lack the character *bù* (“not”). The text above seems incomplete in principle, so it has been added here.

Ren Dachun states: In the current text, the character *bù* (“not”) is missing below “lives.” Upon examination, there should be a *bù* below “lives.” The meaning of this passage is structured in parallel pairs: just as that which follows the Dao of life and dies is misfortune, so too is that which follows the Dao of death and lives also misfortune. Jing Shun’s explanation that there should be a *bù* below “lives” aligns perfectly with the parallel structure of this passage and should be taken as the definitive version.

Bo Jun notes: Yin’s and Ren’s interpretations may be debated; the explanation by Tao Hongqing below is smoother.

Thus, to live without employing [the Dao] is called the Dao; to employ the Dao and attain one’s end is called constancy.
*Annotation*: To employ the Dao of the sage is to accord with principle in life and death.
To die while employing [the Dao] is also called the Dao; to employ the Dao and attain death is also called constancy.
*Annotation*: To ride the principle of peril and harm to one’s own destruction is also the constancy of the Dao.
*Exegesis*: Not to employ cunning in pursuit of self-preservation is the Dao; to employ this Dao and reach one’s end is constancy. The common scholar employs his cunning to the point of death, taking this as the Dao of aiding others; to employ this Dao and reach death is also called constancy.

What the multitude delights in, the multitude takes as the Dao; what the multitude finds secure, the multitude takes as constancy. Thus, the Dao of transcendence and the Dao of the worldly realm share the same name but differ in substance.

Tao Hongqing states: “That which arises without cause and yet is ever-dying is also the Dao”—Zhang’s annotation reads: “To follow the principle of certain death and proceed to a place of certain death—this correspondence of fact and principle is also the natural Dao.” If this is so, then it is entirely indistinguishable from what is called “that which arises from death and so dies,” and its meaning is even more incongruous with the earlier “that which arises without cause and yet is ever-generative is the Dao.” “To live without employing [the Dao]” and “to die while employing [the Dao]”—*yòng* (“employ”) is also *yóu* (“cause”). From “to live without employing [the Dao]” onward, the four sentences do not differ in meaning from the text above. Moreover, having said “to employ the Dao and attain one’s end is called constancy,” to then say “to employ the Dao and attain death is also called constancy” is to equate “end” and “death,” which is not the style of this text. The passage is verbose in wording and obscure in meaning, easily leading to errors in transmission; after being tampered with by the unlearned, it has become the corrupted version we have today. After examining the intent of this text, I venture to correct its wording as follows, leaving it as a matter for further consideration:

That which arises without cause and yet is ever-generative is the Dao. It arises from life and so lives on, and thus, though it may come to an end, it does not perish—this is constancy. That which arises from life and yet perishes is misfortune. That which arises without cause and yet is ever-dying is the Dao. It arises from death and so dies, and thus, though it may not yet have reached its end, it perishes of itself—this is constancy. That which arises from death and yet lives is good fortune. To live while employing [the Dao] is also called the Dao; to employ the Dao and attain life is also called constancy. To die while employing [the Dao] is also called the Dao; to employ the Dao and attain death is also called constancy.

The "ever-generative without cause" and "ever-dying without cause" are described in the *Tianrui* chapter as: "That which does not live can give life to life; that which does not transform can bring about transformation"—this is what is called "self-generation and self-transformation." The "generative through employment" and "dying through employment" are described in the *Tianrui* chapter as: "That which lives cannot but live; that which transforms cannot but transform"—this is what is called "the workings of yin and yang, the succession of the four seasons."

The "generative through life" refers to the worthy and the sagely; the "dying through death" refers to Jie and Zhi. The "attaining life through employing the Dao" and "attaining death through employing the Dao" mean following the transformations and moving with them—this is what the subsequent text calls "the death of the common people."

The "generation and death without cause" and the "generation and death through employment" are both spoken of in terms of the Dao of Heaven, and thus are called the Dao. The "generation through life, death through death," and the "generation and death through employing the Dao" are all spoken of in terms of human affairs, and thus are called constancy.

When Ji Liang died, Yang Zhu gazed at his gate and sang.
**[Note]** Having fully followed the Dao of life and proceeding to death, there was nothing to mourn.
Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (487) quotes "sang" as "did not weep." The note "life-following" is written as "life-nature" in another version.
Bo Jun observes: The *Strategies of the Warring States* (*Wei Ce*) states: "The King of Wei wished to attack Handan. When Ji Liang heard of this, he turned back mid-journey, his clothes singed and unstraightened, his hair dusty and unwashed, to admonish the King of Liang," but it is unclear whether this is the same Ji Liang.

When Sui Wu died, Yang Zhu caressed his corpse and wept.
**[Note]** Having lived in misfortune and died, there was cause for grief.

The life of the common people, the death of the common people—some sing, some weep.
**[Note]** "Common people" refers to the masses. Not knowing why they live or why they die, their grief and joy lose their balance, and so they sing or weep.
**[Explanation]** Those who grasp the principle of complete life and return to their end are why the sage and worthy do not mourn. Those who lose their true nature, violate principle, and proceed to death are why the wise and worthy grieve. The singing and weeping of the common people at life and death are all the constant patterns of things—how could they know where it will lead?

**[Note]** In the text below "common people," the *Zang* edition includes the character "者."
**[Explanation]** The eye about to go blind first sees the tip of an autumn hair.
**[Explanation]** The vision of the elderly is far-reaching, but when they see what is near, it is blurred—this is the gradual onset of blindness.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Miao* (眇), *wang shao* cut. *Du* (睹), read as *du* (睹).

The ear about to go deaf first hears the flight of a gnat.
**[Explanation]** In Qin, mosquitoes are called *rui*. Those with ear ailments hear the sound of insects flying in their ears—this is the gradual onset of deafness.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Rui* (蚋), *er rui* cut.

The mouth about to lose its taste first distinguishes the waters of the Zi and the Sheng.
**[Note]** *Shuang* (爽) means deviation. The waters of the Zi and Sheng have different tastes; once mixed, they are difficult to distinguish.
**[Explanation]** *Yu ling* cut. Two water names in the land of Qi.
**[Four Explanations Edition]** Zhang’s note includes the character "者" after "爽" and "辩" after "难."
Qin Enfu notes: The character "渑" should precede the gloss "余陵切."
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Zi* (淄), read as *zi* (锱); *Sheng* (渑), read as *sheng* (乘). The Zi River emerges from Laiwu County in the Lu Commandery; the Sheng River flows west from the border of Qiancheng County in the Beihai Commandery to Shouguang County, where the two waters converge. The *Shuofu* chapter states: "When the Zi and Sheng waters mix, Yi Ya could taste them." *Bie* (别), *bei lie* cut, same below.
Bo Jun observes: The source of the Zi River is twenty-five *li* west of the abandoned county seat of Boshan, on the northern side of Yuanshan, flowing through Linzi Town and east of Guangrao County into the Xiaoqing River. The Sheng River flows northwest from outside the ancient Qi city in Linzi Town, passing southwest of Guangrao County and emptying into Mada Lake.

The nose about to be blocked first detects the scent of burning and decay.
**[Note]** Burning and decay have the qi of nodes—subtle and difficult to distinguish.

The body about to stiffen first hastens to run and flee.
**[Note]** *Jiang* (僵) means to fall. Like Yan Yuan knowing that Dongye’s driving of the horses would lead to a runaway—it is the same with human affairs.
**[Note]** In the *Four Explanations* edition, the character "之" appears after "人."
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Jiang* (僵), read as *jiang* (姜). *Ji* (亟), *qu li* cut. *Fangyan* states: "亟 means to receive." *Ben yi* (奔佚), read as *ben yi* (奔逸). *Pu* (仆), read as *fu* (赴).
Bo Jun observes: "亟 *receives*"—"receives" (*shou* 受) should be "loves" (*ai* 愛).

The mind about to be deluded first discerns right and wrong.
**[Note]** The eyes, ears, mouth, nose, body, and mind—these six constantly attain the Dao of harmony and cannot be altered or changed. Occupying an extreme position, none do not suddenly come to an end. Thus, the decay of things must first begin with fullness, and then proceed to loss. Reaching the peak and turning downward, extreme prosperity must decline—this is the natural principle.

Therefore, the sage dwells in the center and treads the path of harmony, seeing what the eyes see, hearing what the ears hear, following the body’s abilities, and yielding to the mind’s discernment. Thus, their wisdom encompasses all things, and they preserve their wholeness throughout life.
**[Explanation]** When the mouth loses its proper taste, it distinguishes other flavors; when the nose loses its sense of smell, it detects other scents; when the body is about to stiffen, it first hastens to run; when the mind is deluded about the Dao, it is due to right and wrong. Right and wrong thus become manifest, and the Dao is thereby lost.
**[Note]** In the phrase "cannot be altered or changed," the character *yu* (渝) appears as *ce* (侧) in the Northern Song edition and as *ce* (测) in the *Daozang* and *Shidetang* editions.
**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Yu* (渝), read as *yu* (俞). *Kang* (亢) is the same as *kang* (抗).

Thus, that which does not reach its limit does not return.

**[Annotation]** Only by reaching the ultimate limit does one return, thus keen perception and strong memory become the very resources of darkness, decline, and delusion.

**[Exegesis]** By relinquishing one’s habitual attachments, one ascends to the supreme Dao. Hence it is said: one who sees the tip of an autumn hair cannot perceive Mount Tai; one who hears the buzz of a mosquito cannot hear the crash of thunder. Thus *Zhuangzi* declares: “Obstruct the eyes of Li Zhu, and all under heaven become clear; cripple the fingers of Gongshu, and all under heaven become skillful.” To combine the teachings of Confucians and Mohists, to pride oneself on the wealth of right and wrong, to treasure the dregs of learning as ability—how can one return to the real? By what means can it be attained? Therefore, the *Yijing* states: “No thought, no action. Still and unmoving, yet responsive and penetrating.” This is how the sage earnestly pursues the supreme Dao.

**[Lu Deming’s Note]** The *Zhuangzi* passage cited in Lu’s exegesis is an abridged distillation of the essential meaning of the *Qieqie* chapter, not the original text.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Zao* (造), read as *qidao* (七到切). *Huan* (还), read as *xuan* (旋).

The marshes of Zheng’s fields teemed with worthies—**[Annotation]** those of virtue and power who remained hidden and silent. **[Phonetic Gloss]** *Puze* (圃泽), the marsh of Putian, located in Zhongmou County.

—while Dongli abounded in talent—**[Annotation]** those with administrative skill who participated in state governance. **[Exegesis]** Those who cultivate and exalt the Dao are worthy; those who study texts and scrutinize punishments are talented. **[Phonetic Gloss]** *Zhi* (治), read as *zhili* (直吏切).

Among the disciples of Puze was one named Bo Fengzi—*yi* (役) here meaning “disciple.” As he passed through Dongli, he encountered Deng Xi. **[Annotation]** Deng Xi was a persuasive and cunning scholar of Zheng, who wielded the doctrine of “two possibilities” with no equal in his time. He composed the *Bamboo Codes*, which Zichan adopted. **[Lu Wenchang’s Note]** The annotation’s “Bamboo Codes” appears as “Bamboo Punishments” in the *Zuozhuan*. **[Phonetic Gloss]** *Yan* (验), read as *ge* (戈). *Xi* (析), read as *xi* (锡).

Deng Xi turned to his followers and laughed, saying: “Dance for him.” **[Phonetic Gloss]** *Wei* (为), read as *yuwei* (于伪切). “What do you make of that one approaching?” **[Annotation]** Some in the world call mutual mockery “dancing and toying.” **[Zhu Junsheng’s Note]** *Wu* (舞) is a loan for *wu* (侮). **[Phonetic Gloss]** *Chao* (嘲), read as *zhangjiao* (张交切). *Diao* (调), read as *tudia* (徒吊切).

His followers replied: “We wish to know.” **[Annotation]** *Zhi* (知) here means “to hear.” **[Exegesis]** Deng Xi, self-satisfied among his companions, performed this to deceive and mock Bo Feng. **[Chen Bohjun’s Note]** The exegesis’s phrase “performed this to deceive and mock Bo Feng” may contain a miswritten character. **[Phonetic Gloss]** *Zhi* (知), one edition reads *ru* (如).

Deng Xi then asked Bo Fengzi: “Do you understand the meaning of *yangyang*?” **[Annotation]** The first *yang* is read in the fourth tone, the second in the third tone. **[Eight-character note in the Zang edition]** Reads: “First character, departing tone; second character, rising tone.” **[Exegesis]** Zhang Zhan: the first *yang* is pronounced *yang* (扬), the second *yang* (痒). **[Qin Enfu’s Note]** This passage does not appear in the current Zhang Zhan edition. **[Chen Bohjun’s Note]** The exegesis’s citation of the *yang-yang* pronunciation corresponds to the annotation’s “fourth tone, third tone” or “yuliang, yushang.” Lu’s claim that “this passage does not appear in the current Zhang Zhan edition” is incorrect. **[Phonetic Gloss]** *Yangyang* (养养), the first *yang* read as *yuliang* (余亮切), the second as the standard pronunciation.

“Those who are fed by others yet cannot nourish themselves belong to the class of dogs and swine. Those who nourish things and make them serve their own use demonstrate human capacity. To ensure that your followers are fed to satiety, clothed, and rested—this is the achievement of governance.”

**[Annotation]** This likens those who take themselves for governors to dogs and swine. “When the young and old gather in herds to become fodder for pens and kitchens,” Hong Yi remarks: *Ji* (藉) means “to spread as bedding.” The *Yi*’s *Da Guo* hexagram states: “They spread white couch-grass as bedding.” Ma Rong’s commentary: “That which lies beneath is called *ji* (藉).” The *Erya*’s “Release of Beasts” says: “The pig’s resting place is called *zeng* (橧).” Guo Pu’s commentary: “*Zeng* is the mat upon which it lies.” *Ru* (蓐) is synonymous with *ji* (藉).

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Zhang* (长), read as *zhang zhang* (张丈切). *Ji* (藉) originally written as *ji* (籍), read as *ce ji* (侧戟切). *Lao* (牢) refers to livestock pens or enclosures. *Ji* (籍) also denotes bamboo or wooden fences, or piercing. The *Zhou Li*’s “Turtle Catcher” says: “They fence fish, turtles, and clams in season.” The *Guo Yu* also states: “They net and trap fish.” *Zhuangzi* says: “They stand over the pigpen.” Li Yi comments: “*Lao* is the pigsty; *zha* (栅) is the wooden fence.” Though the characters differ, the meaning is the same. *Cuo* (簎) is pronounced *zha* (栅). *Pao* (庖) is pronounced *pao* (匏).

Qin Enfu notes: In the current *Zhuangzi* text, this reads “pen and whip” (*lao ce* 牢策). “How is this any different from the class of dogs and swine?”

Bo Fengzi did not respond.

**[Annotation]** Not that he could not respond, but he scorned the question and did not answer.

**[Exegesis]** He deemed him unworthy of discourse, as one fundamentally unfit for conversation.

**[Annotation]** The character *ji* (讥, “scorn”) in the *Shi De Tang* edition is written as *ji* (机, “opportunity”).

One of Bo Fengzi’s followers stepped out of turn and said:

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Cong* (从), read as *cai yong* (才用切).

“Has my lord never heard of the many skilled artisans in Qi and Lu?

**[Annotation]** *Ji* (机) means “skill.” There are many people of exceptional ability: some excel in earthworks and carpentry, some in metalwork and leathercraft, some in music, some in calligraphy and mathematics, some in military affairs, and some in ancestral rites. All talents are present, yet none hold positions of coordination, nor can they command one another.

**[Annotation]** When tasks are established, they cannot be universally applied; when skills are mastered, they cannot be universally combined. Those whose craft is specialized and whose wisdom is evenly matched cannot govern or restrain one another.

**[Annotation]** The character *bian* (遍, “universal”) in various editions is written as *pian* (偏, “partial”), which may be an error.

Yu Yue remarks: *Wei* (位) should be *li* (莅). *Li* means “to oversee.” It means there is no one to oversee them. The *Zhou Li*’s “Master of Ceremonies” states: “For all military and hunting expeditions where sacrifices are made to the earth and ancestral altars, they establish positions.” The commentary notes: “The old text writes *wei* (位) as *li* (莅),” showing that *wei* and *li* were interchangeable in ancient script.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Zhi* (智) is written as *zhi* (知), read as *zhi* (智). Below, infer the meaning. *Xiang* (相), read as *xi liang* (息亮切).

Yet those who hold positions lack knowledge, and those who command lack ability, while knowledge and ability are made to serve them.

**[Annotation]** Unable to know what the multitude knows, unable to do what the multitude can do—yet all talents are employed in their service. This is because they do not occupy the position of knowledge or ability, harboring no aversions or preferences, no “this” or “that,” and thus act with a mind of non-action.

Therefore, the clear-sighted see for them, the keen-eared hear for them, the wise plan for them, the brave fight for them, and they themselves remain without concern.

Xun Can said to Fu Gu and Xiahou Xuan: “While you live in this world, your fame and achievements surpass mine, but your understanding falls short.” Fu and Xiahou replied: “Success and fame depend on understanding. Who in the world has a weak foundation yet excels in minor matters?” Xun answered: “Success and fame depend on will, which is constrained by its own limitations. Thus, will and limitation are one and the same, and understanding alone cannot ensure success. I can make you esteemed, but I cannot necessarily ensure the success of your endeavors.”

**[Chen Bohjun’s Note]** The exchange between Xun Can and Fu Gu cited in Zhang’s commentary also appears in the *Records of the Three Kingdoms*’ “Biography of Xun Yu,” in the annotation quoting the *Jin Yang Qiu*, though the wording differs slightly. Here it reads: “Success and fame depend on will, which is constrained by its own limitations,” whereas there it reads: “Fame and success are encouraged by the constraints of will.” Thus, the character *bi* (弊, “constraint”) here is likely a corruption of *jiang* (奖, “encouragement”).

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Bing wei zhi wei* (并为之为), read as *yu wei* (于伪切). Below, infer the meaning.

“Excellent,” pronounced *hu* as in *hu bao* and *hū*. “Detestable,” pronounced *wu* as in *wu lu*. “Can,” pronounced *can* as in *qi han*. “Gu” is read *jia*. “Constrained,” pronounced *ju* as in *qu zu*. “Those who hold office are but tools I employ—why should you take pride in that?”

Deng Xi had no reply; he glared at his disciples and withdrew.

**[Chen Bohjun’s Note]** The *Four Explanations* edition includes a note here, absent in all other versions: “To task the many talents with governance, to employ the myriad things for use, to ensure that chickens and dogs, oxen and horses all find their proper place, and that scholars, farmers, artisans, and merchants each rest in their station—only one who embodies the Way can achieve this. How could you claim such things by your own doing? You see only the branches and not the root; you would pit the arm of a mantis against the wheel of a chariot—this is ignorance of measure. Deng Xi, skilled in disputation yet ashamed to be seen by his disciples, thus glared at them and departed.” The note’s “理析” may be a corruption of “理折.”

Gongyi Bo was renowned among the feudal lords for his strength. Tangxi Gong spoke of him to King Xuan of Zhou.

**[Phonetic Gloss]** *Gongyi* and *Tangxi* are surnames; both were worthy men of Zhou.

**[Chen Bohjun’s Note]** The *Outer Congeries of Sayings, Right Part I* in the *Han Feizi* records: “Tangxi Gong said to Marquis Zhao,” and in the *Wen Tian* chapter, “Tangxi Gong said to Master Han”—both refer to a different Tangxi Gong.

Wang prepared ritual gifts to summon him. Gongyi Bo arrived...

Observing his appearance, he was but a cowardly man. **[Note]** *Cowardly* means weak. The *Cang* edition omits the four characters “pronounced *nu luan* cut.” The *Shiwen* reads: *Cowardly* is pronounced *nuan*.

King Xuan, perplexed in his heart, doubted and asked: “How great is your strength?” The *Shiwen* reads: *You* is pronounced *ru*.

Gongyi Bo replied: “Your servant’s strength can break the leg of a spring katydid,” the *Shiwen* reads: *Break* is pronounced *zhe*. *Katydid* is pronounced *zhong*; another says it is a locust. *Leg* is pronounced *gu*. “And bear the wing of an autumn cicada.” **[Note]** *Bear* means to endure. Yu Yue says: *Bear* should be read as *kan*. The *Shuowen*, under the *ge* radical, states: “*Kan* means to pierce.” The leg of a spring katydid is slender, hence the word *break*—showing that he can snap it. The wing of an autumn cicada is thin, hence the word *kan*—showing that he can pierce it. *Bear* here is a loan character. The *Book of Documents* reads: “The Western Earl having *kan*-subdued Li.” The *Erya*’s *Shigu* commentary cites it as written *kan*, proof that these characters were interchangeable in antiquity. Zhang’s note says “*Bear* means to endure,” but then katydid legs could also be said to *bear*, which fails to capture the precision of the ancients’ language. Hu Huaichen says: *Endure* means to bear the weight. The ancients often used the cicada’s wing to denote the lightest of things. “To *bear* a cicada’s wing” means to support its weight.

The king changed countenance and said: “My strength can rend the hide of a rhinoceros or young buffalo and drag the tails of nine oxen.” The *Shide Tang* edition adds the character *zhe* after *strength*. The *Shiwen* reads: *Rend* may also be written as *fen*. *Young buffalo* is pronounced *zi*. *Drag* is pronounced *yi*. “Yet I still regret its weakness. You break the leg of a spring katydid and bear the wing of an autumn cicada, yet your strength is renowned throughout the world—why?” The *Shiwen* reads: *Regret* is pronounced *han*.

Gongyi Bo sighed deeply, withdrew from his mat, and said: “Excellent is the king’s question! Your servant dares to answer truthfully. Your servant’s teacher is one named Shangqiu Zi, whose strength is unmatched in the world, yet his kin do not know of it—because he has never employed his strength.” **[Note]** He governs things with the utmost suppleness; nothing opposes him, so his achievement is not manifest.

“I would die for him. He instructed your servant, saying: ‘If one wishes to see what others cannot see, one must observe what others do not peer at; if one wishes to obtain what others cannot obtain, one must cultivate what others do not practice.’” **[Note]** Others always attack what is difficult; I alone do what is easy. **[Explanation]** What the multitude does and sees are but the paths of profit and fame, the traces of action. What the multitude does not peer at or practice is where the man of the Dao roams. Thus, one who is unmatched in the world has no opposing force.

Wang Lai says: In the explanation, there should be a *not* before *peer*. The *Shiwen* reads: *Easy* is pronounced *yi*, the same below.

“Therefore, one who studies vision first sees a cartload of firewood; one who studies hearing first hears the tolling of a bell.” The *Shiwen* reads: *Cart* is pronounced *yu*. *Bell* is pronounced *zhong*.
