“For one who has ease within, there is no difficulty without.” **[Note]** The ancients said: One skilled in strength lifts the autumn down; one skilled in hearing perceives the thunderclap—this is what is meant. The *Shiwen* reads: *Thunderclap* is pronounced *ting*.

“With no difficulty without, one’s name does not leave one’s household.” **[Note]** The Dao’s ultimate achievement is mysterious, so one’s name is not proclaimed. **[Explanation]** A cartload of firewood is a nearby thing; the tolling of a bell is a great sound. What is easily heard and seen proceeds from near to far. One who is skilled in living first nurtures his spirit. When the spirit is whole, the achievement of non-action becomes manifest, and no external thing is not penetrated. Thus it is said: One who has ease within has no difficulty without. This is attained in the single mind and perfected in the single household, so outsiders do not know.

“Thus one’s name does not leave one’s household.” The Northern Song edition, *Cang* edition, Qin engraving of Lu Chongxuan’s edition, and Wang’s edition read *household*; the Jifu edition and *Shide Tang* edition read *household*. Qin Enfu says: Lu’s commentary also reads *household*. Wang Zhongmin says: The Northern Song edition’s *household* as *Dao* is nearly correct; Zhang’s note, “The Dao’s ultimate achievement is mysterious,” etc., proves this. **[Chen Bohjun’s Note]** Wang’s view seems unexamined. Zhang’s note, “The Dao’s ultimate achievement is mysterious,” precisely explains the principle of “not leaving one household,” and further states, “thus one’s name is not proclaimed.” “One’s name is not proclaimed” precisely explains the meaning of “not leaving one household.” “One’s name does not leave one’s household” directly follows the preceding “his kin do not know” and contrasts with the following “your servant’s name is heard among the feudal lords.” Its corruption to *Dao* was precisely due to Zhang’s note, “The Dao’s ultimate achievement is mysterious.” Now we follow the Jifu and *Shide Tang* editions to correct it. The *Shiwen* reads: One edition writes *one Dao*, but this does not extend the meaning.

“Now your servant’s name is heard among the feudal lords—this is your servant’s violation of his teacher’s teaching and the display of his ability.” **[Note]** He has not yet been able to prevent his name and traces from being manifest.

“Yet your servant’s name is not due to failing to bear his strength,” **[Note]** He still avoids boasting, thus able to attain renown. The *Cang* edition’s note reads *more* for *still*, and *attain this* for *attain renown*. “But to being able to employ his strength.” **[Note]** One who skillfully employs his strength does not employ his strength.

“Is this not better than failing to bear one’s strength?” **[Note]** Boasting of ability and displaying its use. **[Explanation]** Though I do not match my teacher’s concealment of his traces, how is this not better than bearing one’s ability and displaying oneself?

The one who unites with the Great Dao to transform the myriad things does so by virtue of his power. Thus Zhuangzi said: “Hiding a mountain in a marsh, concealing a boat in a ravine—one of great power could shoulder them away at midnight, yet the deluded would remain unaware.” Yet King Xuan mistook this for mere physical strength.

Wang Lai said: The explanation for *you* should include the two characters *yuyu* (“better than”).

Zhongshan Gongzi Mou was a worthy prince of the state of Wei. **[Note]** Gongzi Mou, son of Marquis Wen, composed four chapters, which were classified as Daoist. When Wei conquered Zhongshan, it enfeoffed the land to Mou, hence he was called Zhongshan Gongzi Mou. **[Explanation]** Gongzi Mou was the son of Marquis Wen, enfeoffed at Zhongshan, thus called Zhongshan Gongzi.

Sun Yirang said: The Zhongshan of Xianyu was first conquered by Wei when, in the seventeenth year of Marquis Wen, Yue Yang besieged it for three years before annexing it, granting the land to Zi Ji. Later, Ji was established as crown prince, and the second son, Zhi, was enfeoffed instead. After Zhongshan regained its independence, it was again conquered by Zhao in the fourth year of King Huiwen. Both events are recorded in the *Records of the Grand Historian* under the hereditary houses of Wei and Zhao, as well as in the biography of Yue Yi. The *Liezi*’s “Zhongni” chapter, the *Zhuangzi*’s “Rang Wang” chapter, the *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s “Shen Wei” chapter, and the *Huainanzi*’s “Dao Ying Xun” all refer to Wei’s Zhongshan Gongzi Mou. Gao You and Zhang Zhan both state that Wei conquered Zhongshan and enfeoffed it to Mou. However, Wei Mou was contemporaneous with Zhao’s Lord Pingyuan, Qin’s Wei Dan, and Fan Sui, by which time Zhongshan had long been under Zhao’s control—how could it still belong to Wei? Thus, Mou’s enfeoffment must not have been in Xianyu’s Zhongshan, and this is beyond doubt. Zhang Zhan further identified Mou as the son of Marquis Wen of Wei, conflating Mou with Zhi, which is particularly erroneous—Yang Liang had already expressed skepticism about this.

Bo Jun’s note: The *Han Shu*’s “Yi Wen Zhi” lists *Gongzi Mou* in four chapters under Daoist works.

Bo Jun’s further note: Qian Mu’s *Xian Qin Zhuzi Xinian Kaobian*’s “Wei Mou Kao” states: Later scholars suspect the *Liezi* to be a forgery by Zhang Zhan, yet passages like this one demonstrate profound and exceptional reasoning, likely derived from ancient texts or remnants of the four chapters, which Zhang could not have fabricated.

Shen Qinkan said: Zhang Zhan’s note reads, “Gongzi Mou, son of Marquis Wen.” By the time of Gongsun Long, over a hundred years had passed since Marquis Wen—he could not have been his son. The *Shiwen* notes: *Mou* is pronounced *mohou*.

He delighted in associating with worthy men and neglected state affairs. The *Shiwen* notes: *Delighted* is pronounced *hubaor*; *neglected* is pronounced *suilü*. He took pleasure in the company of the Zhao man Gongsun Long. **[Note]** Gongzi Mou and Gongsun Long appear to postdate Liezi, yet they are mentioned here—this may be a later interpolation to expand the text’s meaning. If such additions do not violate the work’s general principles and serve to clarify its ideas, what harm do they do? Passages like these are preserved without removal.

Bo Jun’s note: The *Han Shu*’s “Yi Wen Zhi” lists *Gongsun Longzi* in fourteen chapters under the School of Names. The present edition contains five chapters and two thousand characters, though some suspect it to be a later forgery.

The disciples of Yuezheng Ziyu laughed at him. The *Shiwen* notes: *Yu* is pronounced *she*.

Gongzi Mou said: “Why do you laugh at my delight in Gongsun Long?”

Ziyu said: “Gongsun Long’s character is such that his conduct follows no teacher. The *Shiwen* notes: *Conduct* is pronounced *hang*. He studies without companions. **[Note]** He does not model himself on the sages and worthies. He is glib and unprincipled. **[Note]** Though talented in debate, he does not accord with reason. The *Shiwen* notes: *Accord* is pronounced *zhong*. He is recklessly expansive and without a school. **[Note]** The teachings of Confucians, Mohists, Legalists, and Logicians are all jumbled together without a fixed school. The *Cang* edition and *Sijie* read *fixed school* as *a single fixed school*. The *Shiwen* notes: *Recklessly* is pronounced *man*; *expansive* is pronounced *yan*. He favors the strange and speaks absurdly. **[Note]** He loves the bizarre and makes baseless claims. He seeks to confuse men’s minds and subdue their speech, practicing this with Han Tan and the like.” **[Note]** Han Tan is a person’s name, who studied this art together with him.

Zhuangzi said: “In the state of Huan, Gongsun Long could overpower men’s speech but not win their hearts—he was confined to the realm of disputation.” **[Explanation]** His conduct did not follow a teacher; he studied alone without companions. Though eloquent, he did not accord with reason, and his Way was recklessly expansive without a foundation. His teachings could subdue men’s speech but not win their hearts.

Han Tan, as in Zhuangzi, is called Huan Tuan—both are names of persons, similar in sound. The note *Huan Guo* should follow the *Shiwen* and read *Huan Tuan*. *Confined* was originally written as *gu* (“solid”), but here it is corrected to *you* (“realm”) following the *Cang* edition. The *Shiwen* reads *guo* as *tuan*, noting: *Tan* is pronounced *bu’an*; *practiced* is pronounced *yi’er*. *Tuan* is pronounced *daduan*; *confined* is pronounced *you*.

Bo Jun’s note: *Tan* should not be pronounced *bu’an* (*bu’an* in *Guangyun* is *tugan*); the *bu* is likely an error. *Practiced* should not be pronounced *yi’er* (*yi’er* in *Guangyun* is *yangzhi*); the *ge* should be *yi* (both *yangzhi* and *yier* belong to the *yu* initial and *zhi* final).

Gongzi Mou’s expression changed as he said: “Why do you depict Gongsun Long’s faults in this way? Pray, let me hear the truth.”

Ziyu said: “I laugh at how Long deceived Kong Chuan.” 〔Annotation〕 Kong Chuan was Confucius’ grandson. The *Shiji* records him as Long’s disciple. *Deceived* means “to cheat.” The *Shiwen* notes: *Deceived* is pronounced *dai*; it means “to cheat.” The same applies below.

He spoke of “a master archer who can make the rear arrowhead strike the front nock,” with the *Shiwen* noting: *Arrowhead* is pronounced *zu* (as in *zuomu*). *Strike* is pronounced *zhong* (as in *dingzhong*); the same applies below and in the annotation. “The arrows follow one another in succession, each shaft linked to the next.” The *Shiwen* notes: *Linked* is pronounced *zhu* (as in *zhu*), the same as in the annotation. “The front arrow reaches the target without break or fall, while the nock of the rear arrow still holds the bowstring, appearing as one.” 〔Annotation〕 The arrows are connected without interruption; the front arrow hits the target, and the next arrow strikes the front one, so that what the latter joins still holds the bowstring, appearing as a single continuous object. The *Shiwen* notes: *Hits* is pronounced *zhuo* (as in *zhilüe*); the same applies below. *Target* is pronounced *peng*. *Again* is pronounced *fu* (as in *fuyou*); the same applies below. *Joins* is pronounced *cou* (as in *qidou*).

Kong Chuan was astonished. Long said: “This is not yet the most marvelous.” Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (745) includes the character *ji* (“ascend”) after *not yet*.

Among Feng Meng’s disciples was one named Hong Chao. The *Shiwen* notes: *Feng* is pronounced *peng* (as in *bojing*). Enraged at his wife, he sought to frighten her. He drew the *Wuhao* bow and the *Qiwei* arrows. 〔Annotation〕 *Wuhao* was the bow of the Yellow Emperor. *Qi* was a place known for fine arrows. *Wei* refers to the fletching. Wang Chongmin notes: Wang Yinzhi first treated *Qiwei* as a single term, arguing that both were names for arrow bamboo. His explanation states: “The *Fangyan* says: *Bo* is sometimes called *jianli* or *qi*. The *Zhupu* says, ‘□ is *bo* bamboo for arrows.’ If □ is *bo* bamboo called *qi*, then when used for archery, it is also called *qi*. The *Huainanzi*’s *Binglüe* chapter annotation says, ‘Qiwei bamboo is where arrows come from.’ The *Zhupu* cites *Huainanzi* and explains: *Qiyuan* is the land of *Wei*, as in the *Mao Shi*’s ‘Gazing upon that *Qi* bend, the green bamboo so lush.’ *Qi* is the name of a river in *Wei*; to place *Qi* before *Wei* is ungrammatical.” Wang’s view that *Wei* is not a place name is correct, but his claim that *Qi* is also a name for arrow bamboo is likely mistaken. If *Wuhao* is the finest bow, then *Qiwei* should likewise denote the finest arrows. *Bo* arrows differ from archery arrows—can *bo* arrows be considered the finest for archery? The *Huainanzi*’s *Binglüe* chapter reads “Qiwei bamboo”; if all are names for arrow bamboo, why does the *Guangya*’s *Shicao* section list only *junlu* and *□* as arrow bamboo, omitting *Qi*? The theory that *Qi* (or *Qiwei*) refers to arrow bamboo lacks ancient evidence, as Zhang Ji also noted. The *Zhupu* says: “□ is fine.” *Qi* here is simply the *Qiyuan* of *Wei*. *Qiwei* thus refers to the fine bamboo of *Qiyuan*. Arrows made from *Qiyuan*’s fine bamboo could match the strength of the *Wuhao* bow, crafted from mulberry and *zhe* wood. Moreover, if *Qiwei* were arrow bamboo and *jun* were also arrow bamboo, how could they not pair? Wang’s argument is overly rigid. As for *Qiwei*, the *Huainanzi*’s *Yuandao* chapter writes it as *Qiwei*, while the *Binglüe* chapter uses *Qiwei*—both are loan characters; the standard form should be *Qiwei*. The *Taiping Yulan* (745), citing the *Liezi*, also writes it as *Qiwei*. Further, the *Shiming* states: “The side of an arrow is called *yu* (‘fletching’); the people of Qi call it *wei*.” Zhang’s annotation—“*Wei* means fletching”—derives from this. The *Shiwen* notes: *Hao* is pronounced *hao* (as in *hugao*). *Qi* is pronounced *qi* (as in *qiji*). The *Shiji* says: “The bamboo of the state of Qi.” Jin Zhuo notes: “The gardens of Wei abound in bamboo and reeds.” He shot at her eye. The *Shiwen* notes: *Shot* is pronounced *she* (as in *shiyi*).

The arrow came to lodge in her pupil, yet her eyelids did not blink. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (350) cites “came” as “not yet,” matching the *Shiwen* edition. Further, the *Taiping Yulan* (745) renders the two characters “came to lodge” as simply “to.” It is likely that “came” is a superfluous interpolation, for “to” and “lodge” share the same meaning. The following line reads, “The arrow lodged in her pupil, yet her eyelids did not blink,” directly continuing this thought—thus the superfluity of “came” is evident. Bo Jun observes: Wang’s argument is not precise. The character “came” should follow the *Shiwen* as “tip.” The arrow’s tip refers to its point. The *Taiping Yulan* (350) cites it as “not yet,” which is a misprint of “tip.” The *Shiwen* reads “arrow’s tip,” noting: “Tip is written in one edition as ‘came.’” *Pupil* is pronounced *mou* (莫侯切). *Orbit* is pronounced *kuang* (匡). *Blink* was originally written as *qi* (), meaning the flickering of the eye, and so below. *Qi* () is pronounced *qia* (且洽切). Ren Dachun states: The *Leipian* gives both *blink* (睫) and *qi* () the pronunciation *she* (失涉切), describing the movement of the eye; thus in one edition, *blink* is also written as *qi* (). The *Records of the Grand Historian*, “Biography of Bian Que,” reads: “Dimly perceiving the flicker.” The *Suoyin* comments: “*Qi* () is *blink* (睫),” providing evidence for the interchangeability of *blink* and *qi*. The *Shiwen* also defines *blink* as the flickering of the eye. Consulting the *Leipian*, “flickering” refers to the rapid opening and closing of the eye. The *Hanfeizi*, “Illustrations of the Laozi,” records: “Hui Zi said to the Lord of Zhou, ‘If someone were to meet you and wink one eye at you, what would you do?’ The Lord replied, ‘I would surely kill him.’ Hui Zi said, ‘A blind man winks both eyes at you—why do you not kill him?’ The Lord said, ‘He cannot help but wink.’” The meaning of *qi* () here may serve as evidence for its definition as “flickering.” The arrow plunged into the earth, yet no dust rose.

[Annotation] The arrow’s momentum was so extreme that, though it struck, it was imperceptible—what is meant by “the tip of a strong crossbow cannot pierce Lu gauze.” The *Shiwen* writes “pierce” as “tear,” noting: *Plunged* is pronounced *zhui* (坠). *Crossbow* is pronounced *nu* (其两切). *Tear* is written in one edition as “pierce.” *Gauze* is pronounced *gao* (古老切).

“Could these be the words of a wise man?” *Shiwen* notes: *with* is pronounced *yu*.

Gongzi Mou said: “The words of the wise are inherently beyond the comprehension of the dull-witted.” [Annotation] This is said in jest to Ziyu.

The rear arrowhead strikes the front nock, the hook of the latter trailing behind the former. [Annotation] When the later shot follows the earlier, there is nothing it does not hit.

In recent times, there was a man who cast five dice, achieving a hundred *lu* in a hundred throws. People thought him possessed of some Dao, and reported this to Wang Yifu. Wang Yifu said: “There is nothing extraordinary here—he simply casts the later throw as he did the earlier one.” Yu Zisong, upon hearing this, remarked: “Lord Wang’s words unwittingly grasp the principle.” All these are of the same kind.

[Textual Note] The Wang edition writes *later shot* as *shot after shot*, *hundred throws* as *one who throws*, and *Song* for *Zong*. The present version follows the Northern Song edition and the *Zang* edition in emendation.

*Shiwen* notes: *cast* is pronounced *zhì* (直炙切).

An arrow pierces the pupil yet the socket does not blink—this is the full momentum of the arrow. [Annotation] One who can gauge the momentum of bow and arrow, the measure of near and far, will know whether it enters the target or not by the calibration of hand and mind, without fear of miscalculation. Now, if we suppose even the clumsiest archer blindly shoots toward the target’s limit, he must hit its extremity. When he hits its extremity, the arrow will not advance by a hair’s breadth. By blindly aiming for the limit, he adjusts depth according to distance.

Liu Daozhen said to Zhang Shuqi: “I once discussed this with Le Yanfu, who said: ‘This need not be the province of the worthy alone—even the archers of Confucius and Yan Hui must have known this.’” Zhan considered this a matter of form and function, the coarser aspect of principle. To grasp the Dao in part is to master it fully. As with Pao Ding wielding his blade or Carpenter Shi swinging his axe—these are partial attainments in a single craft, not feats requiring sages or worthies.

*Shiwen* notes: *measure* is pronounced *fèn* (符问切). *Miscalculation* is pronounced *cuō dié* (蹉绖). *Said* is pronounced *yǔ* (鱼据切).

Why do you doubt this?

[Solution]
When the rear of the draw-hook aligns behind the front, every shot is as the first—hence the eye sees them as one. When the socket does not blink, the arrow’s force expires at the eyelash, so no dust stirs on the ground; it does not fall because it strikes the lash. Ziyu’s “seeing them as one” means that from bowstring to target the arrows link unbroken like a single strand; his “hearing the arrow strike the pupil and drop” means the shot does not enter the eye. This interpretation fails to grasp the ultimate principle and wrongly accuses Gongsun Long of sophistry.

Yue Zheng Ziyu said: “You are a disciple of Long—how can you not gloss over his gaps?” *Shiwen* notes: *yan* is pronounced *yúqián* (于虔切). “I shall speak of his more glaring errors.”

[Annotation] *You* means “extreme.”

Long deceived the King of Wei, saying: “Intention arises without mind.”
[Annotation] Mind is quiescent, without thought. If wayward intentions and concerns arise, one loses the root of mind.
[Solution] What moves in the mind is called intention. The world recognizes intention but does not recognize mind.

“There is pointing, yet it does not reach.”
[Annotation] To seek arrival through pointing is to rely on the self to rectify things. Relying on the self to rectify things is to fall short of the limit. Only by forgetting what one relies on can both sides attain the mysterious.
Huizi said: “Pointing does not reach.”
[Solution] All pointing is not yet arrival. Arrival is without pointing.

“There is thing, yet it is not exhausted.”
[Annotation] Within the realm of coarse existence, there is always being; at the verge of exhaustion, the One always remains. The One remains undivided, and though one may wish to diminish it, principle does not permit exhaustion. Only by following without diminishing, by conforming without violating, do the towering majesty of Mount Tai and the vast expanse of primordial qi merge indistinctly into one.
Huizi said: “A one-foot staff, halved each day, will not be exhausted in ten thousand generations.”
[Solution] If it were exhausted, it would not be being. A one-foot staff, halved each day, will not be exhausted in ten thousand generations because, though divided many times, it becomes minute yet principle does not allow it to be exhausted.
[Annotation] *Chui* in the Northern Song edition is written as *jìng*; in the Shide Tang edition, as *shén*.

“There is shadow, yet it does not move.”
[Annotation] Shadow arises from light. If light does not move, shadow is newly generated. All things change imperceptibly, and none is different. The deluded have not awakened, so the analogy of shadow is used.
Huizi said: “The shadow of a flying bird never moves.”
[Solution] Movement changes shadow. New shadows follow in succession, so no movement is perceived.
[Annotation] *Weichang* in Wang’s edition is written as *weiyi*; here corrected according to the Zang edition. The character *bu* in “light does not move” is likely an interpolation.
*Shiwen* notes: *jie* is pronounced *ziyi* (子亦切).

“A single hair can draw a thousand jun.”
[Annotation] What causes things to break is always an uneven point. Where every point is even, nothing can break. Thus a hair, though fine, can balance a heavy weight because its force is perfectly even.
[Solution] Fine as it is, a hair can lift a thousand jun—just as the weight of many hairs can break an axle yet remain light.
Bo Jun notes: The *Mozi Jingxia* states: “Evenness does not break—explanation lies in evenness.”

“A white horse is not a horse.”
[Annotation] This argument has many debaters. All debaters lack broad understanding, so it is omitted here without discussion.
[Solution] “White” names color; “horse” names form. “A white horse is not a horse” debates form and color.
[Annotation] *Jianzai* in the original edition is written as *jiancun*; in the Zang edition, as *jianzai*.
*Liezi Jishi*, Juan Five, “Tang Wen Di”

〔Annotation〕What wisdom limits as knowable is nothing compared to what it does not know; yet the world equalizes its own perceptions to limit all things. Thus the great sages pose questions, and those who exhaust principles respond.

〔Solution〕The nature of the myriad things each prizes its own life, yet they do not know how to nurture what sustains their life, instead loving the body to the point of losing their life. Therefore, this chapter discards form to preserve life and thereby penetrate their nature; when nature is penetrated, the disposition is reached, and when the disposition is reached, the Dao is realized.
Qin Enfu notes: Lu’s explanation of the character *zhu* in “sustains their life” is likely erroneous.
*Shiwen* states: *Qi* is read as *caixi*.

Yin Tang asked Xia Ge—
〔Annotation〕*Ge* is pronounced *ji* in the *Zhuangzi*.
Guo Qingfan notes: *Ge* and *ji* were homophonous and interchangeable in antiquity. The *Analects* records “Ji Zicheng,” while the *Han Shu: Guren Biao* writes “Ge Zicheng.” The *Book of Songs* says, “Not thorny are their desires,” which the *Li: Fangji* quotes as “Not *ge*-like are their intentions.” The *Han Shu* mentions “Zhuzao Hou Ge Zhu,” and the *Shiji Suoyin* notes, “*Ge* is pronounced *ji*,” all serving as evidence.
*Shiwen* states: Yin Tang’s surname was Zi, given name Lü, courtesy name Tianyi. *Ge* is pronounced *ji*. Xia Ji’s courtesy name was Ziji, and he served as Tang’s minister.
Bo Jun notes: The *Shiwen*’s “Xia Ji” is likely an error for “Xia Ge.”

—“Did things exist in the earliest antiquity?”
〔Annotation〕Perhaps only a vast, indistinct chaos.
*Shiwen* states: *Mang* is pronounced *mang*.

Xia Ge replied: “In the earliest antiquity, there were no things—how could there be things now?
〔Annotation〕That there are things now is because there were things in antiquity.
Lu Wenchang notes: The Zang edition includes the character *zhi* after “now” and “antiquity,” and *ye* after “therefore.”
*Shiwen* states: *Wu* is pronounced *wu*, the same below.

Would later people be justified in saying there are no things now?”
〔Annotation〕Later generations will surely take the present as antiquity, for antiquity and the present are like a cycle. If later people were to claim there are no things now, it would be untenable.
The *Lushi Qianji* 2 includes the character *shi* before “later.”
*Shiwen* states: *Fu* is read as *fuyou*, the same below.

Yin Tang said: “Then are there no before and after among things?”
Xia Ge replied: “The end and beginning of things have no ultimate limit. What begins may become an end, and what ends may become a beginning—how can one know their order?
〔Annotation〕What is now called an end may be the beginning of something; what is called a beginning may be the end of something. End and beginning follow one another in an unbroken cycle, making them ultimately indistinguishable.
Jiang Yougao notes: *Shi*, *yi*, *ji* rhyme, all belonging to the ancient *zhi* rhyme group.

Yet beyond things and before events, I do not know.”
〔Annotation〕Beyond things and before events, there is only vast emptiness, leaving nothing to point to or speak of.

〔Solution〕If later generations must take today as antiquity, how is it different from today’s inquiry into antiquity? How could there be no things? From Tang’s perspective, antiquity lies before, yet the beginning of things and the origin of events alternate in sequence—this cannot be known.

Yin Tang asked: “Then do the eight directions above and below have limits or boundaries?”
〔Annotation〕Though Tang and Ge exchanged answers, their perceptions and hearing remained unclear, so Tang posed this question again to achieve complete clarity.
Wang Shumin notes: The *Shiwen* edition of the annotation has *hua* instead of *jin*; this is likely correct. The *Zhuangzi: Gengsang Chu* chapter’s “those of its ministers who were *huaran*-knowing departed” is the source of these two characters. *Jin* is probably a graphical error for *hua*, or a corruption influenced by the character *jin* in the main text.
*Shiwen* states: *Chong* is read as *zhuyong*, the same below. *Hua* is pronounced *huo*; one edition has *jin*.

Ge replied: “I do not know.”
〔Annotation〕It is not that he does not know, but that it cannot be known through wisdom.
Tang pressed the question.
Ge said: “If there is nothing, then there is no limit; if there is something, then there is a boundary—how could I know this?
〔Annotation〕To exhaust the limitless and bound the limited is to reason from the unknown by analogy.
Tao Hongqing notes: The character *you* below “if there is something” should also be *wu*. “If there is something, then there is no boundary” aligns with Gongsun Long’s “there are things that are inexhaustible,” Hui Shi’s “a one-foot stick, halved each day, will never be exhausted in ten thousand generations,” and the Western notion of “the indestructibility of matter.” The following passage, “Beyond the limitless there is no further limitless; within the boundless there is no further boundless,” develops this idea. The current text’s error of *you jin* (“there is a boundary”) contradicts its intent. Zhang’s annotation, as given, clearly refers to the absence of limitlessness and the presence of boundlessness, indicating that his edition correctly read *wu jin* (“there is no boundary”).

Yet beyond the limitless there is no further limitless; within the boundless there is no further boundless.
〔Annotation〕If it is called limitless, how can there be anything beyond it? If it is called boundless, how can there be anything within it? What is called “no limitless” and “no boundless” is truly limitless and boundless.
The Northern Song edition of the annotation reads “if it is called emptiness” instead of “if it is called boundless”; Wang’s edition follows this, but the current text adopts the Zang edition’s correction.

Beyond the limitless there is no further limitless; within the boundless there is no further boundless.
〔Annotation〕Some might suppose that beyond the limitless there is another limitless, or that within the boundless there is another boundless. Therefore, it is reiterated that beyond the limitless there is no further limitless, and within the boundless there is no further boundless.

From this I know that it is limitless and boundless, but I do not know that it has limits or boundaries.”
〔Annotation〕To know the limitless is to know everything; not to know the limited is true knowledge.

Tang further asked: “What exists beyond the four seas?”
Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* 2 includes the character *hu* after “exists.”

Ge said, “It is like the Central State.”
〔Annotation〕*Qi* means “center.”
〔Exegesis〕How could the boundless have limits or ends? Thus the Dao pervades all without exception—this is what “nothingness” signifies. Both its essence and function are vast, neither void nor unreal.

Bo Jun notes: *Qizhou* refers to the Middle Kingdom. The *King Mu of Zhou* chapter states, “The central region among the four seas is called the Central State,” which serves as evidence. The *Exegesis on the Text* notes: The *Erya* says, “South of the central region, where the sun is overhead, is called Danxue; north of it, where the Dipper is overhead, is called Kongtong.” *Ju* means “distance,” and *qi* means “center.”

Tang said, “How do you substantiate this?”
Bo Jun notes: The *Huainanzi*’s *Spirit and Light* chapter states, “The multitude regards it as empty words, but I will cite examples to substantiate it.” Gao You’s commentary explains, “*Shi* means ‘to clarify.’” The *Book of Later Han*’s *Annals of Emperor Shun* records, “The edict ordered the inspectors of You, Bing, and Liang provinces to verify and assess officials from *ershiqian shi* down to those with yellow seals, as well as those who were aged, weak, or unfit for military service.” The commentary explains, “*Shi* means ‘to verify,’” both of which elucidate the meaning of *shi* here.

Ge said, “When I traveled east to Ying,
〔Exegesis on the Text〕Today’s Liucheng was ancient Yingzhou; traveling east to the sea confirms this.
the people were the same as here.
〔Annotation〕Just like this region. If one asks about the lands east of Ying, they are still like Ying.
When I traveled west to Bin,
〔Exegesis on the Text〕*You* is interchangeable with *Bin*.
the people were the same as here. If one asks about the lands west of Bin, they are still like Bin. From this I know that the Four Seas, the Four Wastes, and the Four Poles are no different from this.
〔Annotation〕The meanings of the Four Seas, Four Wastes, and Four Poles are found in the *Erya*. Knowing they are no different from this region confirms that this is the standard.
〔Exegesis〕The four directions cannot be exhausted, for all contain birth and death, love and hate, parents and children, wives and sons. Thus, I know that beyond the Four Wastes and Four Poles, it is no different from within Ying and Bin—this is the standard.

Wang Chongmin notes: Below “之,” the original text likely included “外,” which is now missing. The previous question by Tang asked, “What exists beyond the four seas?” This is Ge’s answer, so it should read “beyond the Four Seas, Four Wastes, and Four Poles.” The *Taiping Yulan* indeed includes “外” after “之.”
Bo Jun notes: Wang’s argument is sound. Lu Chongxuan’s exegesis also suggests his edition included “外.”
〔Exegesis on the Text〕The *Erya* states: The Nine Yi, Eight Di, Seven Rong, and Six Man are called the Four Seas. Guzhu, Beihu, Xiwangmu, and Rixia are called the Four Wastes. Dong Taiyuan, Xi Binguo, Nan Pujian, and Bei Zhuli are called the Four Poles. *Jian* is pronounced *xianbian*.

Bo Jun notes: In the *Exegesis on the Text*, “Taiyuan” may appear as “Qinyuan,” “Binguo” as “Jiaoguo,” and “Bei Zhuli” as “Ci Zhuli,” all of which are errors.

Thus, the great and small contain one another without end. That which contains the myriad things is like that which contains heaven and earth.
〔Annotation〕What contains the myriad things is heaven and earth; what encompasses heaven and earth is the Great Void.
〔Exegesis on the Text〕“Great Void” is written as *daxu*; *da* is pronounced *tai*, and the same applies below.
It contains the myriad things and thus is inexhaustible.
〔Annotation〕Heaven and earth contain transformations; yin and yang receive qi. The myriad things flow into form, succeeding one another without ceasing in one life or ending in one form—thus, it is inexhaustible.
It contains heaven and earth and thus is without limit.
〔Annotation〕Heaven and earth enclose the Three Luminaries and embrace the Four Seas—they are vast indeed. Yet as material forms, they must have limits. If one exhausts their limits, how could they not be void? Calculating that heaven and earth exist within the Great Void, they are as if present and as if absent. Thus, all within the realm of bounded space, whether large or small, numerous or few, are relative. Extending this to the ultimate of nothingness, how could it be exhausted by one heaven or bounded by one earth? Then heaven and earth and the myriad things mutually envelop one another, alternating as states and cities. How could one know their fullness or emptiness or measure their totality?

I also how do I know that beyond heaven and earth there are not greater heavens and earths?
〔Annotation〕The Great Void is boundless, while heaven and earth are limited. Encompassing the limited within the boundless, heaven and earth are not necessarily the greatest of forms. Thus, what Zou Yan spoke of was merely within his grasp.
〔Annotation〕In the *Shide Tang* edition, “掌” is written as “尝.”
〔Exegesis on the Text〕*Yan* is pronounced *yuqian*, and the same applies below.
This, too, is something I do not know.

〔Annotation〕All myriad affairs may be inferred by principle, yet cannot be verified by instruments. Thus, those who trust only what their minds and intellects can grasp, yet do not know that such knowledge has limits, possess but superficial understanding. Those who affirm only what their ears and eyes perceive, yet do not know that seeing and hearing have bounds, are common scholars. As for the penetrating person, they dissolve the obstructions of mind and intellect, mystically awakening to the wondrous principles beyond wisdom. They break through the barriers of sight and hearing, distantly attaining the marvelous forms beyond things.

As for those who confine their emotions and thoughts within bounded realms, who tread only within the six directions—such ones will claim that all records are exhausted by the *Three Tombs* and *Five Classics*, that the *Gui Cang* is fully contained within the four seas and nine provinces. Knowing the vastness of the Great Void, the boundlessness of the immense and minute, that heaven and earth are but a single dwelling and the myriad things but floating dust—all these are but narrow views of the present age, dimly perishing together.

Thus, Master Lie expounded the ultimate words of what has no inside, to smooth the obstructions of mind and intellect; he proclaimed the vast teachings of what has no outside, to open the barriers of sight and hearing. Thereby, those who aspire to the wind unconsciously release their self-importance, and those bound by doctrine unknowingly cast off their shackles.

Thus, he carved away the Confucians and Mohists, pointing out the great Dao—was this merely a fondness for the strange and a vain pursuit of the extraordinary? Alas! Lao Dan and Zhuang Zhou were already mocked by世论, how then could you alone escape such censure?

Here follows the translation:

---

The spiritual Dao embraces the myriad things, thus it is inexhaustible; yin and yang embrace heaven and earth, thus they are without limit. Beyond heaven, earth, and the myriad things lies what I cannot discern with reason—this does not mean I know nothing at all.

The annotation for "无垠" originally read "无限," but here it follows the *Shidetang* edition as "无垠." The *Shiwen* notes: "限" is rendered as "垠," and states, "The character '及' in '知及' appears in one version as '反,' which may be a textual error." *Huò* is pronounced *hūkuò*. *Yín* is read as *yín* (like "silver"), and the same applies below; one version writes it as *xiàn*. *Jū* is pronounced *jū*. *Zhìgù* is pronounced *zhìgǔ*. *Jiě* is pronounced *xiè*. *Kū* is pronounced *kū*. *Kuā* is read *kǒuhuā*. *Dān* is pronounced *tāgān*, the name of Laozi. *Zhōu* is the name of Zhuangzi.

Thus, heaven and earth are also things. Since things are insufficient, in ancient times Nüwa smelted the five-colored stones to mend their deficiencies.

**Annotation:** When yin and yang lose their measure, the Three Luminaries expand and contract—this is what causes the deficiencies of heaven and earth, not necessarily a flaw in their physical forms. Nüwa was a divine being, thus she could refine the essence of the Five Constants to harmonize yin and yang, ensuring the solar and stellar degrees followed their proper sequence, without needing to physically patch them with material objects.

**Exegesis:** Zhang Zhan’s annotation here is apt. Qin Enfu notes: "练" is the ancient form of "炼," and the *Huainanzi* also writes it as "练." He Xiou remarks: Zhang Zhan’s annotation, interpreting the five-colored stones as an allegory for the Five Constants, is but a clever turn of phrase. The philosophers of the Warring States often intermingled with the novelists, and not all can be scrutinized. Even in the *Liezi*, the tale of the Lord of Longbo fishing for the giant turtle, or the discourse on the transformed man’s robe—what do these parables truly signify? Wang Shumin observes: The *Yiwen Leiju* (6), *Taiping Yulan* (2 and 51) all include the character "之" before "石," making the syntax consistent with the following text; this should be adopted. The *Shiwen* states: *Wā* is pronounced *guā*; Nüwa was an ancient sovereign, of the Feng clan.

She broke the legs of the giant turtle—

**Annotation:** The *ao* is a colossal turtle. The *Shiwen* notes: *Duàn’áo* is pronounced *duàn’áo*, as explained later.

—to establish the Four Pillars. Later, Gonggong contested with Zhuanxu for the throne.

**Editor’s Note:** The *Records of the Three Sovereigns* in the *Shiji* states he fought with Zhu Rong, while the *Huainanzi*’s "Yuandao" chapter says he vied with Gaoxin for the throne, and the "Tianwen" chapter claims he contended with Zhuanxu—these are all variant traditions from antiquity. The *Shiwen* notes: Gonggong was an ancient emperor, *Gōng* pronounced *gōng*; *Zhuānxū* is pronounced *zhuānxū*.

Enraged, he struck Mount Buzhou—

**Annotation:** Gonggong rose to power between the eras of Fuxi and Shennong. His descendants, relying on their strength, later contested with Zhuanxu for the throne. Zhuanxu was a grandson of the Yellow Emperor. Mount Buzhou lies at the northwestern extreme. Lu Wenchang notes: In the annotation, after "Zhuanxu," the *Zang* edition includes the character "是," and after "Yellow Emperor," the character "之."

—snapping the pillar of heaven and severing the cords of earth. Thus, heaven tilted to the northwest, and the sun, moon, stars, and planets moved there. The *Shiwen* reads *Fú* as *fú*, noting: *Fú* is pronounced *fú*. *Xī* is pronounced *xǔyí*.

Earth was not full in the southeast, so the hundred rivers and floodwaters flowed there.

**Exegesis:** To disrupt the constant order and corrupt virtue is to break the pillar of heaven and sever the cords of earth. Therefore, the sage knows the heavenly Dao diminishes excess to supplement deficiency, so the Three Luminaries and the hundred rivers attain their great essentials. The *Shiwen* notes: *Lǎo* is pronounced *lǎo*.

Tang further asked: "Do things have greatness and smallness? Do they have length and brevity? Do they have sameness and difference?"

The *Ge* said: "East of the Bohai Sea, beyond countless millions of *li*, there lies a great abyss." The *Shiwen* notes: *Bóhǎi* refers to present-day Le’an Prefecture. The *Shan Hai Jing* states: "Beyond the Eastern Sea is a great abyss, truly a bottomless valley." The *Commentary* adds: This is recorded in the *Dahuang Jing*. The *Han Shenyun* of the *Book of Songs* says: "Flowing east into the bottomless valley." Below it lies no bottom. The *Commentary* explains: To call it bottomless is merely to express the extremity of its depth. The preceding line states there is no limit, no end that can be exhausted. Even if it were truly bottomless, there would be nothing to astonish. The *Commentary*’s final character *hài* ("astonish") appears as *hé* ("obstruct") in the Shide Tang edition.

It is called the *Guixu* (Returning Abyss). The *Commentary* cites *Zhuangzi*: "Weilü." Hong Yí notes: The *Li Shan* commentary on the *Wen Xuan*’s *Wu Du Fu* and the *Taiping Yulan*, fascicle 67, both cite *Liezi* as reading *Guītáng* ("Returning Pool"). The *Yan shi Jiaxun*’s *Guixin* chapter states: "The *Guītáng* and *Weilü*—where do the waters disperse?" This also matches certain alternate versions. Wang Chongmin observes: The *Taiping Yulan*, fascicles 60 and 67, both read *Guītáng*, matching the alternate version noted in the *Shiwen*. The *Shiwen* adds: *Guixu* appears in some versions as *Guītáng*.

The waters of the eight cords and nine fields, the flow of the Celestial Han, all pour into it without increase or decrease. The *Commentary* explains: The eight cords are the eight poles; the nine fields are the eight directions of heaven and its center. Tradition holds that the Milky Way connects with the sea. The *Exegesis* states: The bottomless great abyss signifies the inexhaustibility of the great Dao. That which is most subtle and fine, entering into the spaceless, is none other than water. Its lack of increase or decrease signifies that the ten thousand existents contain nothing it does not embrace. The *Shiwen* notes: *Hóng* is pronounced *hóng*.

Within it stand five mountains: the first is called Daiyu. The *Shiwen* notes: *Yú* is pronounced *yú*. The second is called Yuanqiao. The *Shiwen* notes: *Qiáo* is pronounced *qúmiào* (a mountain sharp and tall). The third is called Fanghu. The *Shiwen* notes: It is also called Fangzhang. The fourth is called Yingzhou. The *Shiwen* notes: *Yíng* is pronounced *yíng*. The fifth is called Penglai. The *Shiwen* notes: The *Records of the Grand Historian* states: Fangzhang, Yingzhou, and Penglai—these three divine mountains lie in the Bohai Sea. It is said that those who have reached them find all the immortals and the elixir of deathlessness there. From afar, they appear like clouds. When one draws near, they recede, and in the end, none can reach them.

The mountains rise and fall in a circuit of thirty thousand *li*. The *Shiwen* reads "circuit" as *zhōufàn*, noting: *fàn* is written in one version as the character for "pattern/model" and in another as the character for "circuit." Ren Dachun states: The *Records of Rites* reads, "Casting metal and combining earth." The *Xunzi*’s "Strong States" chapter reads, "The penal model is just." The *Taiyuan Jing* reads, "The ruler’s model for the state." The *Lishi*’s *Yang Zhuo Stele* reads, "Losing this teacher’s model." The *Fragmentary Stele of the Minister of Works* reads, "Receiving my molten model." Thus *fàn* often serves as a loan for *fàn* (the *Tongsu Wen* states: "Scale is called *fàn*," so *fàn* should be written as *fàn*). The *Feng Sheng Stele* reads, "Establishing the central diagram □," where □ is also the character for "model," and *fàn* is interchangeable with □. However, *fàn* as a loan for *fàn* (to violate) is rarely seen. Chen Changqi, Compiler of the Imperial Archives, states: The *Zhuangzi*’s "Great and Venerable Master" chapter reads, "Now, to mold a man’s form and say, ‘Man! Man!’—the Creator must deem this an inauspicious person." Here, "molding a man’s form" is equivalent to "modeling a man’s form," providing one instance where *fàn* and *fàn* are interchangeable. The flat summit of each mountain spans nine thousand *li*. The distance between the centers of these mountains is seventy thousand *li*, and thus they are neighbors.

Their towering terraces and pavilions are all of gold and jade, and the birds and beasts upon them are pure white. Tao Hongqing states: "The two characters *qí shàng* ('upon them') govern the following six clauses; the second *qí shàng* is an erroneous repetition." Wang Chongmin concurs: "Tao’s observation is correct." The *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (vol. 38) omits the second *qí shàng*. The *Exegesis* notes: *chún* is pronounced *chún*; *gǎo* is read as *gǔ-lǎo*.

The trees of pearl and jade grow in dense clusters. The *Exegesis* notes: *gān* is pronounced *gān*. Their blossoms and fruits all bear savor; to eat of them is to never age or die. Wang Chongmin observes: The *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (vol. 38) omits the second *jiē* ("all"), likely a superfluous interpolation.

The inhabitants are all of the lineage of immortals and sages; those who fly back and forth between them day and night are beyond counting.

**[Annotation]** The distance between two mountains is seventy thousand *li*, and among the five mountains, the total spans two hundred eighty thousand *li*. Yet they traverse this in a single day and night. The number of those who come and go cannot be reckoned, for even the swiftest wind and clouds cannot match their speed.

**[Exegesis]** Tangible things arise within the great Dao, adorned with playthings and delights, unaware of aging or death. Their movements and functions never cease, flitting to and fro in an instant—boundless in number. The Shide Hall edition does not repeat the phrase "come and go." In the line "cannot be reckoned," *bù* ("not") is written as *nǎi* ("thus") in the Northern Song edition. The *Exegesis* notes: *shù* ("number") is pronounced *sè-zhǔ*, and the annotation follows the same reading.

Yet the roots of the five mountains have no attachment,

**[Annotation]** Such mountains float upon the sea; by this reasoning, all realms of form are lodged within the great void, thus lacking any root or stem.

Lu Wenchang notes: The annotation omits the character *yú* ("upon") after *fú* ("float") in the Zang edition. The *Exegesis* writes *zhuó* as *zháo*, noting: *zháo* is pronounced *zhí-lüè*.

Ever rising and falling with the tides, the *Exegesis* notes: *shàng* ("rise") is pronounced *shí-zhǎng*, they cannot pause even for a moment.

**[Exegesis]** The five senses—eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body—drift with the waves and cannot rest even briefly. This illustrates how the world is swept along by sound, form, fragrance, and flavor, ceaselessly entangled, even to the point of forgetting life and scorning death in pursuit of fame and profit. They do not know how to still their thoughts, return to the source, nurture the spirit, and restore the Dao.

The *Exegesis* writes *zàn* ("briefly") as *zǎn*, noting: *zhì* ("pause") is pronounced *zhí-lǐ*.

The immortals and sages found this grievous, the *Exegesis* notes: *dú* means "to afflict," and appealed to the Emperor. The Emperor feared they would drift to the westernmost reaches, losing the abode of the assembled immortals and sages. Lu Wenchang notes: The Fang edition writes *kǒng* ("feared") as *nù* ("enraged"), and *qún xiān shèng* ("assembled immortals and sages") originally as *qún shèng* ("assembled sages"). The Zang edition has *xiān shèng* ("immortals and sages"), while the Sijie and Qin editions read *qún xiān shèng* ("assembled immortals and sages").

Yu Yue states: The Lu Chongxuan edition reads, "The Emperor feared they would drift to the westernmost reaches, losing the abode of the assembled immortals and sages," which should be followed. The five rooted mountains, having no attachment, would naturally drift to the westernmost reaches—what cause for anger would there be? The error likely arises from the following phrase, "the Emperor’s wrath." Moreover, the term *xiān shèng* ("immortals and sages") appears three times in the text, proving that *qún shèng* ("assembled sages") here is incorrect. The phrase *xī jí* ("westernmost reaches") is also suspect. If the five mountains rise and fall with the waves, how can one be certain they would drift only westward? The subsequent line, "Mounts Daiyu and Yuanqiao drifted to the northernmost reaches," confirms they need not drift solely westward. *Xī jí* ("westernmost reaches") should likely be *sì jí* ("four extremities").

Bo Jun notes: Yu’s argument is sound; the present text follows the Qin and Sijie editions, adding the character *xiān* ("immortals").

Wang Shumin states: The *Yiwen Leiju* (96), *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (931), and *Shiwen Leiju* (postface, 35) all include the character *shàng* ("Supreme") before *dì* ("Emperor"). The *Jinxiu Wanhua Gu* (supplement, 5) includes *tiān* ("Heaven") before the second *dì* ("Emperor"). The present text likely omits *shàng* or *tiān* before both instances of *dì*.

Thereupon, he commanded Yuqiang,

**[Annotation]** The *Classic of the Great Wilderness* states: This is the name of the god of the northernmost reaches, whose emissary is the sacred turtle. The *Exegesis* writes *Yúqiáng* as *Yúqiáng*, noting: *yú* is interchangeable with *yú* ("corner").

The *Biographies of Divine Immortals* states: The god of the north is named Yuqiang, styled Master of Dark Mystery.

The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: In the great wilderness there is a god with the face of a man and the body of a bird, named Yuqiang.

Jianwen notes: This is the sea god.

Ren Dachun states: The *Huainanzi*’s "Treatise on Terrain" reads, "*Yúqiáng* is where the *bùzhōu* winds arise," and Gao You’s commentary states: "*Yúqiáng* is a celestial deity."

The *Commentary on the Water Classic* states: The county is named Panyu, perhaps referring to the *yú* ("corner") of Mount Pan.

"*Pānshān zhī yú*" ("the *yú* of Mount Pan") is akin to "*Pānshān zhī yú*" ("the corner of Mount Pan").

The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: "The Eight Trees of Guilin lie east of *Pānyú*." Guo Pu’s commentary notes: "*Pānyú* is present-day Panyu County." Thus, *yú* and *yú* are interchangeable.

To have fifteen giant turtles lift their heads and bear them aloft.

**[Annotation]** The *Li Sao* states: "The giant turtles bear the mountains—how can they be at peace?" Bo Jun notes: The present *Chuci*’s *Heavenly Questions* reads: "The turtles bear the mountains and dance—how can they be at peace?" Wang Yi’s commentary cites the *Biographies of Divine Immortals*: "The giant spirit-turtle bears Mount Penglai and dances in the sea." Hong Xingzu’s supplementary commentary first cites this passage from the *Liezi*. The *Exegesis* notes: The *Biographies of Divine Immortals* states: "The giant turtles bear Mount Penglai and dance in the sea." The *Yuan Zhong Ji* states: "They are giant turtles."

They took turns in three shifts, the *Exegesis* notes: *fān* is pronounced *fān*, meaning "to alternate," with one rotation every sixty thousand years.

The five mountains first stood firm and unmoving.

**[Annotation]** For the corporeal form is the dwelling of the numinous spirit. If the five faculties drift and lose their proper governance, then immortals and sages will have no abode. *Zhuangzi* states: "Once it receives its completed form, it does not perish until its end." If the five faculties drift aimlessly, they will follow delusion to death. A life spent in vain—how lamentable! Thus the great sages established methods and teachings to restrain them, and the five faculties thereby found stability. The five dusts correspond to them, the five senses arise from them, hence the term "fifteen." Through the mind they are discerned, hence the term "three shifts." Every sixty thousand years they alternate—from this one understands the Dao of restraining the five faculties.

The *Tibetan*, *Qin*, and *Shidetang* editions omit the three characters "and unmoving." Wang Chongmin notes: The *Leiju* (96) and *Taiping Yulan* (803, 834) include these three characters, suggesting they were omitted in modern editions. Bo Jun notes: The *Wen Xuan* annotations to Zuo Taichong’s *Wu Du Fu*, Mu Xuanxu’s *Hai Fu*, *Taiping Yulan* (931), and Hong Xingzu’s supplementary commentary to the *Chuci*’s *Heavenly Questions* all include these three characters.

In the land of the Longbo, there were giants who, in fewer than several steps, reached the location of the five mountains. The *Northern Song* edition reads "several thousand," followed by Wang’s edition; the present text follows the *Tibetan* edition in emending this. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Northern Song* edition writes "thousand" for "steps," matching one variant noted in the *Exegesis*. The *Leiju* (96) cites it as "several tens of steps," which may be closer to the original. Likely, the *Northern Song* edition’s "thousand" is a corruption of "ten," with the following "steps" omitted. Bo Jun notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (931) and *Shiwen Leiju* (Later Collection, 35) both cite it as "several tens of steps." The *Exegesis* notes: *shu* is pronounced *se zhu*; *bu* ("steps") in one variant is written as *qian* ("thousand").

With a single hook, they caught six giant turtles.

The *Exegesis* notes: *diao* ("hook") in one variant is written as *he* ("join"); *qu* is pronounced *qu* ("to hasten").

They returned to their land and scorched the turtles’ bones to divine by them.

**[Annotation]** A mountain thirty thousand *li* in height and circumference is borne on the head of a single turtle, yet these six turtles were all drawn by a single hook. The people of Longbo could carry them all at once and even bore into their bones to calculate—such a person’s form must have spanned over a million *li*. Compared to them, the *kun* and *peng* are but mosquitoes, midges, fleas, and lice. Then what in the great void could not be contained?

**[Annotation]** *Bo* means "elder." The dragon, bearing the six emotions, seeks its own ease—how much more does it lose its proper governance through the might of its strength! This illustrates how, among the vulgar, desires for sensuality, pride, love, greed, indulgence, and craving stain and drown, yet they further destroy and employ them. Huang Sheng notes: Character dictionaries all define *ao* as a large turtle, but according to this text, *ao* refers to a turtle, not a large soft-shelled turtle. Qin Enfu notes: The commentary following "pride" appears to have omissions or errors. Wang Shumin notes: The *Chuxue Ji* (19), *Caotang Shijian* (35), and *Jinxiu Wanhua Gu* (Continuation, 5) all include the character *yin* ("thereupon") before *zhuo* ("scorch"). The *Exegesis* notes: *zhuo* is pronounced *zhuo*; *shu* is pronounced *su ju*; *suan* means "to calculate"; *zuan* is pronounced *xiang guan*; *kunpeng* is pronounced *kun peng*; *wenrui* is pronounced *wen rui*; *zaoshi* is pronounced *zao se*.

Thereupon, the two mountains Daiyu and Yuanqiao drifted to the Northern Ultimate and sank into the great sea, displacing countless immortals and sages.

**[Annotation]** What the vulgar heart drowns in is nothing heavier than sensuality and beauty; gentlemen and petty men alike are ensnared by fame and profit—hence it is said the two mountains flowed away. Love and drowning run deep, likened to the great sea. The drifting of spiritual awareness cannot be fully expressed.

The Lord was enraged.

**[Annotation]** *Ping* means "great." The *Exegesis* writes *ping* as *feng*, noting: *feng* is pronounced *fen*.

He diminished the land of Longbo and made it narrow. Wang Zhong notes: *E* ("narrow") and *ai* ("constricted") are interchangeable, a shift in pronunciation. The *Exegesis* writes *qin* ("diminish") as *jin*, noting: *jin* is pronounced *zi jin*, with one variant as *qin*; *e* is pronounced *wu mai*.

Ren Dachun notes: The *Records of the Grand Historian* ("Annals of Emperor Wu") states: "It encroached upon Mount Tai." The *Suoyin* commentary says: "*Qin xun* means *jin*." The *Huainanzi* ("Interpretation of Words") states: "At the beginning of yin and yang, all is harmonious and alike; as days lengthen their kind, they gradually encroach and grow distant"—meaning they begin alike but gradually diverge. The *Shiming* states: "When the eye’s flesh grows into the pupil, it is called *jin*; *jin* means *qin*. It also says *jin* means to gradually enlarge," thus *qin* and *jin* are interchangeable.

He shrank the people of Longbo to make them short. By the time of Fuxi and Shennong, the people of that land were still tens of *zhang* tall.

**[Annotation]** The *Shan Hai Jing* states: Beyond the Eastern Sea, in the great wilderness, there is a land of giants. The *Hetu Yuban* states: Nine hundred thousand *li* north of Kunlun lies the land of Longbo, where people are forty *zhang* tall and live eighteen thousand years before dying.

**[Annotation]** The great sages detested the harm caused by desires and thus established laws to restrain them. As the teachings of sages and wise ones spread, their land gradually shrank. Yet even under Shennong’s governance, they remained tens of *zhang* tall, for people cannot eliminate desires—only diminish them. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (377) includes the character *chang* ("tall") after *you* ("still"). The *Exegesis* writes "the people of that land" as "there were people of that land," and "tens of *zhang*" as "thousands of *zhang*," noting: "Thousands of *zhang*" in one variant is "tens of *zhang*."

Four hundred thousand *li* east of the Central States lies the land of the Jiao Yao. Wang Chongmin notes: "East" should be "west," a scribal error.

The "Huainanzi" in its "Dropping Form" chapter states: "To the southwest lies the land of the Jiao Yao." Wei Zhao’s commentary in the *Lu Yu* notes: "Jiao Yao is another name for the southwestern barbarians." Thus, in antiquity, some placed the Jiao Yao in the southwest. The *Taiping Yulan* (790), citing the *Map of Foreign Lands*, records: "The Jiao Yao lie thirty thousand *li* from Jiuyi," which would place them in the south. The *Exegesis*, quoting the *Comprehensive Geography*, states: "They are north of Da Qin." Since Da Qin lies in the southwest, this would place them in the west. Reconciling these accounts, the southwest is the most balanced location. Those who place them in the west or south likely differ only slightly in perspective. Yet no source places them in the east, confirming that "east" is indeed a scribal error. This passage records the extraordinary beings of the four directions: the Ming Ling of Jing’s south, the Kun and Peng of the northern wastes, the Zheng People of the northeast, and the Jiao Yao of the west. If "east" were correct, it would redundantly overlap with the Zheng People. Thus, "east" is a miswritten character, providing further evidence.

The *Taiping Yulan* (378 and 790) both write "four" as "three." It is likely that the original text of the *Liezi* read: "From the Central States, thirty thousand *li* to the west lies the land of the Jiao Yao." Later, the character "west" was mistakenly written as "four," leading to the erroneous insertion of "east" and the deletion of "three."

The *Exegesis* notes: "Jiao Yao is pronounced *Qiao Yao*; it is the name of a land of short people." The *Records of the Grand Historian* states: "The people of Jiao Yao are three *chi* tall, the shortest of all." Wei Zhao says: "Jiao Yao is another name for the southwestern barbarians." According to the *Comprehensive Geography*, they lie northwest of Da Qin, and their people are one *chi* and five *cun* tall.

**[Annotation]** This account appears in the *Poems Containing the Spirit’s Mist*.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Seen" is pronounced *xian* (rising tone), as below.

At the northeastern extreme live people called the Zheng People, nine *cun* tall.

**[Annotation]** See the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*.

The *Poems Containing the Spirit’s Mist* states: "At the northeastern extreme dwell such people." Having described the large, it proceeds to clarify the small. Qin Enfu notes: The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* writes "Zheng" as "Jing." Wang Chongmin says: The *Taiping Yulan* (378) writes "Zheng" as "Jing," which should be read as "Jing." The *Shuowen* states: "Jing: in one sense, it means 'minute.'" The *Classic of Mountains and Seas: Great Wilderness East* says: "Beyond the Eastern Sea, in the midst of the great wilderness, lies the land of the Small People, called the Jing People." Guo Pu’s commentary notes: "Jing is sometimes written as Jing." The *Exegesis* notes: "Zheng" is pronounced *zheng* (rising tone). The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: "Beyond the Eastern Sea dwell small people called the Zheng People."

South of Jing lies the Ming Ling.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Ming Ling is the name of a tree. It grows south of the Yangtze, marking spring by the sprouting of its leaves and autumn by their fall. It takes five hundred years as its spring and five hundred years as its autumn."

In high antiquity, there was the Great Chuen.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Chuen is pronounced *chun* (rising tone); it is the name of a tree, also called by this name. It takes eight thousand years as its spring and eight thousand years as its autumn."

Upon rotting soil grow fungi and zhi.

Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (945) writes "upon" as "soil."

The *Exegesis* notes: "Fungi" is pronounced *jun* (falling tone). Cui Zhuan says: "Zhi grow upon dung. They sprout at dawn and die by dusk." The *Jian Wen* states: "They suddenly sprout as zhi, living from dawn until dusk."

In the months of spring and summer, there are meng and rui.

Wang Shumin notes: The *Cloudy Satchel* (90) writes "in the months of spring and summer" as "in the clear sky."

The *Taiping Yulan* (945), the *Guangyun* (Upper Tone, 3), and the *Yunfu Qunyu* (9) all write "meng rui" as "mie meng."

The *Exegesis* notes: "Meng" is pronounced *meng* (falling tone). "Rui" is pronounced *rui* (falling tone), referring to the tiny flying insects known as mie meng, mosquitoes, and rui. These two are small flying creatures that arise with rain and perish upon exposure to sunlight.

**[Exegesis]** If one’s desires cause them to lose their true nature, then what difference is there between the gigantic and the minuscule, the long-lived and the short-lived? Thus, we know that from the highest immortals to the lowliest ants, those who stray from the true and lose the Dao, driven by their passions and desires, suffer the same loss.

North of the farthest north—

**[Annotation]** The *Zhuangzi* says "the barren north."

The Zang and Shide Tang editions write: "North of the farthest hairy north." Wang Zhong says: The *Zhuangzi* says "barren north" (*qiong fa*); *zhong* is a variant of *qiong*. Yu Yue says: The *Exegesis* notes that one edition omits the character "hairy," and this should be followed. "Farthest north" is the name of a land. Below, it states: "When Yu governed the waters and earth, he became lost and strayed into a land by the northern sea’s edge, a land called Farthest North." Thus, "north of the farthest north" means north of that land. The present insertion of "hairy" likely stems from later scholars adding it based on the *Zhuangzi*’s *Free and Easy Wandering*. They failed to realize that while the *Zhuangzi* speaks of "north of the barren north," this text speaks of "north of the farthest north," and the two are not the same. If one were to add it here, then saying both "north of the farthest hairy north" and "north of it" would be redundant.

The *Exegesis* writes "north of the farthest hairy north," noting: One edition writes "north of the farthest north."

—lies the Dark Sea.

The *Exegesis* notes: The *Record of the Ten Continents* states: "The Dark Sea is a celestial pool whose waters are black."

There is a fish there, thousands of *li* in breadth,

The *Exegesis* notes: "Breadth" is pronounced *guang* (falling tone), and "thousands" is pronounced *shu* (falling tone).

and its length matches its breadth.

Bo Jun notes: The *Artificers’ Record: Wheelwright* says "it is called *can chen*," with the commentary: "*Chen* means 'equal.'" Here, "matches" should be read with a departing tone.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Matches" is pronounced *chen* (falling tone), as below.

Its name is Kun.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Kun" refers to the whale.

There is also a bird there, named Peng.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Peng" is pronounced *peng* (rising tone).

Its wings resemble clouds hanging from the heavens, and its body matches its wings.

A note states: *Zhuangzi* says the Kun transforms into the Peng. How could the world know of such a being?

A note states: People amuse themselves with what they commonly see and grow accustomed to what they habitually hear; even if told of it, they would still disbelieve.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Told" is pronounced *yu* (rising tone).

Great Yu encountered it in his travels, Bo Yi knew of it and named it,

The *Exegesis* notes: "Named" is pronounced *ming* (falling tone), same as *mìng*.

and Yi Jian heard of it and recorded it.

A note states: Strange sights and extraordinary accounts are met with doubt by the multitude. Did Yu, Yi, and Jian merely fabricate fantastical tales to astonish their age? Rather, they clearly affirmed the existence of such beings to dispel the stubborn ignorance of those who cling to their narrow views and to remove the blindness and deafness of those who perceive the world. Though Yi Jian’s name is not widely known, he was one of the ancient masters of broad learning.

Bo Jun notes: The *Wen Xuan*’s *Western Metropolis Rhapsody* by Zhang Heng states, "Bo Yi could not name it, Li Shou could not record it,"—here, the meaning is inverted.

Lu Wenchao says: In the note, the *Zang* edition omits the character "之" after "众," and writes "禹" as "焉."

The *Exegesis* notes: "Recorded it" means "wrote it down."

Between the Yangtze and the Pu rivers, tiny creatures are born.

A note states: "Tiny" means small.

Wang Shumin says: The *Er Ya Yi* (vol. 26) cites "born" as "there are," and the *Shi Wen Lei Ju* (Later Collection, vol. 49) cites it as "on the sea there are insects." The current text’s "there are" (*you*) is written as "born" (*sheng*), which may be an error.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Tiny" is pronounced *yao* (falling tone). The *Character Dictionary* states: "*Yao* means small."

Its name is Jiao Ming.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Ming" is pronounced *ming* (rising tone).

They flock together and alight upon the eyelashes of mosquitoes without colliding.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Eyelashes" is pronounced *jie* (rising tone).

They roost and depart, yet the mosquito remains unaware.

Li Zhu and Zi Yu, in broad daylight, wiped their eyes, raised their brows, and gazed upon them,

The *Exegesis* notes: "Wiped" is pronounced *shi* (falling tone). "Brows" is pronounced *zi* (falling tone), referring to the corners of the eyes.

but could not perceive their form.

A note states: Li Zhu was a man of the Yellow Emperor’s time with keen eyesight, able to see the tip of an autumn hair from a hundred paces away. Zi Yu’s name is not recorded.

Yu Shi Kuang and Master Kuang, in the dead of night, pricked up their ears, lowered their heads, and listened,

The *Exegesis* notes: "Yu" is pronounced *chi* (falling tone). Both Yu Shi Kuang and Master Kuang were men of ancient times with acute hearing. "Pricked" is pronounced *ti* (falling tone). "Lowered" is pronounced *mian* (rising tone).

but could not hear their sound.

A note states: Yu Shi’s name is not recorded. Master Kuang lived in the time of Duke Ping of Jin; Xia Ge had no reason to mention him, so this must be a later embellishment by the compiler.

Those who rely on their minds, intelligence, ears, and eyes to see and hear cannot perceive the most minute of creatures.

Lu Wenchao says: In the note, the *Zang* edition includes the character "而" after "缘得."

Only the Yellow Emperor and Rong Chengzi dwelled upon the Kongtong,

Lu Wenchao says: The *Zang* edition writes "峒" as "桐."

Wang Shumin says: The *Yi Wen Lei Ju* (vol. 97) cites "Rong Chengzi" as "Guang Chengzi." The *Zhuangzi*’s "In the Human World" chapter also writes it as "Guang Chengzi."

The *Exegesis* notes: The *Records of the Grand Historian* states: The Yellow Emperor reached the river and ascended Mount Kongtong. It is now in Fengquan Prefecture.

They shared a chamber for three months, their minds stilled and their bodies abandoned.

A note states: This refers to the mind becoming like dead ashes and the body like withered wood.

Swiftly, they perceived with their spirit,

A note states: The spirit is a silent, profound illumination, not dependent on the eyes.

Wang Chongmin says: The *Lei Ju* (vol. 97) cites "swiftly" as "suddenly," which is correct. For "suddenly perceiving with the spirit" corresponds to "gradually hearing with qi" below.

Bo Jun notes: Wang’s interpretation is overly rigid; the original "swiftly" (*xu*) better suits the meaning.

They saw it as a solid mass, like the slopes of Mount Song;

A note states: To perceive the formless through the spirit is as if seeing Mount Song—yet even that is insufficient to describe its vastness.

Gradually, they heard with their qi,

A note states: Qi follows its natural course without relying on external means.

They heard it with a resounding crash,

The *Exegesis* notes: "Crash" is pronounced *peng* (rising tone).

like the sound of thunder.

A note states: To perceive sound through emptiness is as if hearing thunder—yet even that is insufficient to describe its magnitude.

An explanation states: If hindered by form and sound, then piled earth becomes a mountain, and swarming mosquitoes become thunder; to see it as a solid mass or hear it as a crash is hardly surprising.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Thunder" is pronounced *ting* (rising tone).

In the lands of Wu and Chu, there is a great tree called the *you*.

A note states: Pronounced *xiu* (falling tone).

The *Exegesis* notes: Pronounced *you* (falling tone). The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: "Jingshan has many orange and *you* trees." The *you* resembles the orange but is larger, with thick skin and a sour taste. Its jade-green tree bears fruit in winter, its cinnabar fruit tastes sour.

Wang Chongmin says: The character "" is the same as "柚" (*you*). "Bears" (*sheng*) should be "green" (*qing*), a scribal error.

The *Classic of Mountains* states: "Jingshan has many orange trees." Guo Pu’s commentary: "Resembles the orange but larger." The *Records of the Grand Historian*, in the "Biography of Sima Xiangru," states: "Oranges and *you* are fragrant." The *Correct Meaning* says: "The small is called *ju* (orange), the large *you*. The tree has thorns, does not wither in winter, and its leaves are green." Thus, the tree’s leaves are green and do not wither in winter, so the *Liezi* says, "Its jade-green tree remains green in winter." Here, "green" (*qing*) was likely corrupted into "主" and further miswritten as "bears" (*sheng*). The *Essential Techniques for the Common People* (vol. 10) cites it as "its jade-green tree remains green in winter," though it erroneously includes an extra "bears" (*sheng*), the "green" (*qing*) remains correct. The *Lei Ju* (vol. 87, mistakenly cited as "Lie Zhuan" instead of *Liezi*) and the *Imperial Digest* (vol. 973) both correctly cite it as "remains green in winter." "Jade-green tree, green in winter" and "cinnabar fruit, sour in taste" form a parallel structure. If written as "bears," the parallelism is lost.

Wang Shumin states: The *Jizuan Yuanhai* (vol. 92) also cites it as "green." Consuming its bark and juice cures qi-induced ailments. Xu Weiyu notes: Lüshi Chunqiu’s *Utmost Loyalty* commentary glosses "已" as "to heal." Wang Shumin adds: "厥" is a loan for "瘚." The *Shuowen* defines "瘚" as "reversed qi." The *Exegesis* reads: "愤" is pronounced *fèn* (房吻切). "愤厥之疾" refers to qi disorders.

The tree is prized in Qi; crossing the Huai northward, it transforms into the *zhi*. The *Exegesis* notes: The *Zhouli* states, "The orange crosses the Huai north and becomes the *zhi*." The myna does not cross the Ji River. The *Exegesis* reads: "Ji" is pronounced *jǐ* (子礼切); "鸲鹆" is pronounced *qúyù* (瞿浴). The *he* dies upon crossing the Wen. The *Exegesis* reads: "貉" is pronounced *hè* (鹤), resembling a fox, a sleep-loving beast; "汶" is pronounced *wén* (武巾切). Li Daoyuan’s *Shui Jing* states: The Ji River rises in Mount Wangwu as the Dui (pronounced *yǎn*) River, flows east through Wen to become the Ji, enters the Yellow River after ten *li*, then southward across the river to form Yingze, passing through nine commanderies including Jiyin before reaching the sea. The *Zhouli* states: "The myna does not cross the Ji; the *he* dies upon crossing the Wen—this is due to the land’s qi." Zheng Xuan notes: The Wen River lies north of Lu’s capital. Earlier scholars, following one another, mistakenly assumed this referred to Lu’s Wen River. However, according to the *Records of the Grand Historian*, "汶" and "" share the pronunciation *wén* (武巾切), denoting the Min River, not the *wèn*-pronounced Wen. The *Shan Hai Jing* states: The Great River issues from Mount Min. Guo Pu comments: It flows southeast through Shu Commandery, northeast through Badong and Jiangxia, then enters the sea at Guangling. The *Han Shi Waizhuan* states: "Of old, the Jiang River rose in Mount Min; at its source, it was but a cup’s depth." The *Chu Ci* also reads: "Hidden in the clear Jiang of Mount Min." This is conclusive. Moreover, the *Liezi* and *Zhouli* both speak of the differing natures of water and soil, such that relocation causes harm. Thus, the Four Rivers are cited as examples.

Now, Lu’s Wen River spans no more than a few dozen paces, its source no more than two hundred *li*. One could wade across it in moments—how could a fox or *he*, briefly crossing, face life and death so abruptly? The *Shuowen* states: "The *he* is a fox-like creature." All thrive on hills and dry land. Today, people along the Jiang say foxes do not cross the river. Clearly, crossing great waters harms their nature, even unto death. This is the land’s qi at work.

[Note] This principle is also found in the *Zhouguan*. The Qin edition reads: "This is the land’s qi at work."

Nevertheless, though their forms and qi differ, their natures are equal. Wang Shumin states: The *Exegesis* reads, "One edition adds '情' (emotion), rendering it '情性钧已' (emotions and natures are equal)." This is correct. "Emotions and natures are equal" parallels the earlier "forms and qi differ." The *Exegesis* notes: All punctuate at "已." One edition reads: "Emotions and natures are equal." They do not exchange with one another. All beings are whole; all parts are sufficient. The *Exegesis* reads: "分" is pronounced *fèn* (符问切).

"How can I discern their greatness or smallness? How can I know their length or brevity? How can I recognize their sameness or difference?"

[Note] Myriad beings, myriad forms, myriad natures, myriad emotions—each rests in its proper place, none failing to fulfill its role. Thus, their natures are equal and whole, with no desire for exchange. How could wisdom distinguish them?

[Exegesis] What is born of yin and yang, suited to the land, touched by spiritual qi, or altered by habit—all are thus. What need is there to debate it?

The Taihang and Wangwu Mountains—

[Note] "形" should be "行." Taihang lies in Heyang County, Henan; Wangwu in Dongyuan County, Hedong. Wang Chongmin states: The *Taiping Yulan* (vol. 40) cites "行" for "形," likely amended by the compiler. The *Exegesis* reads "太形" as "大形," glossing it as *tàxíng* (泰行), with the same note. "垣" is pronounced *yuán* (袁).

—span seven hundred *li* and rise ten thousand *ren*. Originally situated south of Jizhou and north of Heyang. The Foolish Old Man of North Mountain,

[Note] The common term "foolish" does not necessarily imply lack of wisdom.

aged nearly ninety, lived facing the mountains. Harassed by the mountains’ northern blockade and the circuitousness of his comings and goings,

[Exegesis] "形" is pronounced *xíng* (户刚反). "惩" means caution, trauma, or governance. The *Exegesis* notes: The *Han Shi Waizhuan* glosses "惩" as "suffering." "迂" is pronounced *yū* (于), as below.

he gathered his household to deliberate: "I propose we unite our strength to level the perilous terrain, opening a path south to Yuzhou and reaching the northern bank of the Han River. Is this feasible?" They all assented.

[Note] "杂" means "all." The *Exegesis* reads: "杂" is pronounced *zá* (七合切), as below; "佥" is pronounced *qiān* (七廉切).

His wife raised a doubt,

[Note] "献疑" means to pose a challenge. The *Exegesis* reads: "难" is pronounced *nàn* (乃旦切).

saying: "With your strength, you cannot even reduce the mound of Kuifu. What can you do to the Taihang and Wangwu?

[Note] Kuifu is a small hill in Chenliu. The *Taiping Yulan* cites the *Huainanzi*: "A puddle from an ox’s hoof holds no carp a foot long; the hill of Kuifu yields no timber for a hut—both are too narrow to contain greatness." The *Yiwen Leiju* (Mountains section) cites the *Huainanzi* with "魁父" as "□府." The original text reads "魁阜," differing in character but identical in sound. The *Exegesis* reads: "曾" is pronounced *céng* (层), as below. The *Huainanzi* writes "魁阜," meaning a small hill like a mound.

Where will you dispose of the earth and rocks?" They replied: "Dump them into the tail of the Bohai Sea, north of Yintu."

[Note] The *Huainanzi* states: "The northeasternmost land is called Yintu."

Liu Jiun's note: The current edition of the *Huainanzi*'s "Dixing Xun" reads, "In the northeast lies the land called Bohai; it is called Yintu." The character "得" in the annotation is likely a scribal error.

Thereupon, he led his descendants—three men capable of bearing loads—striking rocks and breaking earth, transporting the soil and stones with baskets to the tail of the Bohai Sea.

A widowed wife from the neighboring Jingcheng clan, who had a fatherless boy just coming of age, leapt forth to assist them.

Ren Dachun notes: The *Han Shu*'s "Annals of Emperor Gao" states, "The King of Han leapt forth." Jin Zhuo explains, "To leap forth is to act on one’s own initiative," as seen in the subsequent line, "Alone, he departed with Lord Teng through the Wang Gate of Chenggao." In this passage of the *Liezi*, which recounts Yu Gong’s removal of the mountains, none came to his aid, yet the fatherless boy alone rushed to help—hence the phrase "leapt forth to assist." The sense of "leapt forth" here aligns with Jin Zhuo’s gloss, mutually confirming its meaning.

Hong Yi notes: The *Han Shu*'s "Annals of Emperor Gao" reads, "The King of Han leapt forth." Ru Chun glosses, "Leapt is pronounced *tao* (逃), meaning to flee." The *Records of the Grand Historian* writes it as "fled." Jin Zhuo states, "To leap forth is to act on one’s own initiative." The *Biography of King Yan* in the *Han Shu* reads, "Thereupon, he leapt forth and galloped to Chang’an," also meaning to flee swiftly.

The *Exegesis* notes: "Leapt" is pronounced *tiao* (調), meaning to jump. Some write it as *tiao* (眺), which is incorrect.

Winter and summer alternated, and only then did they make a single return trip.

The River Bend Wise Old Man laughed and sought to dissuade him. {Note: Though commonly called wise, he was not necessarily free from folly.} He said, “How extreme is your lack of wisdom! With your waning years and remaining strength, you cannot even destroy a single blade of grass on the mountain—what then can you do with the earth and stones?”

The Old Fool of North Mountain sighed deeply and said, “Your heart is so obstinate that it cannot be penetrated. {Pei Jun notes: *Che* means ‘to penetrate.’ *Shiwen* reads: *che*, *chou lie* cut.} You are not even the equal of a widow or a weak child.
