He crafted endless arguments while Zichan held office and created the bamboo penal code.
**Annotation:** *Bamboo penal code* refers to laws inscribed on bamboo slips.
Lu Wenchong remarks: The annotation “bamboo penal code, laws on bamboo slips” should perhaps read “bamboo-slip penal code.” Bo Jun notes: Lu’s suggestion does not clarify Zhang’s intent; Zhang’s annotation likely explains *bamboo penal code* as *laws on bamboo slips*.

The state of Zheng adopted it, repeatedly challenging Zichan’s governance.
**Annotation:** *Shuo* is pronounced *shuo*. *Nan* is pronounced *nandan*.

Zichan was confounded by this. Zichan arrested and executed him, soon after putting him to death.
**Annotation:** This tradition states that Zichan executed Deng Xi, but the *Zuozhuan* records that Si Luan killed Deng Xi and adopted his bamboo penal code—Deng Xi died twenty years after Zichan’s death.
Bo Jun notes: The phrase “Zichan arrested and executed him” contains a superfluous repetition of “Zichan,” likely interpolated from the preceding text. “Executed him” and “put him to death” are redundant. It is suspected that *lu* (executed) should instead read *ju* (arrested). The *Taiping Yulan* (626) omits the eight characters “was confounded by this. Zichan arrested and executed him,” having excised them due to their incomprehensibility, which further confirms the error’s long-standing nature.
**Annotation:** *Lu* is pronounced *liu*, or written as [variant character]. *Luan* is pronounced *chuan*. *Zu* is pronounced *zilu*.

Thus, Zichan was not truly able to employ the bamboo penal code—he had no choice but to use it. Deng Xi was not truly able to humble Zichan—he had no choice but to submit. Zichan was not truly able to execute Deng Xi—he had no choice but to put him to death.

**Annotation:** The principle of this passage aligns with that of the preceding one.

**Explication:** To establish laws is a matter of power; to suffer execution is a matter of fate. To enforce those laws is also a matter of power; to put their author to death is also a matter of fate. To wield power in affairs is a matter of talent; for talent to go unrecognized is also a matter of fate. The Northern Song edition, Wang’s edition, and the Shidetang edition all omit the character *zhang* ("passage"); this follows the *Zang* edition’s addition.

Those who may live and do live—some accumulate virtue and practice benevolence, some encounter favorable times and prosper, gaining the world’s favor and fulfilling their own aspirations, as if by retribution, as though through wisdom and effort. The Shidetang edition’s annotation omits the character *ye* ("also") at the end. This is Heaven’s blessing. Some are simply born, simply at peace—this is not necessarily due to benevolence, virtue, or wisdom. Yet to walk the path of trust and compliance, to fulfill one’s aspirations, to live out one’s years without care or peril—what but Heaven’s blessing could account for this?

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Xing* (conduct) is pronounced *xia meng*.

Those who may die and do die—some accumulate evil and commit violence, some suffer hunger, cold, and destitution, thus scorning punishment and execution, forsaking survival, and meeting their end in death, as if self-inflicted, as though responding to circumstance. The *Zang* edition’s annotation reads *yi* ("with") for *yu* ("in"), while the Shidetang edition reads *er* ("and"). This, too, is Heaven’s blessing. Some simply die, simply meet their end—this is not necessarily due to cruelty or folly. Yet to indulge a cruel heart, to dwell in a state where survival is untenable, and to meet one’s end in death—such a death is a fitting death, and thus it, too, is called Heaven’s blessing.

**Explication:** To live when life is possible is Heaven’s blessing; to die when death is fitting is also Heaven’s blessing. For example, Yiwu sought life in the time of Duke Huan of Qi and secured his survival—this was truly Heaven’s blessing. Or consider Chu Ni, who dashed his head against a locust tree to meet his end, preserving his lord’s command and sparing a worthy man from harm, thus securing his death and an undying name—this, too, was Heaven’s blessing. The *Daozang Sijie* edition of the *Zang* reads *yi* ("with") for *yu* ("in") in the annotation “meeting their end in death.”

Those who may live but do not—dwelling in prosperity and ease, wishing for long life yet meeting an early end. This is Heaven’s punishment. To wish for life yet not attain it is called Heaven’s punishment.

Those who may die but do not—dwelling in hardship and humiliation, wishing not to live long yet enduring beyond death. The various editions omit the character *jiu* ("long") before *sheng* ("life"). This, too, is Heaven’s punishment. To scorn death yet not die is also Heaven’s punishment.

**Explication:** Dwelling in prosperity and ease, occupying a lofty position—this is to be able to live yet not live, as with Dong Xian and the like. Dwelling in hardship and humiliation, enduring suffering and adversity—this is to be able to die yet not die, as with the human swine and the like. To seek yet not attain—both are Heaven’s punishment.

There are those who may live or die and do live or die. There are those who may neither live nor die, yet some die and some live. **Annotation:** This refers to those who, in this circumstance, live and do live, or die and do die. The two preceding lines have already encompassed this meaning, and their repetition here is suspect; likely a textual error. Tao Hongqing said: The two *bu* ("not") characters are superfluous; the original text read, “Those who may live or die, some die and some live.” This speaks of those who may live yet die, or may die yet live. Zhang’s annotation states: “This refers to those who, in this circumstance, live yet die, or die yet live.” This suggests that the edition he consulted lacked the two *bu* characters. The preceding passage states, “Those who may live yet do not live suffer Heaven’s punishment; those who may die yet do not die suffer Heaven’s punishment”—its meaning aligns with this, hence Zhang’s annotation also suspects repetition.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Chong* (repetition) is pronounced *zhu yong*.

Yet life and death, life and death—neither due to things nor to the self—are all a matter of fate. There is nothing wisdom can do.

**Annotation:** Since the principle of life and death is unfathomable, death does not arise from things, nor does life reside in the self—how could wisdom avail?

**Explication:** Not due to things, nor due to the self; when knowledge cannot prevail and effort cannot succeed, only then may one submit to fate. The Yuan edition and the Shidetang edition’s annotation read *bi* ("must") for *ru* ("how") at the end.

Thus it is said: Profound and boundless, the Dao of Heaven converges of itself; vast and undifferentiated, the Dao of Heaven moves of itself.

**Annotation:** Boundless and undifferentiated—this is the ultimate of spontaneity. To converge and move of itself—how could it be compelled?

Jiang Yougao said: *Ji* (convergence) and *hui* (meeting) rhyme, both in the ancient *zhi* (*祭*) rhyme group. *Fen* (division) and *yun* (movement) rhyme, both in the ancient *wen* (*文*) rhyme group.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Fen* is pronounced *fu wen*; the annotation is the same.

Heaven and Earth cannot transgress it.

**Annotation:** Though Heaven and Earth are vast, they cannot defy spontaneity.

The sage and the wise cannot interfere with it.

**Annotation:** Though the sagely and the divine are wondrous, they cannot contravene the workings of time.

Ghosts and demons cannot deceive it.

**Annotation:** Though ghosts and demons are uncanny, they cannot falsify what is true and upright.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Mei* is written as *魅*; the annotation states: some write it as *媚*.

That which is spontaneous completes in silence.

**Annotation:** *Mo* means "without."

Levels and pacifies.

**Annotation:** To level and pacify requires no action.

Guides and welcomes.

**Annotation:** Without loss or ruin, it seems as though it guides and welcomes.

If one aligns with the Dao to fulfill destiny, Heaven and Earth cannot transgress it, the sagely and the wise cannot interfere with it; when operations accord with principle, responses to change are divine—even ghosts and demons cannot deceive it; how much less so human affairs?

**Annotation by Bo Jun:** *Cheng*, *ping*, and *ning* rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *geng* group; *jiang* and *ying* rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *yang* group.
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Sang* is pronounced *xi lang*.

A friend of Yang Zhu was named Ji Liang.
Ji Liang fell ill, and after seven days, his condition grew critical.
**Annotation:** *Jian* means "severe."
**Variant:** The Northern Song edition has *ji* ("illness") instead of *bing* ("disease").

His sons surrounded him, weeping, and begged for physicians.
**Annotation by Wang Chongmin:** The *Taiping Yulan* (738) includes a *ye* ("petition") after *qing* ("beg"), meaning to request of their father that physicians be summoned. The following line, "in the end, three physicians were petitioned," refers to this. Without *ye*, the meaning is unclear.
**Annotation by Wang Shumin:** The *Wen Xuan* annotation to Sun Zijing’s letter to Shi Zhongrong also includes *ye*.

Ji Liang said to Yang Zhu: "My sons are so unworthy—why do you not sing for me to enlighten them?"
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Wei* is pronounced *yu wei*.

Yang Zhu sang:
"Heaven does not recognize it—
how can man be aware?
Not by blessing from Heaven,
nor by misfortune from man.
Is it I? Is it you?
Do they not know?"

"Physicians or shamans—
do they truly know?"
**Annotation:** This means only you and I understand that life and death are fated; physicians and shamans cannot know this.

His sons did not comprehend and ultimately petitioned three physicians.
**Annotation:** They failed to grasp the meaning of Yang Zhu’s song, believing it aligned with their own views.
**Exegesis:** If even the mandate of Heaven cannot be discerned, how can man perceive it? Heaven does not bestow blessings selectively, nor does man err to invite misfortune—yet one falls ill: this is fate. If even you and I cannot know this, how could physicians or shamans? Furthermore, the song’s intent suggests: if you and I can endure this illness, and I cannot, then perhaps the shaman can.

**Qin Enfu’s note:** Lu’s exegesis under "song’s intent" contains omissions and errors.
**Jiang Chaobo’s note:** *Zhong* means "complete." The *Huainanzi*’s *Chuzhen Xun* states: "Wisdom encompasses Heaven and Earth." *Zhong* means "complete." Thus, "ultimately petitioned three physicians" means "petitioned all three physicians," not "in the end."

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Jie* is pronounced *xie*.
One was surnamed Jiao.
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Jiao* is pronounced *jiao* (rising tone).
The second was surnamed Yu, and the third was surnamed Lu. They examined his illness.
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Zhen* is pronounced *zhen* (rising tone), meaning to feel the pulse.

Physician Jiao said to Ji Liang: "Your cold and heat are imbalanced,
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Ru* is written as *nü* (same pronunciation as *ru* below).
your deficiency and excess lack measure, and your illness stems from irregular eating, sexual indulgence, and scattered essence and thought. It is neither Heaven’s doing nor a ghost’s."

The Northern Song edition, Wang edition, and Qin edition write "Heaven" as "premature death." While "premature death" may be borrowed for "portent," though plausible, judging by the subsequent text—"your illness stems neither from Heaven, nor from man, nor from ghosts"—the version with "Heaven" is more appropriate. Thus, we follow the *Zang* edition and Yuan edition as correct.

"Though chronic, it may yet be treated."

Ji Liang said, "A mediocre physician. Quickly dismiss him!"

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Ji* is pronounced *jí*. *Bing* is pronounced with a rising tone, meaning "to remove."

Physician Yu said, "At first, your prenatal *qi* was insufficient, while your postnatal milk was excessive.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Dòng* is pronounced *zhòng*, meaning "milk."

The illness did not arise in a single day or night; its cause has accumulated gradually and cannot be cured."

Ji Liang said, "A fine physician. Let him stay and be fed!"

**[Exegesis]:** The illness described by Physician Jiao stems from human failings, matters within one’s own power. The illness described by Physician Yu, however, arose with the body’s formation—*qi* was insufficient from the start and cannot be remedied.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Shí* is pronounced *sì*.

Physician Lu said, "Your illness stems neither from Heaven, nor from man, nor from ghosts. Upon receiving your form, there was already one who governed it, and one who knew it.

**[Annotation]:** The division of life and death, the span of long and short, are all determined by non-action, by the governance of Heavenly principle. Yet the ignorant are deluded by this, while those of profound insight comprehend it.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Fèn* is pronounced *fèn*.

What can medicine and stone do for you?"

Ji Liang said, "A divine physician! Bestow generous gifts and send him off!"

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Kuàng* is pronounced *kuàng*.

Soon after, Ji Liang’s illness resolved of its own accord.

**[Exegesis]:** The illness described by Physician Lu arose from the spirit. The spirit’s workings may yield merit or fault. The form is the vessel that repays the spirit, and the spirit governs it. Before receiving form, the spirit already knew it. If the spirit is insufficient, the form follows accordingly. Longevity or brevity, beauty or ugliness—one’s physical endowment is already fixed. How could medicine or stone cure this? Ji Liang regarded him as a divine physician. By cultivating the spirit and nurturing virtue, his illness healed itself.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Chōu* is pronounced *chōu*.

Life is not preserved by what is prized, nor is the body enriched by what is cherished. Life is not cut short by what is despised, nor is the body diminished by what is slighted. Thus, what is prized may not preserve life, and what is despised may not cause death; what is cherished may not enrich the body, and what is slighted may not diminish it. This appears contradictory, yet it is not—life and death, enrichment and diminution, proceed of their own accord. Or, what is prized may preserve life, and what is despised may cause death; what is cherished may enrich the body, and what is slighted may diminish it. This appears compliant, yet it is not—life and death, enrichment and diminution, likewise proceed of their own accord.

Yü Xiong addressed King Wen.

**[Annotation]:** Yü Xiong was King Wen’s teacher.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Yü* is pronounced *yù*. *Yǔ* is pronounced *yù*, the same below.

Yü said: "What is long is not lengthened by effort, and what is short is not shortened by harm. What then is lost by calculation?"

**[Annotation]:** *Suan* (算) here means "wisdom" or "discernment."

**[Interpretation]:** If one understands that the body’s recompense is as it is, then one will not be swayed by personal feelings. Personal feelings involve prizing and cherishing, despising and slighting. The body’s thickness or thinness does not follow the weight of such feelings—thus, what is gained may seem compliant, and what is attained may seem contradictory. Yet in truth, it is neither compliant nor contradictory, just as length and shortness, beauty and ugliness, are not altered by personal affection. They are beyond the reach of wisdom and calculation.

Qin Enfu notes: Lu’s interpretation of *baowei* (报为) may have an error in the character *wei* (为).

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Suan* (算) is pronounced *xiàn*. *Wang* (亡) is pronounced *wú*.

Laozi addressed Guan Yin, saying: "Who knows the reason for what Heaven detests?"

**[Annotation]:** Wang Bi said: "*Shu* (孰) means 'who.' Who can know the intent of Heaven? Only the sage."

Bo Jun notes: These two lines are from *Laozi*, Chapter 73. The present text of Wang Bi’s commentary reads: "*Shu* means 'who.' Who can know the reason for what Heaven detests? Only the sage, perhaps!" Zhang’s annotation quotes an abridged version.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *E* (恶) is pronounced *wù*.

To anticipate Heaven’s will and weigh profit and harm is not as good as following one’s own nature.

**[Annotation]:** One who follows the heavenly principle without contrivance cannot be violated by ghosts and spirits or disturbed by human affairs. But to anticipate Heaven’s will, calculate fortune and misfortune, embrace compliance to avoid opposition, and pursue profit while shunning harm—this merely sets one in great opposition to adversity and harm. It is the height of clever calculation, yet it cannot prevent the arising of good and ill fortune or the exhaustion of blessings and calamities.

**[Interpretation]:** Those who do not know the Dao—how could they know what Heaven loves or hates? To preempt Heaven’s will, weigh profit and harm, and act from personal feeling is to fail to follow principle and entrust oneself to fate. This chapter speaks of the inability of human effort to alter fate, and the unknowability of fate in advance. To entrust oneself to it is to lag behind the times; to strive against it is to defy fate. Thus it rebukes those who know the Dao yet cultivate spirit, nurture authenticity, initiate undertakings, and strive to turn fate to their will, contending with Heaven.

Qin Enfu notes: Lu’s interpretation under "knowing the Dao" may have an omission.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Chuai* (揣) is pronounced *chuǎi*. *Liao* (料) is pronounced *liáo*.

Yang Bu—

**[Annotation]:** Younger brother of Yang Zhu.

—asked: "Consider a man here: in age, he and his brother are alike; in speech, they are alike—Yu Yue said: The character *yan* (言) is meaningless and should follow the *Shiwen* in reading as *zī* (訾). The *Guanzi*’s *Jun Chen Shang* chapter states, 'Officials and stewards all have *zī cheng shi lü* (訾程事律),' which refers to this meaning of *zī*. Official ranks and social status must be measured by *zī cheng* (訾程). Thus, '*Zī* brothers' corresponds properly to the following 'nobility and baseness are like father and son.' Yin Jingshun did not grasp the meaning of *zī* and thought it should be the character for wealth, but then the following line should speak of poverty and wealth, not nobility and baseness."

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Yan* (言) in the *Shiwen* is written as *zī* (訾), pronounced *jī yí*; it should be the character for wealth. Another version writes *yan* (言).

—in talent, they are alike; in appearance, they are alike. Yet in longevity and early death, they are like father and son; in nobility and baseness, they are like father and son; in reputation, they are like father and son; in love and hatred, they are like father and son. I am perplexed by this."

**[Interpretation]:** Age, speech, talent, and appearance are similar, so they are called brothers. Longevity and early death, nobility and baseness are vastly different, so they are called father and son. This is the unknowability of fate, hence the perplexity.

Yangzi said: "The ancients had a saying I once learned and shall now tell you. What is so without reason for being so is fate.

**[Annotation]:** It is the principle of spontaneity, thus it cannot be known by wisdom.

Now, in darkness and obscurity, in confusion and disorder, one follows what is done and what is not done. Days pass and days come—who can know the reason? It is all fate."

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Mei* (昧) is pronounced *huì*.

Lu Wenchang said: The *Zang* edition omits the character *neng* (能).

**[Interpretation]:** What the multitude does not understand, they take as natural—dark and obscure, days passing and coming, ceaseless in their movement. Do people take this as fate?

One who trusts in fate is without longevity or early death.

**[Annotation]:** Where there is longevity or early death, it is not fate.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Wang* (亡) is pronounced *wú*, the same below.

One who trusts in principle is without right or wrong.

**[Annotation]:** Where there is right or wrong, it is not principle.

One who trusts in the heart is without compliance or opposition.

**[Annotation]:** Where there is compliance or opposition, it is not the heart.

One who trusts in nature is without safety or danger.

**[Annotation]:** Where there is safety or danger, it is not nature.

This is called having nothing to trust and nothing not to trust.

**[Annotation]:** Principle, too, is without trust or lack of trust.

The *Daozang* Jiang Yu edition and the *Sijie* edition omit the second *du* (都).

Truly sincere and earnest—what is there to abandon, what to pursue? What is there to grieve, what to rejoice?"

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Le* (乐) is pronounced *luò*.

What is there to do, what not to do?

**[Annotation]:** If principle is without heart, then there is nothing not done, and also nothing done.

**[Exegesis]:** Longevity and premature death are of fate; right and wrong are of principle; compliance and opposition are of the heart; safety and danger are of nature. If one who trusts in fate is without longevity or premature death, one who trusts in principle is without right or wrong, one who trusts in the heart is without compliance or opposition, and one who trusts in nature is without safety or danger, then this is called having nothing to trust and nothing not to trust—only then does one reach the true Dao. What is there to abandon, what to pursue? What is there to grieve, what to rejoice? What is there to do, what not to do? This is called the ultimate Dao.

The *Yellow Emperor’s Book* states: *"The perfected person dwells as though dead, moves as though mechanical."*

**[Annotation]:** This illustrates the extreme of being without heart.

Yu Yue remarks: The character *xiè* (械) is meaningless. **Phonetic Annotation:** The text also appears as *jiè* (戒), but both are in fact the character *hài* (骇). In the *Rites of Zhou*, the Grand Charioteer’s "commencement drum" (*shǐ jiè gǔ* 始□戒鼓) is recorded in the old script as *hài* (骇). The original text of the *Liezi* likely also used *hài* (骇) for *jiè* (戒), but later copyists mistakenly wrote it with the wood radical as *xiè* (械). *"Dwells as though dead, moves as though startled"* (*jū ruò sǐ, dòng ruò hài*) conveys the same meaning as *"like a virgin, like a fleeing hare."*

Wang Shumin states: Yu Yue’s interpretation is incorrect. The perfected person’s *"heart is like dead ashes"* (*xīn rú sǐ huī*), hence *"dwells as though dead"* (*jū ruò sǐ*); their *"form is like withered wood"* (*xíng rú gǎo mù*), hence *"moves as though mechanical"* (*dòng ruò xiè*). The annotation *"this illustrates the extreme of being without heart"* is correct. *Jiè* (戒) is also a loan for *xiè* (械). If taken as *hài* (骇), it misses the point.

The *Zhuangzi*’s *"Gengsang Chu"* chapter states: *"Moves without knowing what is done"*—this is the same meaning as *"moves as though mechanical."* **Phonetic Annotation:** *Xie* (械) is pronounced *hù jiè*, and the text also appears as *jiè* (戒). They neither know why they dwell, nor why they do not dwell; neither know why they move, nor why they do not move.

Neither do they alter their inner disposition or outward appearance because of the many people’s observations, nor do they claim that their inner disposition or outward appearance remain unchanged because the many do not observe them.
**[Annotation]** They do not change their bearing due to external perceptions or judgments.

Tao Hongqing states: The phrase *"nor do they claim that their inner disposition or outward appearance remain unchanged because the many do not observe them"* should read *"nor do they alter their inner disposition or outward appearance because of the many people’s observations"*—the current *"do not observe"* is a spurious addition by later hands.
Zhang’s annotation suggests that the version he saw had both clauses as *"because of the many people’s observations."*
The superfluous *"not"* distorts the meaning, rendering it repetitive.

Wang Chongmin notes: *"For"* (為) and *"claim"* (謂) were interchangeable in ancient usage.
Zhang’s annotation implies that the text he consulted read *"for."*
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *"Claim"* (謂) is written as *"for"* (為), pronounced *yú wěi*; the annotation follows the same reading.

Alone they come, alone they go; alone they depart, alone they enter—who can obstruct them?
**[Annotation]** Things go, and they go with them; things come, and they come with them.
They let things enter and exit freely, so nothing can obstruct them.

**[Exegesis]** *"Dwells as though dead"*—without heart; *"moves as though mechanical"*—operates like a device.
Like a wooden puppet’s movements, what awareness could there be?
It lies neither in disposition nor in appearance—merely a wandering spirit. Who could obstruct it?
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *"Obstruct"* (碍) is written as **, pronounced *ài*.
**[Annotation]** *Mò* (墨) is pronounced *méi*.
*□* is pronounced *chì yí*.

**[Exegesis]** The demeanor of feigned stupidity.
Qin Enfu states: *"Mò"* (墨) in regional speech is written as *"mè"* (嚜), pronounced *mù*. *"Mò"* and *"mè"* were interchangeable in ancient script.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Mò□* is pronounced *méi chī*.
*Fangyan* glosses: *"Mò□"*—in the Jiang-Huai region, it means *"worthless."*
*Guangya* states: *"Mò"* is pronounced *mù*; *□* means *"deceive."*

From here onward, twenty individuals exhibit mutually opposing intelligence, craft, talent, and conduct, yet can harmoniously coexist year-round—each follows their true nature.

Bo Jun notes: *Guangya*’s *Shigu* II states: *"Mè□"* means *"deceive."* The phonetic annotation may contain errors.

*Dān* (单) **[Annotation]** is pronounced *zhàn*.
*Zhì* (至) **[Annotation]** is pronounced *dié*.

**[Exegesis]** The appearance of light agitation.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Dān* is pronounced *zhàn*. *"Dān zhì"*—the utmost of agitated tension.

*Tān* (啴) **[Annotation]** is pronounced *chǐ rán*.
*Xuān* (咺) **[Annotation]** is pronounced *xǔ yuán*.

**[Exegesis]** The appearance of leisurely slowness.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Tān* is pronounced *chǐ rán*, also *tā dān*.
*Xuān* is pronounced *xuān*, also *hū yuǎn*.
Zheng Xuan’s annotation to the *Liji* states: *"Xuān"*—the demeanor of relaxed spaciousness.
*Shuowen* states: *"Xuān"*—the appearance of a broad and unhurried mind and belly.

*Biē* (憋) **[Annotation]** is pronounced *fáng miè*.
*Fū* (□) **[Annotation]** is pronounced *fū*.

These all describe the appearances of feigned stupidity, agitation, sluggishness, haste, or slowness.
**[Note]** The four pronunciations—*"chì yí,"* *"chǐ rán,"* *"xǔ yuán,"* and *"fáng miè"*—originally lacked the *"fǎn"* (反) marker. This follows the *Yuan* edition and *Shidetang* edition in adding it. The same applies to the pronunciations *"yú lüè,"* *"chǐ lüè,"* and *"kǔ jiāo"* below.

Qin Enfu states: This passage seems to lack Lu’s annotation.
*Fangyan* states: *"Biē"* means *"evil."*
Guo Pu’s annotation: *"Biē fū"*—a hasty temperament.
The *Hou Hanshu*’s *"Dong Zhuo"* chapter: *"bì cháng gǒu tài"* (敝肠狗态).
Li Xian’s annotation: *"Bì"* is written as *"biē"*—*Fangyan* glosses it as *"evil."*
*Fū* should be written as *fū* (怤).
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Biē* is pronounced *piàn miè*; *fū* is pronounced *fū*.
*Fangyan* states: *"Biē fū"* is pronounced *fú*, meaning *"hasty temperament."*

Four individuals wander together in the world, each following their own inclinations.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Xū* (胥) is pronounced *xiāng jū*—meaning *"mutual."*
*Rú* (如) means *"to follow."*
That is, each follows their own will.

Though they live out their years without understanding one another’s true feelings, they each believe their own wisdom to be profound.
**[Exegesis]** Though they wander together in the world, they never learn one another’s names throughout their lives, each considering themselves superior.

Crafty flattery and foolish honesty—
**[Exegesis]** *"Crafty flattery"*—the appearance of glib and obsequious speech.
*"Foolish honesty"*—the appearance of guileless simplicity.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *"Crafty flattery"*—clever words and perverse compliance.
*"Foolish honesty"*—like a fool, honest and straightforward.

*Nüè* (婩) **[Annotation]** is pronounced *yú lüè*.
*Zhuó* (斫) **[Annotation]** is pronounced *chǐ lüè*.
*"Nüè zhuó"*—the appearance of unenlightened obstinacy.
**[Exegesis]** The demeanor of dull astonishment.

**[Note]** The seven characters *"Nüè zhuó—the appearance of unenlightened obstinacy"* appear in the *Northern Song* edition and Wang’s edition under the phrase *"pián pì"* (便辟). This follows the *Daozang* editions in moving them here.

Hong Yi states: *"Nüè zhuó"* is the same as *"nüè □."*
*Fangyan* states: *"Nüè □"* means *"fresh and fine"*—a common expression beyond the southern regions of Chu.
*Shuowen* states: *"□"* means *"uniform."*
The *Hanshu*’s *"Jiang Chong"* chapter: *"Chong was tall and imposing."*
Yan Shigu’s annotation: *"Imposing"*—having edges and corners like a cliff.
*"Imposing"* is the same as *"nüè."*

**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Nüè* is pronounced with the rising tone.
*Zhuó* is pronounced *zhuó*.
*"Nüè zhuó"*—the appearance of sharp and precipitous bearing.
*Zilin* states: *"Nüè"* means *"uniform"*—the appearance of prolonged speechlessness.
*Jiě* (解) is pronounced *xiè*.

Ren Dachun states: In this passage, Zhang Zhan’s annotation *"Nüè zhuó—the appearance of unenlightened obstinacy"* is concisely summarized in Lu Jing’s phonetic notes, hence the phrase *"prolonged lack of understanding."*
The *Daozang* edition’s *"speech"* (語) is a corruption of *"enlightenment"* (悟).

Flattery and obsequiousness—
**[Exegesis]** The appearance of affected deference.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Pián* (便) is pronounced *fáng lián*.
*Pì* (辟) is pronounced *bì yì*.
*"Pián pì"*—excessive reverence.

Four individuals wander together in the world, each following their own inclinations.
Though they live out their years without discussing their arts,
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Yǔ* (语) is pronounced *yú jù*—meaning *"to speak."*
they each believe their own craft to be subtle.
**[Exegesis]** Though they wander together in the world, they never exchange visits throughout their lives, each considering their own skill exquisite.

*Fū* (□) **[Annotation]** is pronounced *kǔ jiāo*.
*Yá* (□) **[Annotation]** is pronounced *kǔ yá*.

**[Exegesis]** The appearance of obstinacy, perversity, and stubborn defiance.
Qin Enfu notes: In *Wen Xuan*, Zuo Si’s *"Wu Capital Rhapsody"* reads: 「□□泶□」. Li Shan’s commentary states: *"Fangyan* defines □ as *jiǎo* (狡, cunning)." Thus, □ is the character *jiǎo*.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Jiǎo* (□) is pronounced *kǒu jiāo*.
*Jiā* (□) is pronounced *kǒu jiā*.
Ruan Xiaoxu states: 「□□」 denotes a crouching, servile demeanor.
*Jiǎo* (□) is pronounced *kǒu jiāo*.

**Unconcealed emotions**,
**[Exegesis]** The state of hiding nothing.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** Emotions laid bare, nothing concealed.

*Jiǎn* (□) **[Annotation]** pronounced *jiǎn*.
**Obstruction**,
**[Exegesis]** The appearance of stammering and inarticulacy.
The *Shide Tang* edition reads 「□」 as 「极」.
Qin Enfu notes: *Fangyan* writes it as 「极」. *Jí* (极) and *jí* (□) are interchangeable as ancient characters.
Yu Zhengxie states: 「□□」 means stuttering. *Jí* (□) carries the sense of urgency. *Records of the Grand Historian* says: "Zhou Chang was a stutterer, and when enraged, his speech became even more hurried." Stuttering implies volubility, and a hasty temperament causes speech to emerge haltingly yet urgently—hence *jiǎn jí* (蹇□). *Zuozhuan* states: "Gongsun’s urgency," with commentary: "His nature was impatient, unable to endure restraint." It is also written as 「謇吃」. *Zhubing Yuanhou Lun* says: "When yin and yang qi are disharmonious and the visceral qi are deficient, stuttering arises. The heart’s qi connects to the tongue, the spleen’s qi to the mouth, and the spleen’s vessels link to the tongue’s root. When pathogenic qi invades the organs and contends with the normal qi, speech is initiated and qi is stirred, allowing the pathogen to disrupt the proper vessels. Obstructed qi causes congestion, leading to stuttering—this is treatable." *Yiqie Jing Yinyi*, citing *Tongsu Wen*, states: "Impeded speech is called *jiǎn chí* (謇吃)."
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Jiǎn* (□) is pronounced *jiǎn*, *jí* (□) is pronounced *jí*.
*Zilin* states: *Jí* (□) means stuttering. *Fangyan*: *Jí* (□), *chī* (吃), and *jí* (□) mean urgency—speech is hurried and stuttered. It also denotes a halting manner. It further means rapidity, or a hasty temperament at odds with others. Some write it as *jí* (殛) or *jí* (极), but these are incorrect.
Ren Dachun states: In *Xunzi’s "Rhapsodies"*, "entering and exiting with great *jí* (极)" is glossed: "*Jí* (极) is read as *jí* (亟), meaning urgency." It also states: "reversing and repeating with great *jí* (极)," with the gloss: "*Jí* (极) is read as *jí* (亟), meaning urgency." Thus, *jí* (□) is also interchangeable with *jí* (极).

**Harsh rebukes** **[Annotation]** pronounced *suì*.
These all describe the manner of excessive reproach, stammering, inarticulacy, or glibness.
**[Exegesis]** The appearance of seizing opportunities to censure others.
The *Shide Tang* edition reads "此皆多" as "比皆反".
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Suì* (谇) is pronounced in the *rù* tone.
*Harsh rebukes* means a fondness for humiliating and berating others.
*Shuowen* states: *Suì* (谇) means to reproach and admonish.
*Zilin* glosses it as *jù lǜ* (聚律) cut.
*Nè* (讷) is pronounced *nú hū*.
*Sè* (涩) is pronounced *suǒ lì*.

The four wander together in the world, each following their own inclinations.
Though they live out their years without mutual enlightenment,
**[Note by Bo Jun]** The Qin edition includes an "而" after "穷年".
each believes their own talent to be perfectly realized.
**[Exegesis]** Each considers their own abilities superior.

**Dullness** **[Annotation]** pronounced *mò diǎn*.
**Slackness** **[Annotation]** pronounced *tú jiǎn*.
**[Exegesis]** The appearance of lacking vitality.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Mián* (眠) is written as 「」, pronounced in the *shǎng* tone.
*Niǎn* (娗) is pronounced *tiǎn*.
*Fangyan*: *Niǎn* (娗) means deceptive and contemptuous speech. Guo Pu states: It refers to using words to belittle and mock others. It also denotes an unforthcoming manner.
Ren Dachun states: The modern edition writes 「」 as *mián* (眠). *Fangyan* reads *mián niǎn* (眠娗) as *mò diǎn*, and the modern edition’s *mián* (眠) is correct. Jing Shun’s *Shiwen* edition writes *mián* (眠) as 「」. Consulting *Yupian*, this is an ancient form of the character *shì* (视). 「」 is pronounced *shàng zhī*, meaning "to see"—its meaning differs entirely from *mián* (眠) in *mián niǎn* (眠娗). The character 「」 should be *mián* (眠); Tang scholars avoided the character *mín* (民), hence the substitution with *shì* (氏). The *Shiwen*’s note "眠上声" is a superfluous *mián* (眠).

**Hesitation** **[Annotation]** pronounced *zhǐ lěi*.
**Shirking** **[Annotation]** pronounced *rú wěi*.
**[Exegesis]** Both describe a cumbersome, encumbered manner.
The *fǎn* (反) in the four phonetic annotations—*mò diǎn* (莫典), *tú jiǎn* (徒茧), *zhǐ lěi* (止累), and *rú wěi* (如伪)—are added following the Yuan edition and *Shide Tang* edition.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Zhuì* (諈) is pronounced *zhī shuì*.
*Wěi* (诿) is pronounced *kǒu huì*, or *rú wěi*.
It means sluggishness.
*Erya* states: *Zhuì wěi* (諈诿) means to shift burdens away. Guo Pu states: It refers to passing responsibilities to others through hesitation and shirking. It also means cumbersome and encumbered.

**Courage and boldness**,
**[Exegesis]** The appearance of vigor and strength.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** Courage and boldness mean bravery, ferocity, and decisiveness.

**Timidity and hesitation** **[Annotation]** *Mián niǎn* (眠娗) denotes an unforthcoming manner. *Zhuì wěi* (諈诿) denotes a cumbersome manner.
**[Exegesis]** The appearance of weakness and indecision.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** Timidity and hesitation mean cautious hesitation.

The four wander together in the world, each following their own inclinations.
Though they live out their years without mutual reproach or exposure,
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Zhé* (谪) is pronounced *zhī gé*.
*Zhé* (谪) means to censure their faults; *fā* (发) means to attack their flaws.
each believes their conduct to be free of transgression.
**[Exegesis]** Each considers their own path perfectly balanced and appropriate.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Xíng* (行) is pronounced *xià mèng*.
*Wú lì* (无戾) means without deviation or offense.

**Harmonious**,
**[Exegesis]** The appearance of agreement and accord.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Duō ǒu* (多偶) means frequent harmony with others.
*Guangya* states: *Ǒu* (偶) means harmony.

**Self-reliant**,
**[Exegesis]** The appearance of acting alone.
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Zì zhuān* (自专) means to act independently without consulting others.

**Seizing power**,
**[Exegesis]** The appearance of wielding authority.
**[Note by Bo Jun]** The Qin edition writes *chéng* (乘) as *bǐng* (秉).
**[Phonetic Annotation]** *Chéng quán* (乘权) means to leverage power and influence.

**Standing alone**,
**[Exegesis]** The appearance of solitary integrity.

The *Shiwen* states: *Zhī lì* (只立) means solitary and self-reliant.

Four people wander together in the world, each following their own aspirations; though they spend their whole lives without glancing at one another, each deems their own timing fitting. These are the manifold dispositions of the world. The *Shiwen* states: *Tài* (态) is pronounced *tā ài*.

Their appearances are not uniform—*qí* (其) was originally absent but has been added following the Jifu and Shidetang editions—and yet all are subsumed under the Dao, as destiny’s return. **[Exegesis]** That cunning, eloquence, foolishness, flattery, and integrity—these manifold dispositions—are all ascribed to destiny is a principle that cannot be so. Now, those who expound such views claim that the thickness or thinness of one’s received *qi* accounts for these differences, attributing all to Heaven without recourse—this is the ignorance of the unknowing.

Thus, those who know the Dao cultivate their spirit, preserve their authenticity, ease their concerns, and transform their bodies. Their physical forms are self-fashioned; they exert their conduct, shift their destinies—these are the splendid achievements of those who nurture life. Yet if one distinguishes destiny by form, then effort is inferior to destiny; if one verifies form by effort, then destiny is inferior to effort.

*Guǐ guǐ chéng zhě* (佹佹成者) are those who *qiào* (俏) succeed. **[Annotation]** *Qiào* is pronounced *xiào*. *Qiào* means "to resemble." Qin Enfu notes: Lu’s annotation reads *wēi wēi* (魏魏), differing from Zhang Zhan’s edition. Bo Jun observes: A *zhě* (者) may be missing after *qiào chéng* (俏成) to match the syntax below. The *Liushu Gu* (Six Writings) Volume 8 cites it correctly as *qiào chéng zhě yě* (俏成者也). The *Shiwen* states: *Guǐ* (佹) is pronounced *gū wēi*, denoting a near-desiring appearance. *Qiào* is identical to *xiào* (肖). Yet this is not true success. **[Exegesis]** *Wēi wēi* (魏魏) describes a near-desiring state. *Qiào* means "to resemble." *Guǐ guǐ bài zhě* (佹佹败者) are those who *qiào* (俏) fail—yet this is not true failure.

**[Annotation]** The world speaks of near-gains and near-losses, but in truth, there is no "near." **[Exegesis]** One who nearly succeeds yet does not is like success but not success; one who nearly fails yet does not is like failure but not failure. The *Shiwen* states: *Jī* (几) is pronounced *qí*, the same below.

Thus, delusion arises from *qiào* (俏). **[Annotation]** Confusion stems from mistaking semblance for success or failure, unable to discern the source of delusion. Lu Wenchang notes: The annotation’s *yǐ* (以) appears as *sì* (似) in the Zang edition. At the juncture of *qiào* (俏), all is obscure. The *Shiwen* marks this as a sentence. If one is not obscure at the juncture of *qiào* (俏), **[Annotation]** *Jì* (际) means "convergence," implying murky indistinction. **[Exegesis]** Human delusion arises from resemblance, from lack of clarity. Without clarity, all is obscure. If one discerns resemblance without obscurity, this is called illumination. Lu Wenchang notes: The Zang edition includes an *ér* (而) after *mèi* (昧) in the annotation.

Then one is not startled by external misfortune—the *Shiwen* writes *hài* (骇) as *hài* (駴), stating it is identical to *hài* (骇)—nor delighted by inner fortune. **[Annotation]** Are misfortune and fortune truly internal or external? Both are the mysterious determinations of principle. Seeing their sudden emergence, one calls them external; seeing their gradual manifestation, one calls them internal. The *Shiwen* states: *Zú* (卒) is pronounced *cūn* (村) in the entering tone. One moves with the times, halts with the times—wisdom cannot fathom it. **[Annotation]** If movement and stillness are not of the self, then they are not discernible by wisdom. **[Exegesis]** The so-called illuminated one understands nature, comprehends the spirit, and knows that effort gives rise to life while destiny brings it to fruition. Thus, there is no external misfortune to fear, no inner fortune to rejoice in; movement and stillness follow the times, requiring no calculation by wisdom.

Those who trust in destiny harbor no duality between self and other. **[Annotation]** They have no emotions of joy or fear. Those who harbor duality between self and other would do better to cover their eyes, plug their ears, turn their backs to slopes, and face moats without stumbling. **[Annotation]** This illustrates that relying on wisdom and planning is inferior to following nature. **[Exegesis]** If one can eliminate duality between self and other, then fortune and misfortune, regret and shame do not arise. If one cannot know destiny and follow principle, then preserving the body and avoiding harm is merely to escape collapse and stumbling.

Thus, the world does not forget striving for effort but cannot entrust itself to destiny. Lu Wenchang notes: The annotation’s *rú* (如) appears as *ruò* (若) in the Zang edition. The *Shiwen* writes *bèi bǎn* (背阪) as *bèi chéng* (背城) and *zhuì* (坠) as *duì* (队), stating: *Yǎn* (揜) is pronounced *yǎn*; *bèi chéng* (背城) appears as *bèi bǎn* (背阪) in one edition. *Duì* (队) is pronounced *zhuì* (坠), *pū* (仆) as *fù* (赴).

Thus it is said: Life and death follow destiny; poverty and hardship follow the times. **[Annotation]** If it were not for destiny, the benevolent and wise would surely live long, while the cruel and foolish would surely die young—but this is not necessarily so. **[Annotation]** If it were not for the times, the diligent and frugal would surely grow rich, while the extravagant and indolent would surely remain poor—but this is not necessarily so. **[Exegesis]** Zixia said: "Life and death are a matter of destiny; wealth and honor rest with Heaven." "Heaven" here means "the times." When yang warmth spreads its *qi*, all things are born; when the sage benefits from this and all beings flourish, this is called destiny, self-determined; when transformation reaches them, this is called the times. Lu Wenchang notes: The Zang edition includes a *yě* (也) at the end of the annotation. Tao Hongqing states: *Pín qióng* (贫穷) should be *pín fù* (贫富), aligning with the preceding "life and death follow destiny." Zhang’s annotation suggests his edition originally read *pín fù* (贫富). The current text’s error stems from the following "those who resent poverty." The *Shiwen* states: *Pín qióng zì shí yě* (贫穷自时也) appears as *fù guì zì shí yě* (富贵自时也) in one edition.

Those who resent early death do not understand destiny; those who resent poverty do not understand the times. The *Shiwen* states: *Shé* (折) is pronounced *zhī shé*. **[Annotation]** These are all failures to recognize the principles of nature. Facing death without fear, enduring hardship without sorrow—this is knowing destiny and resting in the times. **[Exegesis]** Knowing destiny and resting in the times is the greatest virtue.

When the times come, they cannot be shared; when destiny arrives, it cannot be refused. Thus it is said: rest in the times and dwell in compliance, and sorrow and joy cannot enter. Delusion arises from resemblance, and grief arises from not understanding the times.

Those who are highly intelligent weigh advantages and harms, assess emptiness and fullness—*liào* (料) is pronounced *liáo*. They gauge human sentiments—*duó* (度) is pronounced *tuò luò*, as below. Whether they gain or lose, they hit the mark—*zhòng* (中) is pronounced *zhì chōng*, meaning "half," as below. Some editions read *zhì zhòng*, which is incorrect.

**[Annotation]** *Zhòng* means "half."

Those of little intelligence do not weigh advantages and harms, do not assess emptiness and fullness, do not gauge human sentiments. Whether they gain or lose, they still hit the mark. What difference is there between weighing and not weighing, assessing and not assessing, gauging and not gauging?

**[Exegesis]** Generally, in assessing the affairs of the world, one who succeeds half the time must be skilled in assessment. Yet those of little intelligence, though they do not assess, also succeed half the time—what difference is there? Only when there is nothing measured—**[Annotation]** not employing intelligence—and nothing unmeasured—**[Annotation]** relying on what intelligence knows—is one whole and without loss—*wáng* (亡) is pronounced *wú*; *sàng* (丧) is pronounced *xī làng*, as below. Yet this is neither knowing wholeness—*zhī* (知) is pronounced *zhì*, as below in "knowing loss"—nor knowing loss. One is whole of oneself, lost of oneself, ruined of oneself.

**[Annotation]** Being whole of oneself is not something the mind’s efforts can achieve; being ruined of oneself is not the result of misconduct.

**[Exegesis]** Even if one toils the mind and strains the will, assessing with half success, it is still inferior to not assessing at all and preserving one’s life. Those who labor in thought do not understand destiny; those who measure nothing do not rely on their own strength. Not relying on strength is close to the Dao, so one abandons the former and adopts the latter.

Yu Yue says: The three characters "自亡也" (*zì wáng yě*) are likely superfluous. The preceding text states: "Only when there is nothing measured and nothing unmeasured is one whole and without loss. This is neither knowing wholeness nor knowing loss." Here, it says, "One is whole of oneself, ruined of oneself," which is sufficient in meaning. Adding "lost of oneself" disrupts the parallel with the earlier "whole" and "loss." This redundancy likely arose from the three preceding instances of *wáng* (亡), all meaning "nothing" (無), not "loss" (丧亡).—*xíng* (行) is pronounced *xià mèng*.

Duke Jing of Qi traveled to Ox Mountain. Ox Mountain is now in Linzi County of Beihai Prefecture. Looking north over his capital, he wept and said: "How beautiful is this land! So lush and verdant—*qiān* (芊) is pronounced *qiān*. The *Guang Ya* states: *qiānqiān* means "luxuriant." Why must I leave this land, flowing away in tears?"—Lu Wenchang says: In the *Zang* edition, "滴滴" appears as "□□."—*Dīdī* (滴滴) is also written as *pāngpāng*, both pronounced *pǔ láng*, meaning "flowing abundantly." Ren Dachun says: For *pāngpāng*, it suffices to note the pronunciation *pǔ láng*; there is no need to say "both pronounced." This means the main text’s *dī* and the variant *pāng* are both pronounced *pǔ láng*. However, *dī* has no such pronunciation. Consulting the *Xunzi*’s "Fu Guo" chapter, Yang Liang’s annotation reads: "*Fāngfāng* (汸汸) is read as *pāng*, meaning 'abundant water.'" Thus, *dī* may be a corruption of *fāng*.

Bo Jun notes: The *Liezi*’s *Shiwen* convention is that if character A should be character B, or if they share the same meaning, then B’s pronunciation is given, regardless of whether the two characters can be phonetically loaned. Below, it states: *xíng* (行) is glossed as *xiá* (暇), meaning *xíng* should be *hé* (何), not that *xíng* has the sound of *hé*. The same applies to *dī* and *pāng* sharing a pronunciation.

Ren’s argument is unclear.

"If the ancients never died, where would I go from here?"—Lu Wenchang says: The *Han Shi Waizhuan* reads "何之" (*hé zhī*) instead of "之何" (*zhī hé*).

Shi, Kong, and Liangqiu Ju all wept alongside him—*Shǐ Kǒng* (史孔) is written as *Ài Kǒng* (艾孔) in one edition; *ài* is pronounced *wǔ gài*. They said: "We rely on Your Lordship’s grace. Coarse grain and tough meat are ours to eat—*sū* (疏) is written as *guì* (跪) in one edition; *guì* should be *sū*. The *Han Shi Waizhuan* includes this entire passage, stating: 'Coarse grain and tough meat can be eaten.' Coarse grain means vegetables. We may ride broken-down horses and rickety carts—*nú* (驽) appears as *nù* (怒) in the *Shide Tang* edition. *Zhàn* (棱) should be *zhàn* (栈). The *Yanzi Chunqiu* and other texts all write *zhàn chē* (栈车), meaning carts made of woven wood. *Zhàn* is pronounced *shì xiàn*. Even so, we do not wish to die—how much less should our lord?" Only Yanzi laughed to the side—*Yànzǐ* (晏子) is written as *Yàn Yīng* (晏婴); Yan Ying was from Yiwei in Lai.

The duke wiped his tears and turned to Yanzi—Bo Jun notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s "Guan Biao" chapter states: "Wu Qi wiped his tears in response." Gao You’s annotation: "*Xuě* (雪) means 'to wipe.'" The *Kongzi Jiayu*’s "Zilu Chujian" chapter states: "Millet is used to wipe the mortar." The annotation: "*Xuě* means 'to wipe.'"—and said: "Today’s outing has saddened me. Kong and Ju wept with me, yet you alone laugh. Why?"

Yanzi replied: "If worthy men always preserved it, then the Grand Duke and Duke Huan would still possess it..."

"If brave men always preserved it, then Duke Zhuang and Duke Ling would still possess it. Bo Jun notes: 'And always preserve it' means 'could always preserve it.' *Néng* (能) and *ér* (而) share an ancient pronunciation, hence they may be used interchangeably. If these several lords were to preserve it, our lord would now be donning a straw raincoat and bamboo hat, standing amidst the furrows of the fields. Would he have leisure to grieve over affairs or contemplate death in vain?

[Annotation] *Xíng jiǎ* (行假) should read *hé xiá* (何暇).
[Exegesis] That the dead may return to life is a notion common to Buddhist scriptures, Daoist texts, and Confucian teachings, though none state it plainly. Here, however, it is said that 'our lord would now be donning a straw raincoat and bamboo hat, standing amidst the furrows of the fields'—thus the principle of life and death is made clear. We know that power brings about destiny, and destiny brings forth life; hence the workings of life’s renewal are evident. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Han Shi Waizhuan* reads *hé xiá* (何暇). The *Shiwen* glosses: *Xíng jiǎ* is pronounced *hé xiá*. Then how could our lord have attained this position and stand here? Because it is by turns occupied and relinquished. As for the lord alone weeping over it—this is unkind. Seeing an unkind lord and flattering ministers, I saw these two things, and this is why I alone secretly laughed."

Bo Jun notes: *Wéi* (为) means *yǐ* (以). "The reason for laughing alone" means "the reason why I alone laughed." For further discussion, see Wang’s *Shici*.

Duke Jing felt ashamed, raised his cup, and punished himself. He then penalized the two ministers, each with two cups. There was a man of Wei named Dongmen Wu whose son died, yet he did not grieve. Wang Shumin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (518), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (48, 51), *Shiwen Leiju* (Later Collection 7), and *Hebi Shilei* (Former Collection 32) all include "aged forty" after "there was a man." The phrase "his son died, yet he did not grieve" is rendered as "he had a son whom he lost, yet he did not grieve."

His steward said: Bo Jun notes: The *Liji*’s "Qu Li" (Part II) states: "A scholar does not refer to his steward or eldest concubine by name." *Xiàngshì* (相室) likely means *jiāxiàng* (家相), the one who assists in household affairs. The *Shiwen* glosses: *Xiàng* is pronounced *sì liàng*. "Your lordship’s love for your son was unmatched in the world. Now that your son has died, why do you not grieve?" Dongmen Wu replied: "I once had no son. When I had no son, I did not grieve. Now that my son has died, it is the same as when I had no son before. Why should I grieve?" Wang Chongmin notes: The *Jifu* edition reads *jù* (讵) instead of *chén* (臣), likely the original read *xī jù yōu yān* (奚巨忧焉). *Xī jù* is a compound, but readers, not grasping its meaning, altered it to place the emphasis on *xī* (奚). Bo Jun notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (518) reads: "Then why should I grieve?"

The farmer hurries to the season, the merchant hastens for profit, the artisan pursues his craft, and the official chases power—such is the force of circumstance. Yet the farmer faces drought and flood, the merchant meets gain and loss, the artisan encounters success and failure, and the official meets favor or rejection—such is the force of destiny.

[Annotation] The workings of nature’s hidden course.
[Exegesis] That scholars, farmers, artisans, and merchants each pursue profit and chase power is what their strength can achieve. Drought and flood, success and failure, favor and rejection—these lie beyond their power, so they entrust themselves to destiny and find peace. This is like gathering the mulberry and elm without harming their protection. The world attributes what cannot be helped to destiny, yet those who do not strive are deluded by the semblance of attainment. Dongmen Wu was skilled at accepting destiny, not at understanding it. If the living have one who gives life, then one grasps that which creates one’s destiny; how then could one entrust destiny to the living? This is to grasp the principle of alternating presence and absence. One who understands destiny should entrust it to fate while applying one’s strength.

Qin Enfu notes: Lu’s annotation on the "mulberry and elm" sentence is unclear. Sun Yirang notes: The exegesis likely reads *sāng* (桑) for *sōu* (橾) and *yǔn huò* (陨获) for *sǔn hù* (损护), as seen in the *Liji*’s "Ruxing" chapter. Bo Jun notes: Based on Lu’s exegesis, it seems the *Chongxuan* edition connects "the farmer hurries to the season" to the preceding passage. However, judging by the meaning, "the farmer hurries to the season" and what follows form a separate section, summarizing the chapter’s theme, and thus remains set apart.

[Annotation] Life is but a momentary gathering of qi, a fleeting spark of sentience in a single being. What is momentarily gathered must ultimately scatter; what is fleetingly sentient must return to emptiness. Yet to favor ease and detest labor is the constant nature of all things. Thus, what delights one in life amounts to nothing more than rich flavors, fine garments, beautiful forms, and enchanting sounds. Yet one cannot freely follow the inclinations of one’s nature or the pleasures of the senses, instead using benevolence and righteousness as bolts and ritual propriety as sashes, withering away in one’s prime while seeking a lingering reputation in posterity—this is to fail to grasp the joy of the ceaseless arising of life.

[Exegesis] The noble person dies for fame, the petty person for profit. Fame and profit alike are what emotions drown in and the common crowd contends for. Thus, one who embodies the Dao does good without nearing fame, does not rush toward what the crowd competes for; does evil without nearing punishment, does not act in ways the crowd condemns. To violate the Dao in pursuit of fame or to drown in emotion in pursuit of desire is equally to lose the mean. Therefore, one who possesses the Dao does not dwell in such extremes. This passage seems contradictory, and scholars have often doubted it. Yet how does the chapter of Yang Zhu differ from that of Robber Zhi?

The *Shiwen* notes: Yang Zhu, some say his courtesy name was Ziju, was a man of the Warring States period, later than Mozi. Yang Zhu debated with Qin Guli, advocating self-love and refusing to pluck a single hair for the benefit of the world, opposing Mozi’s teachings. Lu Deming states, “Yang Rong’s courtesy name was Ziju,” suggesting Ziju was not Yang Zhu.

*Hao* is pronounced *hūbào*; *wù* as *wūlù*; *fù* as *fúyòu*; *jiàn* sounds like *jiàn*; *jīn* as *jīn*; *gǎo* as *kǒulǎo*.

Liang Yusheng remarks: In the *Zhuangzi*’s “Emperor of the North Sea,” Yang Ziju appears, and the *Shiwen* notes, “Li [Yi] says: *Ju* is his given name; *zi* is a general term for men.” Elsewhere, in the *Zhuangzi*’s “Words for All Occasions,” the *Shiwen* states, “His surname was Yang, given name Zhu, courtesy name Ziju,” where he engages in dialogue with Laozi. How then could he be identified as Yang Zhu?

Yang Jun notes: Whether Yang Zhu and Yang Ziju were the same person has long been debated. Wang Zhong, in his *Shuxue Laozi Kaoyi* appendix, argued they were two distinct figures, and later scholars like Tang Yue, in his *Yang Zhu Kao* (published in *Dongfang Zazhi*, vol. 22, no. 5), insisted Yang Zhu was not Yang Ziju. The view that they were two people is likely correct.

Yang Zhu traveled to Lu and lodged with the Meng family. Meng asked him, “One is merely human—why the need for fame?” Yang Zhu replied, “Fame is for wealth.” “Once wealthy, why not stop?” “For honor.” “Once honored, why not stop?” “For death.” “Once dead, what then?” “For descendants.”

[Annotation] Since one’s affairs never cease, one’s desires are never sated.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Wéi fù*, *wéi guì*, *wéi sǐ*, *xī wéi yān*, and *wéi zǐsūn* are all pronounced with the *wěi* tone. *Yàn* is pronounced *yīyán*.

“What benefit does fame bring to one’s descendants?” Yang Zhu replied, “Fame torments the body and scorches the heart.

[Annotation] Fame is to seek the real through the false, to summon the substantial through the insubstantial, to act against one’s nature and force one’s conduct—how could it not entail the toil of anxiety?

The *Shiwen* notes: *Jiāo* is pronounced *jiāo*.

Yet those who ride upon fame bring blessings to their clans and benefits to their villages—how much more so to their descendants?”

Tao Hongqing said: “The eight characters ‘Fame torments the body and scorches the heart’ should follow the passage above, ‘Master Meng asked: "Man is but man—why seek fame?"’—to reveal the harm of fame and the folly of those who pursue it. Furthermore, the lines ‘Once wealthy, why not cease? Once noble, why not cease?’ precisely describe those who, despite tormenting body and scorching heart, do not desist. Now, mistakenly omitted here, the preceding passage lacks full meaning, while this passage, discussing the benefits of fame, first presents its harms, disrupting the coherence of the argument.”

“Those who pursue fame must be incorruptible; incorruptibility leads to poverty. Those who pursue fame must be yielding; yielding leads to lowliness.”

[Annotation] This is the objection of a disputant. Now, those who possess the fame of incorruptibility and yielding yet cannot escape poverty and lowliness do so because they practice goodness without seeking profit.

[Explication] In this worldly life, man is concerned only with fame and profit. The sage uses fame and profit as a hook: petty men die for profit, gentlemen die for fame—none fail to be ensnared. Though good and evil differ, both involve seeking. Yet those who seek fame and succeed not only attain wealth and nobility but bring glory to their descendants and benefit their villages. Though they torment the body, scorch the heart, and labor in incorruptibility and yielding, their aspirations have an object, and their passions forget themselves—both lose the mean.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Nàn* is pronounced *nǎidàn*.

Yang Zhu said: “When Guan Zhong served as minister to Qi,

The *Shiwen* notes: *Xiàng* is pronounced *xīliàng*; same below.

the lord was licentious, and so was he; the lord was extravagant, and so was he.”

[Annotation] This means he did not claim sole credit for good or evil.

Bo Jun notes: The *Analects* (*Eight Rows of Dancers*) states: “Guan Zhong had three concubines, did not combine official duties, erected screen gates like a feudal lord, and set up a *fandian* for diplomatic banquets like a feudal lord.” All these are evidence of his licentiousness and extravagance.

“Their aspirations aligned, their words followed one another, and their Dao was enacted, making the state hegemonic. Yet after death, Guan Zhong was nothing more.”

[Explication] The benefit of true fame is meager.

“When the Tian clan served as ministers to Qi,

Bo Jun notes: The *Imperial Digest* (vol. 485) includes the words ‘thereafter’ before ‘the Tian clan.’

the lord was full, and they diminished themselves; the lord levied, and they bestowed.”

[Annotation] This shifts blame onto the lord.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Liǎn* means to gather and collect; *shī* is pronounced *shǐchǐ*.

“The people all turned to them, and thus they took possession of Qi. Their descendants have enjoyed it to this day, unbroken.”

[Explication] The benefit of false fame runs deep.

“If true fame leads to poverty, false fame brings wealth.”

[Annotation] To do good without seeking fame, yet fame arises naturally—this is true fame. To pursue fame in order to gain profit while the world remains unaware—this is false fame. False fame is what secures profit.

The annotation “fame arises naturally” reads in the *Zang* edition as “yet arises naturally.”

Yu Yue remarks: After “If true fame leads to poverty, false fame brings wealth,” two sentences should follow: “true fame leads to lowliness, false fame brings nobility.” The preceding text states, “All who seek fame must be incorruptible, and incorruptibility leads to poverty; all who seek fame must be yielding, and yielding leads to lowliness.” Thus, the examples of Guan Zhong and the Tian clan are cited to prove that true fame results in poverty and lowliness, while false fame yields wealth and nobility.

Tao Hongqing states: Yu’s suggestion that two sentences—“true fame leads to lowliness, false fame brings nobility”—should be added is correct. However, his claim that this and the preceding discussion of Guan Zhong and the Tian clan form a single argument is mistaken. The earlier passage reads, “All who seek fame must be incorruptible, and incorruptibility leads to poverty; all who seek fame must be yielding, and yielding leads to lowliness.” Zhang’s annotation rightly treats this as the objection of a disputant. Here, the statement “If true fame leads to poverty, false fame brings wealth; true fame leads to lowliness, false fame brings nobility” likewise represents the objection of a disputant. *Ruo* (“if”) here means “in this manner”; for further discussion, see Wang’s *Jingzhuan Shici* (“*Ruo* may be followed by *ran* [‘thus’]; the phrase ‘Meng Sunyang said, *ruoran* [if thus], swift death is preferable to prolonged life’ in the *Shuofu* and ‘*Ruoran*, why could the dead not speak of the art of living?’ in the *Shuo Fu* provide examples”).

The claim that Guan Zhong’s descendants were poor and lowly due to their true fame, while the descendants of the Tian clan were wealthy and noble due to their false fame, would imply that fame indeed leads to poverty and lowliness. The disputant’s intent here is that "true" refers to genuine fame, while "false" refers to something other than fame. The subsequent response states, “Truth has no fame, fame has no truth; fame is but falsity.” This means that truth and fame cannot coexist—once something is called fame, it is all falsity with no truth, which would imply that fame indeed leads to wealth and nobility. The respondent’s intent is that "false" constitutes fame, while "true" is not fame. The following response explicitly marks its beginning with *yue* (“it is said”) to distinguish it, leaving no doubt that this is the disputant’s objection. If one were to attribute this and the preceding and following passages to a single speaker, then the lines “Truth has no fame, fame has no truth” and so on would become redundant and superfluous, their purpose unclear.

From “Now that they are wealthy, why not pursue it?” onward, all belong to the disputant’s objections, where the *yue* (“it is said”) is omitted. Readers must discern the meaning for themselves.

It is said: “Truth has no fame, fame has no truth. Fame is but falsity.”
[Annotation] Without falsity, one cannot attract profit.
[Exegesis] Those with true conduct have no fame; those who seek fame have no truth. Thus, without falsity, profit cannot be made manifest.

Formerly—Emending note: The *Taiping Yulan* (424) and *Yiwen Leiju* (21) omit the character *zhe* (“one who”)—Yao and Shun falsely offered the world to Xu You and Shan Juan, yet did not lose the world, enjoying a reign of a hundred years.
[Annotation] The traces of truth and falsity arise from circumstances. Those who achieve falsity follow the traces of Yao and Shun, but the sage is without falsity.
Emending note: Yao’s offer of the world to Xu You is also recorded in the *Zhuangzi*’s “Free and Easy Wandering” chapter; Shun’s offer of the world to Shan Juan is likewise found in the *Zhuangzi*’s “Giving Away a Throne” and “Robber Zhi” chapters.

Boyi and Shuqi truly ceded the rulership of Guzhu—Emending note: The *Taiping Yulan* (424) and *Yiwen Leiju* (21) omit the character *jun* (“lord”), which is correct—and ultimately lost their state, starving to death on Mount Shouyang.

The distinction between truth and falsity is thus made clear.

[Annotation] *Shěng* means "to examine."

[Exegesis] The false pursues reputation without substance; the true embodies action while forgetting fame. The contrast between Yao and Shun on the one hand, and Boyi and Shuqi on the other, is thus luminously clear. Are the traces of truth and falsity not easily discerned? If worldly people do not lose their authenticity in pursuit of fame and profit, they will drown in passions and desires, forgetting the Dao.

The good are few in the world, while the unvirtuous are many; thus, those who chase reputation are rare, while those who follow desire are legion. Even the wise can do nothing about this, for all have lost the mean.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Shěng* is read *sī jǐng qiē*.

Yang Zhu said: "A hundred years is the utmost limit of longevity." The *Shiwen* notes: *Qí* is read in the falling tone, meaning "limit." Among a thousand, not one attains a hundred years. The *Shiwen* reads *wú* as *wáng*, glossing it: "pronounced *wú*." Even if one such person exists, from infancy to senility, nearly half their years are spent thus. The *Shiwen* notes: *Jǐ* is pronounced *qí*; same below.

Of the remaining half, sleep at night erases some, and waking hours squander others. The *Shiwen* notes: *Mǐ* is read *mián bì qiē*; *jué* is pronounced *jiào*. Pain, illness, sorrow, and suffering—loss, anxiety, and fear—consume yet another half. Lu Wenchang notes: The *Yilin* quotes "pain and illness" as "illness and disease." Wang Shumin notes: The *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on Lu Ji’s "Long Song" also reads "illness and disease."

Measuring within these ten-odd years, how rarely does one find a moment of carefree contentment, free from the slightest concern? The *Shiwen* notes: *Wáng* is pronounced *wú*; same below. *Jiè* is pronounced *jiè*, meaning "subtle." Such moments last but an instant. What, then, is the purpose of human life? What joy does it bring? The *Shiwen* notes: *Lè* is pronounced *luò*.

It is for fine food and rich pleasures— The *Shiwen* notes: *Wéi* is read *yú wěi qiē*—for sensual delights. Yet even these cannot be constantly sated; The *Shiwen* notes: *Fù* is read *fú yòu qiē*; same below. *Yàn* in the *Shide Tang* edition is written as *yàn*, the original character. The *Shiwen* notes: *Yàn* is read *yī yán qiē*; some versions write *yàn* as *餍*, with the same pronunciation. Nor can sensual pleasures be perpetually indulged.

Thus, one is further constrained by rewards and punishments, advanced or withdrawn by fame and law. Restlessly, one competes for fleeting reputation in the moment, scheming for posthumous glory.

Ever anxious, one conforms to the sights and sounds that please the eyes and ears—*"Shùn"* in the *Daozang* *Baiwen* edition, *Lin Xiyi* edition, *Yuan* edition, and *Shide Tang* edition all write it as *"shèn"* (cautious). The *Yilin* citation matches this. *Qin Enfu* notes: The ancient characters *"shùn"* (顺) and *"shèn"* (慎) were interchangeable. In the *Yi Jing*, *"Treading on frost, solid ice follows—this speaks of shùn,"* where *"shùn"* means *"shèn."* The *Shiwen* writes *"shùn"* as *"shèn,"* noting: *"Yǔ"* is pronounced *qiū yǔ qiè.* *"Shèn ěr"* in one version is written as *"shùn ěr."* *Ren Dachun* observes: In the *Xunzi*’s *"Cultivating the Self"* chapter, *"shùn Mò"* is glossed by *Yang Liang* as *"shèn Mò."* In the *"Junzi"* chapter: *"The loyal are sincere—this is what shèn refers to."* *Yang Liang*’s commentary reads: *"Shèn* is read as *shùn.*" The *Shiwen* for the *Zhuangzi*’s *"Lie Yukou"* chapter notes: *"Shèn in warfare"*—*"shèn"* is sometimes written as *"shùn."* *"Those who are shùn-huān and yet succeed"*—*"shùn"* is also written as *"shèn."* In the *Da Dai Liji*’s *"Baofu"* chapter: *"Because of what they were shèn toward others,"* *Lu Bian*’s commentary states: *"All win the people’s hearts"*—here, *"shèn"* means *"shùn."* In the *"Zengzi on Great Filial Piety"* chapter: *"After parents have passed, one shèn-conducts oneself"*—*"shèn"* is also written as *"shùn."* In the *"Shèn Virtue"* chapter: *"To shèn Heaven’s laws,"* the commentary reads: *"The Dao of Heaven cannot be accomplished by merely shùn-ing it"*—thus, *"shèn"* means *"shùn."* In the *"Wenwang’s Officials"* chapter: *"Without discernment, one naturally shèn"*—*"shèn"* is read as *"shùn."* *"Shùn ěr"* here preserves the ancient character.

One clings to the right and wrong of personal inclinations, merely forfeiting the supreme joy of one’s prime years, unable to indulge freely even for a moment.

The heavy prisoner, bound in layered fetters—*Shiwen* notes: *"léi"* is pronounced *léi*. *"Gù"* is read as *gǔ* in the *gǔwò* initial, meaning hand restraints. What difference is there? The annotation states: *"yì"* means "different," an ancient character. The explanation: Ordinary people all take a hundred years as the span of a lifetime, yet what is diminished by day and night of sorrow and toil is already so much; those who remain at ease and follow their nature are few in number. Matters of following one’s nature extend no further than indulging in sound, form, fine flavors, yet again constrained by the bonds of punishment and reward, fame and teaching, unable to give free rein to their nature—how do they differ from those imprisoned in shackles and fetters? These are all words of stagnant emotion.

*Shiwen* notes: The ancient character for *"yì."*

The people of the Great Antiquity—*Shiwen* notes: *"Tài"* is written as *"dà"* and pronounced *tài*—knew that life is but a brief sojourn, knew that death is but a fleeting departure. The annotation: In truth, life is a brief sojourn, death a long departure—this is the commonplace talk of the world. Yet to say death is but a fleeting departure, at first glance, seems a scribal error. However, the central purport of this text holds that existence and annihilation, departure and return, the transformation and continuation of form and *qi*, have never truly ceased. This meaning is already expounded in detail in the annotation to the *"Heavenly Auspices"* chapter. The Qin engraving of Lu’s commentary omits the character *"zhī"* ("know") before *"sǐ"* ("death"). *Shiwen* notes: *"Zú"* is read as *cù* in the *qīhū* initial. Thus, they acted from the heart, following their impulses without resisting what nature favored. *Shiwen* notes: *"Cóng"* is pronounced *zòng*, and so below. *"Hào"* is read as *hào* in the *hūbào* initial.

The pleasures of this life are not to be forsaken—Yu Yue notes: *"Dāng shēn"* ("this life") is an error for *"dāng shēng"* ("present life"). Below, it states, *"The reputation after death is not to be sought,"* and *"dāng shēng"* directly opposes *"sǐ hòu"* ("after death"). Further on, it says, *"Moreover, hasten to the present life—why rush to consider the afterlife?"*—this serves as proof. *Shiwen* notes: *"Qù"* is pronounced *qiū lǚ*. Thus, one is not swayed by the lure of reputation. The annotation reads: *"Those who do good without drawing near to fame."*

The Northern Song edition, Wang’s edition, and the *Four Explications* edition write *"guān"* ("observe") for *"quàn"* ("exhort"), but here we follow the Jifu edition, the *Daoist Canon* unannotated edition, and the Shidetang edition in correcting it. *Shiwen* notes: *"Quàn"* has a variant reading as *"guān."*

Following one’s nature in wandering, one does not oppose the desires of the myriad things. The reputation after death is not to be sought, so one does not incur punishment. The annotation reads: *"Those who do evil without drawing near to punishment."* Bo Jun notes: Not opposing the desires of the myriad things means not offending others; not offending others means not doing evil, hence one does not incur punishment. Zhang’s annotation touches on this but does not elaborate. *Shiwen* notes: *"Jìn"* is read in the falling tone, and so below. *"Xíng"* means harm.

Fame and reputation, whether early or late, and the length of one’s lifespan are not matters to be measured. The exegesis states: To cite the people of the great antiquity is to suit the mean. That which is born and dies is form; that which emerges into life and enters death is spirit. Knowing that life and death are but fleeting arrivals and departures, one does not urgently seek fame; knowing that spirit is neither born nor dies, one does not anxiously strive for the Dao. Thus, one acts from the heart without resisting what nature favors. One delights in the body alone—what use is there for fame? Thus, one wanders in accord with one’s nature without opposing the desires of the myriad things. One is content in the moment alone—what fear is there of punishment? Therefore, fame, reputation, and lifespan are not matters to be calculated.

Those who delight in the body and are content in the moment move in harmony with the Dao, not drowning in emotion. Yang Zhu said: "What differs among the myriad things is life; what is the same is death. In life, there are the worthy and the foolish, the noble and the base—this is what differs. In death, there is putrefaction and dissolution—this is what is the same. Though this be so, worthiness and foolishness, nobility and baseness are not within one’s power; putrefaction and dissolution are also not within one’s power. Thus, life is not what one lives, death is not what one dies; worthiness is not what one makes worthy, foolishness is not what one makes foolish, nobility is not what one makes noble, baseness is not what one makes base." The annotation reads: All these are natural, not what one’s power can effect.

Bo Jun notes: After *"gù shēng fēi suǒ shēng"* ("thus, life is not what one lives"), the character *"néng"* ("power") is likely omitted below each *"suǒ"* ("what"). These phrases closely follow *"xián yú guì jiàn fēi suǒ néng yě, chòu fǔ xiāo miè yì fēi suǒ néng yě"* ("worthiness and foolishness, nobility and baseness are not within one’s power; putrefaction and dissolution are also not within one’s power"). A careful reading of Zhang’s annotation and Lu’s exegesis below suggests that the editions they consulted all included *"néng."*

Yet the myriad things are equal in life and equal in death, equal in worthiness and equal in foolishness, equal in nobility and equal in baseness. The annotation reads: All return equally to nature. Whether ten years or a hundred years, all die. The benevolent and sagely die, the cruel and foolish die. In life, they may be Yao and Shun; in death, they are but rotting bones. In life, they may be Jie and Zhou; in death, they are but rotting bones. The bones rot the same—who knows the difference? Moreover, hasten to the present life—why rush to consider the afterlife? The annotation reads: This mocks those who calculate the afterlife in their delusion.

One who does not scheme for the past, does not worry for the future, and has no attachment to the present—this is the perfection of virtue. The exegesis states: Life is the retribution of this body; death is the exhaustion of this retribution. Worthiness and foolishness, nobility and baseness are the distinctions of living things—hence they differ. Putrefaction and dissolution are the constants of dead things—hence they are the same. The world points to form as life and death, unaware of the spirit beyond form. When the spirit departs, it is as if all knowledge ceases. Thus, worthiness and foolishness, nobility and baseness, putrefaction and dissolution are not what form itself can effect. If not self-effected, then the substance of all living things has never not been equal. People know what is equal but not why they differ. Moreover, they compete in the present life and have no leisure to nurture what gives them life—thus those who possess the Dao do not conform to this.

Yang Zhu said: "Bo Yi did not lack desire—his error lay in his pride in purity, leading him to starve to death." The annotation reads: He clung to starvation until death. *Shiwen* notes: The *Gongyang Commentary* states: *"Fàng sǐ bù lì"* ("He starved to death without establishing himself"). Liu Zhao’s annotation reads: *"Fàng"* means "to the utmost." Zhan Ji did not lack emotion—his error lay in his pride in integrity, leading him to diminish his lineage. *Shiwen* notes: *"Guǎ zōng"* means "few in lineage." How mistaken is this error of purity and integrity! The annotation reads: These are words that slander the worthy and betray reality, yet to convey praise or blame, one cannot but place responsibility on those of lofty virtue.

The exegesis states: The excess of pursuing fame truly reaches this point—this is not how one embodies the truth, perfects the Dao, forgets fame, and attains reality. Yang Zhu said: "Yuan Xian was impoverished in Lu." Bo Jun notes: *"Jù"* should be *"jù."* The *Shuowen*, *Yupian*, *Guangyun*, *Jiyun*, and *Yunhui* all write *"jù,"* not *"jǔ."* The *Leipian* writes *"jǔ."* The *Jiyun* also includes *"jǔ,"* glossing it as *"ōu jù."* It is suspected that those writing *"jǔ"* were all later scholars from the Tang onward, for before the Tang, there was no character *"jǔ."*

The *Poetry*’s "Bei Men" states, "Ever impoverished and poor," while the *Erya* glosses *jù* as "poverty." The *Classic of Rites* reads, "The host declines with *jù*," and the *Xunzi*’s "Questions of Yao" says, "Thus they are petty and *jù*." All instances of *jù* should be written as *jù*.

The *Exegesis on Texts* notes: *Jù* is pronounced *qíyǔ*. Zigong engaged in commerce in Wei.

The annotation explains: *Jù* means poverty; *zhí* refers to mercantile pursuits. Yuan Xian’s poverty harmed his life, while Zigong’s commerce burdened his person.

The *Exegesis on Texts* adds: *Lèi* is read in the departing tone.

"Then neither poverty nor commerce is acceptable—where, then, does the acceptable lie?"

The *Exegesis on Texts* notes: *Yān* is pronounced *yúqián*.
