[Bo Jun’s note: The annotation cites Confucius’ words in the *Analects*, *Wei Linggong* chapter.] The youngest said: ‘Benevolence and righteousness allow me to preserve both body and reputation.’ [Annotation] Being enlightened and wise, one safeguards oneself. [Bo Jun’s note: The annotation quotes a line from the *Book of Songs*, *Da Ya*, “Zheng Min.”] These three methods differ, yet all emerge from Confucianism. Which is right, and which is wrong?”

Yangzi said: “There was a man who lived by the river. Accustomed to water, he was bold in swimming. [Annotation: *qiu* is pronounced *qiu* (like *qiu* in ‘prisoner’).] He plied the boat to ferry passengers, earning enough to feed a hundred mouths. Those who came with packed rations to study under him formed a crowd, yet nearly half drowned. [Annotation: *ji* is pronounced *qi* (like *qi* in ‘prayer’).] They originally studied swimming, not drowning, yet the outcome of profit and harm was thus. If one were to ask which is right and which is wrong?”

Xinduzi fell silent and left. [Annotation: The *Ji* edition writes *mo* (‘silent’) as *mo* (‘default’).]

Meng Sunyang reproached him, saying: “Why did you pose such a roundabout question, only for the Master to give such an oblique answer? [Annotation by Lu Wenchang: The *Zang* edition writes *pi* (‘oblique’) as *bi* (‘avoid’). Annotation: *yu* is pronounced *yu* (like *yu* in ‘roundabout’), meaning ‘tortuous.’ *Bi* is pronounced *pi* (‘oblique’).] My confusion has only deepened.”

Xinduzi said: “The great Dao, by its many forking paths, loses the sheep; the learner, by its many methods, forfeits life. [Annotation: *sang* (‘forfeit’) is pronounced *sang* (like *sang* in ‘loss’), same below.] The learning is not fundamentally different, nor is its root not one, yet its branches diverge so. [Annotation by Bo Jun: The *Complete Jin Literature*, volume 34, records Lu Chen’s letter to Minister of Works Liu Kun: ‘The root is the same, but the branches differ—Yang Zhu mourned this.’ The forger of the *Liezi* may have drawn from this, or perhaps such a passage already existed in ancient texts, which the *Liezi* compiler then adopted.] Only by returning to unity and reverting to oneness can one avoid loss and gain, forfeiture and preservation. [Annotation: *wang* (‘loss’) is pronounced *wu* (like *wu* in ‘without’), same below.]

You have long attended the Master’s gate and practiced the Master’s Dao, yet you do not grasp the Master’s analogy. [Annotation: *zhang* (‘long’) is pronounced *zhang* (like *zhang* in ‘senior’). Annotation: *kuang* means ‘analogy.’ [Annotation by Bo Jun: The *Book of Han*, *Annals of Meritorious Ministers under Gao, Hui, and Empress Gao*: ‘To compare the past with the present is deeply lamentable.’ Yan Shigu notes: ‘*Kuang* means analogy.’ Here, *kuang* should also be glossed as ‘analogy’ or ‘comparison.’ In the former, it is used as a verb; here, as a noun.] Alas!”

“[Explanation:] The sheep is used as an analogy for the spirit; guarding the spirit without loss is the Dao. Once one loses the sheep and rushes about on branching paths, it cannot be recovered. Simply guarding one’s spirit is to be without loss or gain, and thus without dependence. Those who pursue仁义 (*ren-yi*, benevolence and righteousness) through many paths are likewise.

Yang Zhu’s younger brother was named Bu. He wore plain white clothes when he went out. [Annotation: The first *yi* (‘wore’) in *yi su yi* (‘wore plain white clothes’) is pronounced *yì* (like *yì* in ‘clothing’); the same applies below to *yi zi yi* (‘wore black clothes’). The second *yi* in *su yi* (‘plain white clothes’) is read literally.] It rained, so he took off his plain white clothes and put on black ones before returning. His dog, not recognizing him, ran out and barked. Yang Bu grew angry and was about to strike it. [Annotation by Lu Wenchang: In the *Zang* edition, *pu* (‘strike’) is written as *po*; the same below. The *Shiwen* notes that *pu* is written as *po* and pronounced *piàn-bǔ*.] Yang Zhu said: ‘Do not strike it! You would do the same. If your dog had gone out white and returned black, how could you not find it strange?’

[Commentary:] This passage illustrates that when one’s own form changes, external things cannot comprehend it, giving rise to judgments of right and wrong. To not seek within oneself but instead place heavy blame on others is like Yang Bu, who changed his clothes and was surprised by his dog’s barking. [Annotation: In the *Zang* edition, *hou ze* (‘heavy blame’) is written as *zhuan ze* (‘exclusive blame’).]

[Explanation:] When one guards authenticity and returns to unity, even seagulls may be tamed; but if one loses the Dao and alters the constant, even a household dog may become fearful. [Annotation by Xu Weiyu: In the *Han Feizi*, *Shuo Lin Xia*, the character *zi* (‘you’) appears before *qi* (‘how’), which better suits the meaning. The *Shiwen* reads *xiang zhe shi ru gou* (‘formerly made you see the dog’) as *xiang zhe shi ru jian gou*, noting that *xiang* is pronounced *xiàng*. One edition omits the character *jian* (‘see’). Wang Shumin notes: Lin Xi Yi’s *Kou Yi* reads, ‘If one saw a white dog become black,’ suggesting that the edition he saw also included the character *jian*.]

Yang Zhu said: ‘Act with goodness not for the sake of fame, yet fame follows; fame does not seek profit, yet profit accrues.’”

“Profit does not seek contention, yet contention comes to it. [The *Shiwen* reads: *zheng* is pronounced *zhèng*; the same below.] Thus the noble person must be cautious in doing good.”

[Annotation:] In matters of wisdom, others will contend with him; in matters of strength, others will vie against him—this is the natural course of events. There has never been one who dwells at the crossroads of fame and profit yet avoids calamity. As the saying goes, “In doing good, do not draw near to fame”—how can this not be true?

[Exegesis:] The goodness that seeks fame is what all contend for. Thus, “in doing good, do not draw near to fame” means not to vie with others for profit. To practice what others cannot practice without boasting—this is to be cautious in doing good.

Lu Wenchang notes: In the annotation, the *Zang* edition reads “at the center of profit and fame” instead of “at the crossroads of fame and profit,” and includes the character *er* (‘and’) after *zhong* (‘center’).

Bo Jun observes: The *Shuo Yuan*, in its *Jing Shen* chapter, records words by Wei Gongzi Mou that closely resemble this passage.

[The *Shiwen* reads: *nan* is pronounced *nǎndàn*.]

Formerly, there was one who claimed to know the Way to immortality. [The *Daozang* unannotated edition, Lin Xiyi’s edition, and the Jifu edition include the character *you* (‘there’) after *ren* (‘one’); the Northern Song edition, the *Daozang Sijie* edition, Jiang Yue’s edition, the Shidetang edition, and Wang’s edition omit it.] Tao Hongqing said: The characters *yan you* (‘claimed to know’) are transposed in error. Wang Chongmin said: Tao’s view is incorrect; the character *you* (‘there’) is merely missing after *ren* (‘one’). The *Daozang* and Jifu editions both include *you* after *ren*.

Bo Jun observes: Following Wang’s reading, if rendered as “formerly, there was one who claimed to know the Way to immortality,” then the one who knew the Way and the one who spoke would be two different people. This would not align with the subsequent text, where the speaker dies. Tao’s reading is closer to the mark.

The Lord of Yan sent someone to learn it. Before success was achieved, the speaker died. [Bo Jun observes: The *Han Feizi*, in its *Wai Chu Shuo Zuo Shang* chapter, reads: “The scholar he sent had not yet finished learning when he died abroad. The king was enraged and executed him.”]

[The *Shiwen* reads: *jie* is pronounced *yì*.]

The Lord of Yan was furious and intended to execute his envoy.

[The *Shiwen* reads: *shi* is pronounced *shì*.]

A favored minister admonished him, saying: “Nothing concerns people more urgently than death, and nothing do they value more than life. He himself lost his life—how could he have enabled you to avoid death?” Thus, he was not executed.

There was a man of Qi who also wished to learn the Way. When he heard that the speaker had died, he struck his chest in regret. Fuzi, hearing of this, laughed and said: “He desired to learn the Way to immortality, yet when the man died, he still regretted it—this is to not understand the purpose of learning.”

Huzi said: “Fuzi’s words are wrong. There are those who possess a method but cannot practice it, and there are those who can practice it but lack the method. There was a man of Wei skilled in calculation who, on the verge of death, explained the method to his son in detail.”

The character 「决」 appears as 「诀」 in the *Daozang* white-text edition, Lin Xiyi’s edition, the Shidetang edition, and the Jifu edition. Bo Jun notes: The *Shuowen Jiezi* supplement states, “‘诀’ means to part. Another definition: method.” However, *决* may be interchangeable with *诀*, as in Bao Zhao’s poem in the *Wen Xuan*: “About to depart, he returned once more to take leave,” where Li Shan’s commentary states, “‘诀’ is the same as ‘决.’” Here, *决* means *诀*—method. The son memorized his father’s words but could not practice them. When others asked him, he relayed what his father had said. The questioner applied the words and practiced the method, achieving results no different from the father’s. If this is so, why could the dead not transmit the method for living?

**[Annotation]**
Some things can be spoken but not practiced, while others can be practiced but not spoken—such are the differences in talent and nature.

**[Explanation]**
Some claim that certain methods are false, arguing that one may merely expound empty words to debate principles without personally practicing or verifying them, thus doubting the truth of their teachings. This passage, therefore, speaks of those who possess knowledge, those who possess knowledge but cannot practice it, and those who can practice but do not possess knowledge. Thus, knowing without practicing, practicing without knowing, or neither knowing nor practicing—though all may attain awakening—are not without distinction. Moreover, those who hear the teaching and put it into practice, gaining understanding through knowledge—are they not superior to those who do not comprehend the words?

The people of Handan presented doves to Jianzi on the first morning of the first month. Jianzi was greatly pleased and richly rewarded them. A guest asked the reason.

Jianzi said, "Releasing creatures on the first morning of the new year demonstrates benevolence." The guest replied, "The people, knowing that you wish to release them, *compete to capture them*—thus many die. If you truly wish to preserve their lives, it would be better to forbid the people from capturing them at all. To capture and then release them is a benevolence that cannot compensate for the harm done."

Jianzi said, "You are right."

**Explanation:** When people know how to perform good deeds, they focus only on superficial acts. If one addresses the root, though few may understand, the benefit far exceeds that of tending to the branches. Thus, small acts of kindness are but thieves of true benevolence. The traces of moral teachings attend to the branches; the power of the Great Dao attends to the root. Most people see only the small and fail to recognize the great—hence this example of releasing doves is given to clarify this grand principle.

The Tian clan of Qi performed ancestral rites in their courtyard, hosting a thousand guests. During the feast, someone presented fish and geese. The patriarch sighed and said, "How generous is Heaven toward the people! It cultivates the five grains and brings forth fish and birds for their use." The guests echoed his words in unison.

Bao’s son, twelve years old, was among the attendants. He stepped forward and said, "It is not as you say. Heaven and earth, the myriad things, and we ourselves are born together as the same kind. There is no nobility or baseness among kinds—only self-regard that leads to mutual disdain. It is merely by differences in size and strength that they dominate one another, devouring each other in turn. They are not born for one another’s sake. Humans take what is edible and eat it—was it truly Heaven’s intent to create them for human consumption? Moreover, mosquitoes and gnats pierce our skin, tigers and wolves devour flesh—was it Heaven’s intent to create humans for mosquitoes and gnats, or flesh for tigers and wolves?"

**Explanation:** That creatures of prey consume one another extinguishes Heaven’s principle—how could this be Heaven’s will? Bao’s son spoke rightly to the heart of the matter. There was once a vulgar scholar who claimed that Fuxi invented nets and traps, and Suiren cooked meat for food. Yet these two emperors were sages—how far are sages from tigers that eat flesh? The sutras of the Buddha are not like the teachings of China’s sages, which restrain people for their benefit. The Buddha possesses the six penetrations, while the sages’ teachings restrain perception for the sake of liberating sentient beings. Now, the *Liezi* once again clarifies this principle—thus the teachings of the Great Dao have never differed.

A poor man in Qi was accustomed to begging in the marketplace. The townspeople, weary of his frequent appeals, gave him nothing. He then went to the Tian clan’s stables, where he worked alongside the stablehands and borrowed food. Someone in the capital mocked him, saying, "To eat by serving the stablehands—is this not shameful?" The beggar replied, "There is no greater shame in the world than begging."

The beggar said, "If even begging is not shameful, how could serving the stablehands be shameful?" The note explains: he did not consider working for the stablehands a disgrace. This chapter illustrates that when things reach their extreme, divisions are already fixed, and thus all sense of honor and shame is lost—how much more so for those who naturally level gain and loss?

The commentary states: There are scholars who break their limbs or lick sores to gain advancement, all for the sake of clothing and food. Those who labor at the gates of lowly physicians also seek clothing and food. If they gain much profit, they consider it honor; if little, they consider it shame. Yet who among people truly understands the reality of honor and shame?

Qin Enfu notes: In the commentary, "breaking limbs" refers to "breaking branches." Mencius says, "To break a branch for an elder." Zhao Qi’s annotation explains: "Breaking branches means massaging the joints to relieve fatigue."

There was a man from Song who, while traveling on the road, found a discarded wooden tally. The note explains: "discarded" means abandoned. Wang Chongmin observes: The *Taiping Yulan* (499) omits the character "traveling." The tally was a notched piece of wood used to record matters. He took it home and hid it, secretly counting its teeth. The note explains: the notches resembled teeth. Wang Zhong comments: According to the note, the "tally" here refers to the carved notches, synonymous with "engraving." Yang Bojun notes: The matching parts of a tally are its teeth, used to verify authenticity. The *Yilin* states: "The left tally matches the right, their teeth aligning." Thus, upon finding the tally, the man secretly counted its teeth. He told his neighbor, "I shall soon be rich!" The note explains: Those who use empty names to seek real gain are like holding a discarded tally to claim wealth.

The commentary states: Ordinary people, deluded by empty names and losing sight of truth, are all like picking up a lost wooden tally, counting its notches to await riches. They are also like those who feel no shame in begging in the marketplace yet feel shame in serving others. How is this different from a runaway slave abandoning his master to serve another? The labor is no different, yet he believes himself no longer bound to anyone. Following deluded emotions while losing true principle—such is the nature of all these cases.

There was a man with a withered parasol tree. His neighbor, an elder, said that withered parasol trees were inauspicious. Yang Bojun notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Qu You* chapter) uses "good" instead of "auspicious." The neighbor hastily chopped it down. The note explains: Though his words were fair, he spoke out of place. Yu Yue argues: The character "neighbor" is superfluous. Above, it says "a man had a withered parasol tree," and here it says "his man," referring to this same person. The "neighbor elder" mentioned throughout refers to this man’s neighbor—how could it then refer to the neighbor as "this man"? Below, it says, "The man was displeased, saying..."—also without the character "neighbor," proving that "neighbor" here is extraneous. The neighbor elder then asked to take it as firewood. The note explains: He further treads a dubious path. Wang Shumin observes: The *Liu Tie* (16) omits the character "man," and the current text’s "man" may be an interpolation from the surrounding text. The *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Qu You* chapter) also omits "man." The man was displeased, saying, "The neighbor elder merely wanted firewood and thus urged me to cut it down. Living beside me, how treacherous he is—how can this be?" The note explains: In doubtful matters, things cannot be trusted.

The commentary states: Urging him to cut the tree was a fair suggestion; asking for it as firewood was reasonable. Yet urging its felling while requesting it raised suspicions of ulterior motives. Thus it is said: What people fear, one must fear. Do not think it harmless—its misfortune will grow. This is what it means.

There was a man who lost his axe. The note explains: "axe" refers to a hatchet. He suspected his neighbor’s son. Yang Bojun notes: There should be a "man" after "neighbor," as below it also says "neighbor’s son," and the *Taiping Yulan* (763) renders it as "neighbor’s son," though it omits "of," the character "man" is not missing. He observed the son’s gait—he had stolen the axe; his complexion—he had stolen the axe; his speech—he had stolen the axe; his movements and demeanor—nothing did not suggest he had stolen the axe. The *Sibu Congkan* edition omits "gait." Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (763) renders "movements and demeanor" as "demeanor and movements," which is correct. Below, it says, "Another day, he saw his neighbor’s son again, and his demeanor and movements no longer resembled those of an axe thief." Yang Bojun notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Qu You* chapter) also uses "demeanor and movements." Wang’s observation is correct. Here, following Lu Chongxuan’s edition and the *Daozang Sijie* edition for emendation. The *Shiwen Leiju* (Bieji 18) and *He Bi Shilei* (Xuxi 33) also use "demeanor and movements." Soon after, he dug in his valley and found his axe. Another day, he saw his neighbor’s son again. Wang Shumin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (763), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (55, 59), *Shiwen Leiju* (Bieji 18), and *He Bi Shilei* (Xuxi 33) all omit the character "man." His demeanor and movements no longer resembled those of an axe thief.

His demeanor and movements no longer resembled those of an axe thief.

**Note:** When the mind is biased and deluded, it shifts and alters with one’s thoughts and intentions. In extreme cases, white and black become indistinguishable, square and round merge in form—how could this be a change in external things? Thus, the saying goes: the myriad affairs, tangled and confused, all arise from the mind.

**Exegesis:** Many misfortunes stem from doubts and resemblances. Even the fall of a kite or a mouse may breed suspicion and disaster. Only those who accumulate virtue, uphold the Dao, and remain impartial and selfless can avoid such calamities. The case of losing an axe and suspecting a neighbor is but one example.

**Note (variant):** The phrase *"how could this be a change in external things"* appears in the *Daozang Sijie* edition as *"how could external things have the power to change them?"*

**Phonetic Gloss:** *fù* (復), *fúyòu* (扶又) cut.

When Viscount Bai of Shen plotted rebellion,

**Note:** *Lǜ* (慮) means "to consider" or "to scheme," here referring to plotting rebellion.

**Phonetic Gloss:** *shèng* (勝), *shīzhèng* (詩證) cut.

he left court and stood, leaning on his staff upside down, its spike piercing his chin.

**Note:** *zhuì* (錣) refers to the pointed tip of a staff.

**Pei Jun’s Note:** The *Hanfeizi* (*Yu Lao* chapter) reads: *"He left court, inverted his staff, and its spike pierced his chin."*

**Phonetic Gloss:** *zhuì* (錣), *zhāngliè* (張劣) cut. Xu Shen’s commentary on the *Huainanzi* states: *"A horse whip has a sharp iron tip to prod a horse that refuses to advance."*

Blood flowed to the ground, yet he was unaware. A man of Zheng, hearing of this, said: *"If one can forget one’s chin, what else could one not forget?"*

**Note:** In the Northern Song edition and the *Shide Tang* edition, *"chin"* (頤) appears as *"head"* (頭).

When the mind is fixated, one’s steps may stumble over roots or pits,

**Phonetic Gloss:** *zhǔ* (屬), *zhú* (烛) sound. *zhuó* (著), *zhíluè* (直略) cut. *zhì* (踬), "to stumble." *kǎn* (埳), "pit."

one’s head may strike a wooden post, yet one remains oblivious.

**Pei Jun’s Note:** The passage *"When the mind is fixated..."* also appears in the *Huainanzi* (*Yuandao Xun*).

**Phonetic Gloss:** *dǐ* (抵), *dīnglǐ* (丁礼) cut.

Long ago, a man of Qi coveted gold. At dawn, he dressed and went to the market. Arriving at the gold vendor’s stall, he seized the gold and left.

**Phonetic Gloss:** *yìguān* (衣冠), both in departing tone. *yù* (鬻), *yù* (育) sound.

The authorities arrested him and asked: *"With people all around, why did you seize another’s gold?"*

**Wang Chongmin’s Note:** The *Leiju* (83), *Taiping Yulan* (810), and *Lüshi Chunqiu* all include the word *"reason"* (故) after *"why"* (何). The *Huainanzi* (*Fanlun Xun*) reads *"why"* (何故) as *"what"* (何也).

**Wang Shumin’s Note:** The *Liushitie* (8), *Shilei Fu* (9), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (1, 55), *Shiwen Leiju Xuxi* (25), and *Tianzhong Ji* (50) all include the word *"reason"* (故).

**Phonetic Gloss:** The text reads: *"Why did you seize another’s gold?"* (子攫人之金何故), with a variant omitting *"reason"* (故).

He replied: *"When I took the gold, I saw no one—only the gold."*

**Note:** The chaos wrought by craving and desire upon the human heart is this severe. Thus, the ancients said: *"One who examines the tip of an autumn hair cannot see the form of Mount Tai; one who tunes the harmony of the five notes cannot hear the sound of thunder. When the mind is ensnared by the myriad things and attached to externals, even great forms and sounds may be overlooked. How much more so for one whose heart strays from principle, who restrains emotions and gathers thoughts, abiding in tranquil stillness—how could the movements of the myriad things disturb them?"*

**Exegesis:** Zhang Zhan states: *"The chaos wrought by craving and desire upon the human heart is this severe. Thus, it is said: 'One who examines the tip of an autumn hair cannot see the form of Mount Tai; one who listens to the harmony of the five notes cannot hear the sound of thunder.' When the mind is fixed on something, the body may be forgotten—all such cases are like this."* This chapter speaks of the great harm in indulging desires, which can destroy the body and extinguish one’s nature. Now, one seeks to enrich the self with that which destroys it. If one could be without self, what need would there be for gold? To speak of being without self is not to destroy the self, but merely not to indulge it.

**Note:** In the *Daozang Sijie* edition, the word *"thus"* (因) appears after *"how"* (豈), likely in error.

**Lu Wenchang’s Note:** The word *"thing"* (物) in the note may be superfluous.

**Pei Jun’s Note:** Lu’s suggestion is uncertain. It is likely that *"the movements of the myriad things"* (萬物動之) should read *"the movements of the myriad things"* (萬物之動), with *"movements"* (動) and *"of"* (之) transposed.

**Phonetic Gloss:** *zhuó* (著), *zhíluè* (直略) cut. *bó* (泊), *hún* (魂) sound, meaning "tranquil and composed."
